PETITION.TITLE: Kakadu National Park
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament. The Petition of the undersigned shows:
That we oppose any mineral exploration or mining in any part of Kakadu National Park, the Kakadu Conservation Zone, or the Alligator Rivers Region.

Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should halt all mineral exploration and mining in the Kakadu conservation zone by revoking current leases and licences and by incorporating the zone in Kakadu National Park and prevent proposed mining in Kakadu stages one and two by incorporating the Jabiluka and Koongarra project areas in the National Park and by proclamation the whole park under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act, 1983.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and senators in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth:

That your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs-including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat-and place them, for cost saving reasons only, on a special list requiring Authority from a Canberra Bureaucrat, and;

That we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to waste valuable time referring a case to a person in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senators in Parliament assembled will call on the Government to immediately abandon the proposal and keep its election promise of high quality and universal health care for all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President and the members of the Senate assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That we most strongly oppose the process of `food irradiation' by Cobalt 60, Caesium-137, Caesium-134 or any machine sources.
That we oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process being permitted by State Governments.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Federal Government ban the importation of any radio-active substances or machinery for the purpose of food irradiation, disallow regulations permitting the irradiation of food in Australia, and ban the irradiation of food in this country.
We also call upon the Federal Government to withdraw from the Asian Regional Co-operative Project on Food Irradiation and the International Consultative Group on Food Irradiation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sporting, Cultural and Community Groups: Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned.
(i) are alarmed that many sporting, cultural and community groups have been made to feel that they can attract sponsorship only from promotors of unhealthy products;
(ii) call for a National Health Promotion Foundation to be established through an increase in tobacco excise of 10 cents per packet; and

(iii) urge that the National Health Promotion Foundation provide national sporting, cultural and community groups with alternative sponsorship funding so that these groups can flourish without the taint of accepting money from tobacco companies and assisting in the promotion of their unhealthy products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: Metered Calls
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
(1) That we oppose time local calls by Telecom.
(2) Timed calls will seriously affect pensioners, the elderly, low income earners and other disadvantaged groups.
Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should not introduce time calls in the absence of widespread community support.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned,

note that a majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material has strongly opposed the proposition that a new NVE category will contain that material as defined in the current `X' classification.

call upon the Senate to request the Government immediately to implement the recommendation of the majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material by introducing substantive legislation to ensure that X rated video material (and its R rated equivalent) is refused classification for the purpose of Commonwealth laws.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled. The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia.
Respectfully showeth
that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide independent radio and television service
that the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia
that the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray

PETITION.TITLE: Elector Initiated Referenda
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectively showeth:

That while having some reservations on individual aspects of the Constitutional Alteration (Electors Initiative) Bill 1987 your petitioners wish to express our strong support for the concept of people's democracy implied in that Bill.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will refer the above mentioned Bill to an appropriate Parliamentary Committee and will examine the operations of direct democracy procedures overseas with the intention of passing legislation granting such facilities to your petitioners during the Bicentennial year.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitution Alteration Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That the constitution of the Commonwealth has served Australia well, is not out of date, has proved to be flexible and should not be radically altered.

2. Our deep concern that the recommendations of the constitutional commission and its advisory committees which propose radical changes to the constitution are threatening to reduce our rights as citizens of the Commonwealth.

3. Our strongest opposition to any referendum proposals of the Hawke government which give more power to the Government and less to the people and which concentrate that power in Canberra at the expense of the States and weakens the role of the Senate.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Vessels in Australian Waters
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President of the Senate and senators in Parliament assembled:

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, strongly urge that the Australian Government prohibit the entry of nuclear-armed or nuclear-powered vessels into Australian ports or waters during our bicentennial celebrations and at any other time in the future.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Release of Confidential Medical Information
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:

That we express grave concern about the public release of confidential medical information by the Government, sufficient to enable the public identification of doctors and their patients and calls upon the Parliament to censure all those involved in this gross abuse of the privacy of all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Sales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, being concerned that the Australian Government, in breach of its own stated policies, has lifted the bans on the sale of uranium to France; demand that the Government re-impose the bans on such sales, and further, that the Government ratifies and strengthens the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty to prohibit uranium sales within the region.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short statement and a brief description of the scrutiny of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances and of the Committee's correspondence with the two Ministers.

The documents read as follows-

The Committee at its last meeting considered correspondence received from the Minister for Industrial Relations, the Hon. Ralph Willis, M.P., and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the Hon. John Kerin, M.P.

The Minister for Industrial Relations supplied additional information which answered the concerns that the Committee had in relation to Defence Determinations Nos 14 and 15 of 1988. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy gave the Committee a number of undertakings in connection with the Committee's concerns which were raised with respect to the three Plans of Management made under the Fisheries Act.
The Committee thanks the two Ministers involved for their co-operation in these matters.
SUMMARY OF COMMITTEE'S SCRUTINY
Defence Determinations Nos 14 and 15 of 1988

Defence Determination No. 14 amended certain provisions relating to the payment of financial entitlements to the dependants or the estate of a former member of the Defence Force. Clause 6 of the Determination contained a discretionary provision, the nature of which was of concern to the Committee. The Minister for Industrial Relations, the Hon. Ralph Willis, M.P., indicated that this Determination extended the provisions of clause 6 to cover former cadet force members and that the exercise of the discretion was qualified by other clauses of the Determination.

Defence Determination No. 15 contained a reclassification of localities for the purposes of calculating the rate of Post Allowances. The Determination contained an element of retrospectivity and the Committee was concerned that, in respect of the reclassification of Manila in the Philippines, no loss of entitlement would occur to an eligible member. The Minister indicated that the reclassification was a beneficial provision which would not prejudice any eligible member.
The Committee thanks the Minister for his co-operation in these matters.
Northern Prawn Fishery Management Plan (Amendment), Northern Prawn Fishery (Special Provisions) Management Plan (Repeal) as contained in Plan of Management No. 16.

The Committee raised with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the Hon. John Kerin, M.P., concerns in relation to (i) the presentation of the Plan of Management which was in a photocopied form with no Notes or gazettal information; (ii) a number of typographical errors in the Plan presented to the Committee; and (iii) the drafting style of one paragraph which appeared to confer discretionary powers on officials in circumstances where there may have been no intention to do so.

The Minister indicated to the Committee that there were administrative difficulties in the production of this Plan of Management and that a number of the drafting errors would be corrected in the next amendment to the Plan. He further indicated to the Committee that a standard ``loose-leaf'' format would now be used in the presentation of plans of management which would overcome the committee's criticisms in relation to this plan. The Minister undertook to amend the paragraph in relation to the discretionary power to ensure that any ambiguity was removed.
The Committee thanks the Minister for his co-operation in these matters.
South East Trawl Fishery Preliminary Management Plan as Amended as contained in Plan of Management No. 17.

The Committee's concerns with this Plan of Management related to a number of paragraphs which contained apparent unreviewable discretions that could be exercised by officials; drafting and presentational problems with the new ``loose-leaf'' format; and the legislative authority which provided a safeguard of the right of review of a decision by an official concerning the endorsement of a licence.

The Minister indicated to the Committee that the unreviewable discretions contained in the paragraphs referred to by the Committee were unintended and that the paragraphs would be re-drafted to avoid any ambiguity. The Minister further undertook to provide that, in future Explanatory Statements, details of how each amended provision had been altered would be included. The Minister indicated that the right of review would be safeguarded by the provisions of section 16a of the Fisheries Act 1952.
The Committee thanks the Minister for his co-operation in these matters.
Southern Shark Fishery Management Plan as contained in Plan of Management No. 18.

The Committee's first concern with Plan of Management No. 18 related to the inclusion of certain paragraphs that contained apparent unreviewable discretions that could be exercised by officials. The Minister indicated that, as with Plan of Management No. 17, the discretions were unintended, and gave an undertaking that the necessary amendments would be made.

The Committee's second concern related to the use by officials of criteria published by the Department in a document that appeared not to be subject to disallowance by Parliament. The Minister indicated that the document which contained the criteria and which was referred to in the Plan was used as a basis of decision-making prior to the Plan coming into force. The Committee accepted, on this occasion, the Minister's contention that the document did not need to be subject to Parliamentary review, as the document was used as a guideline for officials in exercising discretionary powers under the Fisheries Act prior to the Plan of Management entering into force and that the classification process had been subjected to the two-tier review process under section 16a of the Act.

The Committee's third concern was in relation to a lack of criteria guiding the Minister in the exercise of an exemption discretion concerning the allocation of units following the splitting up of a licensing package. The Minister undertook to amend the Plan to ensure that any exemptions can only be achieved by further amendments to the Plan rather than by an administrative decision.
The Committee thanks the Minister for his co-operation in these matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate both as Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and as Minister representing the Prime Minister. I ask: Will he continue to urge the Prime Minister to establish a timetable for his departure, despite the fact that his colleague Senator Ray is quoted in today's Age as saying, `If Hawke has a timetable in mind he should keep it at the very most to himself and Keating, and probably to himself'? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a very good effort by Senator Chaney, but there is no conflict between the advice he says Senator Ray tendered to the Prime Minister and the advice-if it might be called advice-or the comments which I made on Friday, which were televised on Sunday. That is a matter which I am sure is capable of resolution, quite distinct from the problems of the Opposition however, where there is no resolution of any of these problems in sight. It has a Deputy Leader who does not want to become leader-the most reluctant deputy leader in the history of this country-because he knows he will go down the chute at the next election if he does, and a Leader who is incapable of leading the Opposition to any successful result in any foreseeable election. ANSWER.PARA: Is there something really wrong with the coalition and its leadership, do you think?

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is he aware that the Queensland Government may be using Commonwealth funds to mount an intensive television advertising campaign against the referendum for fair and democratic elections? What action can the Government take to stop such a misuse of Federal funds?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I received information this morning of a very intensive television campaign, against the fair elections referendum in particular, that the Queensland National Party Government is conducting. I understand that the Government has already admitted that it has spent some $800,000 of public money on that campaign. It has, of course, a very strong vested interest in ensuring that fair and democratic elections are not held. I note for the record that, perhaps for equally self-interested reasons, the Queensland Liberal Party is fighting with the Queensland National Party over this issue. I have a clipping from the Brisbane Sunday Sun which quotes the former Queensland Minister, Russ Hinze, as saying:

ANSWER.PARA: I've carried the National Party, unlike some of the seats in Queensland that are rigged to the extent that the boundaries . . . that all you have to do is set the NP tag and you can win it forever and a day.

That comes from Mr Hinze's own mouth and demonstrates the degree to which the Queensland National Party has been dependent upon an unfair and undemocratic electoral system to keep itself in government.

I understand that last night, between the hours of 6 pm and 8.30 pm, at least seven advertisements appeared on the major commercial television stations in Queensland for the Queensland Government, taxpayer-funded campaign against the referendum. One does not have to keep that up for very long to get away with $800,000. It seems likely that the campaign would amount to more like $2m of taxpayers' money being shamelessly spent by the Queensland Government in an attempt to ensure the continuation of the corrupt electoral system to which it owes its political power. From past experience, it will be very difficult to get a proper account from Queensland as to the amount of money that it spent.

I was also asked by Senator Colston about what action the Commonwealth Government can take. I do not think there is anything the Commonwealth Government can do directly about this misuse of taxpayers' money by the National Party Government of Queensland, but I will speak to the Treasurer to sound out his views on whether an appropriate deduction should be made from the financial assistance grants paid to Queensland next year so that it will at least get the message that if it continues to spend taxpayers' money for such improper purposes, effectively it will be fined for doing so.
