—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Has the staff level of the Office of the Supervising Scientist (OSS) for the Alligator Rivers Region grown to the unacceptable level of 70, as described in a report entitled Prospects for the Northern Territory's Nuclear Industry by the Northern Territory Minister for Mines and Energy, Mr Barry Coulter, in which Mr Coulter stated that the OSS `has grown in a manner never envisaged by Mr Justice Fox'?
—Just answer yes and trans- fer it to the Northern Territory.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot do that, Senator; I am sorry. The Government rejects any assertion by Mr Coulter or anyone else that the OSS has grown into an organisation that is performing functions that were not envisaged by Mr Justice Fox. I suggest that the opposite is the case. Obviously, like all organisations, it worries about its staff and its capacity to perform the tasks that have been allotted to it. Currently, the staffing level of the OSS is 73. Two-thirds are located in the Northern Territory and the remainder are in Sydney. All of the laboratory facilities are in Jabiru and all the research staff except three are located there. Obviously one can argue, I suppose, that there is no need for a Sydney office, but at the end of the day the cost of accommodation for the OSS staff in Jabiru, in particular, is extraordinary. If one notes what we have had to spend to house just a few in the conservation zone, one sees that it gets even worse. In fact, relocation expenditure of about $5m for housing and other facilities in Jabiru would be required if we wanted to close down the Sydney part of the operation.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Coulter also commented on the lack of returns for the uranium industry as a whole. I have been quite surprised at times by the attitude of Energy Resources of Australia Ltd (ERA) to the operations of the OSS. It would seem to me that over time the OSS has proved useful to ERA in demonstrating that ERA is, by and large, conducting its operations correctly. That monitoring helps, and I hope we can see it continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that the Office of the Supervising Scientist is a key element in the protection of the Alligator Rivers-Kakadu National Park region from the effects of uranium mining and that the OSS 1985-86 annual report recommended a staff of 85 for the Office to be fully effective, will the Minister ensure that the functions of the OSS to protect the region are not emasculated, as Mr Coulter would like them to be, but enhanced, and that a proper staffing level of at least 85 be given to the OSS? The OSS's own report states that because of current staff level cuts there are notable gaps in much needed research. For example, two biologists and a hydrochemist for the study of waste water management are immediate priorities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have already said, the current level of staff is 73. I realise that the OSS would like 85 staff. Indeed, all the agencies in my portfolio, and I dare say all the ones in my colleagues' portfolios, would like more staff. Nonetheless, it is our job to attempt to estimate what is an adequate number. I know that there are staff gaps. Obviously, when one is talking about laboratory facilities in a place like Jabiru, one cannot cover every single discipline. That is just not possible. For that reason, the OSS is able to fill in the gaps by making sure that it uses facilities at major universities, the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and the like. So I do not really believe that there are gaps. If and when I am convinced that there are any, I will do something about them.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. On 11 May last year I asked the Minister, in his then capacity as Minister for Resources and Energy, whether he would support a proposal put to the Australian and New Zealand governments by Mr Harold Evans, a prominent former New Zealand jurist. The proposal was for the two governments to initiate in the United Nations General Assembly a request to the International Court of Justice (IJC) for an advisory opinion on the legality or otherwise of nuclear weapons. The Minister, in his response on that occasion, said that he would let the Senate know when he had reached a considered opinion on the matter. He has not let the Senate know. I do not know whether that is because he has not reached a considered opinion; whether he does not have an opinion at all; or whether it is just because he changed portfolios. In any event, I ask: Is the Minister aware that the Australian section of the International Commission of Jurists has expressed support for the proposal? Has the Minister and/or his successor reached the conclusion that Australia should support such proposed action? If the Minister does not agree that Australia should initiate such action, would he be prepared to give Australia's support to other United Nations members taking such an initiative?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that the Australian section of the International Commission of Jurists has expressed support for the proposal. As to the more substantive question of the Government response, it has been given consideration within the highest levels of the Government. In fact, the Prime Minister replied to Mr Evans-no relative-some months ago explaining the Government's position, which is along the following lines: The Government is not convinced that referring the issue of the legality of nuclear weapons to the International Court of Justice would constitute a practical and effective means of achieving progress toward the objective of a world without nuclear weapons which is, of course, an objective we all share or, at least, honourable senators on this side of the chamber, running round about as far as Senator Haines.

ANSWER.PARA: President Reagan and Mr Gorbachev agreed as long ago as their 1985 summit meeting in Geneva that a nuclear war cannot be won and must never be fought. Underlying this shared view is the conviction, on the part of both the United States and the Soviet Union, that nuclear war between them could not advance their national interests. That mutual conviction would seem to be a more compelling practical restraint on the nuclear weapons states than any ICJ judgment that nuclear weapons are illegal. Even if the ICJ were to conclude that nuclear weapons are illegal under international law, the practical impact of its judgment would be ambiguous. The existence of nuclear weapons is not simply a legal question; their existence has direct implications for the security situation and the defence planning of many countries. Of course, this state of affairs has existed for many years and the goal of the reduction and ultimate elimination of existing nuclear arsenals and preventing the emergence of new nuclear weapons states is most productively pursued in negotiating forums where these considerations and related matters, such as effective means of verification, can be addressed.

The Government's objective is, as I have said on many occasions in this place, the maintenance of international security at the lowest possible level of armament, both nuclear and conventional. In pursuing that objective we have in place coherent and appropriate policies. In terms of our priorities in this area, however, we could not give a high priority to a referral to the ICJ of the issue of the legality of nuclear weapons because, for all the reasons I have indicated, we do not consider that it would be more likely to lead to the effective arms control and disarmament measures which we all seek. Nevertheless, I guess that the whole of the Government sympathises strongly with the intent behind Mr Evans's initiative and we share with him the commitment to build a more truly peaceful world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I listened to the Minister's response. I wonder whether he could give some indication of on what the Prime Minister bases his belief that a referral of the sort such as Mr Evans proposed would not be helpful, either as a practical response, which I think were the words that were used in the Minister's answer, or as an additional response to the nuclear weapons issue.

—There is nothing that I can usefully add to my answer. It is a matter for judgment, all things considered, as to, firstly, whether any kind of a legal foundation could possibly substantiate such an initiative and, secondly, whether it is likely to be of practical utility in terms of the way in which nation states around the world, conscious of their security and defence concerns, are likely to respond. Whether it has some statutory, moral or emotional force and effect such as to justify embarking upon the initiative is, I guess, as I said, a matter for judgment, but it is not something about which we would be so confident as to justify its being given a high priority.

—Does the Minister representing the Attorney-General recall that during the debate on the Australian Bill of Rights I raised fears that its provisions could be used to strike down criminal laws on abortion? Does he recall saying around about that time that this would not be possible since the measure was introduced by Mr Lionel Bowen, whom he described publicly as a Catholic father of seven? Does he also recall Senator Gareth Evans stating that the Australian Bill of Rights would operate in a similar way to the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms? Is the Minister aware that recently the Supreme Court of Canada struck down criminal laws on abortion in Canada as they infringe the liberty and security provisions of that very same Canadian Charter of Rights and Liberties? Is this not an example of the dangers of governments framing broadly based, loosely worded laws such as the Australian Bill of Rights which are open to interpretation by judges who are far from the will of the people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question asked does not relate to any particular legislation currently before the Parliament or any legislation proposed to be brought into the Parliament. It is about an old debate on the proposed Bill of Rights which was before the Parliament some time ago. It may be the case that the Canadian Supreme Court has made a determination resulting in the decision outlined by Senator Harradine. But whether it was in relation to words of an identical type to be found in the Bill of Rights proposal that was put to this Parliament, for example, I am quite unable to say. I am not sure that it was based on trying to embody the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights-and I do not believe it was. I doubt whether the wording was exactly the same as that which we proposed.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Harradine has, with due respect I imagine, asked this question because he thinks it has some relevance to the present fourth proposal being put to the people by way of referendum to which we seek their assent on 3 September. I want to say very clearly that the extension of the three rights and freedoms presently contained in the Constitution to do with trial by jury, the acquisition of property on just terms, and freedom of religion, which are presently, as the framers intended, contained in the Constitution as a safeguard for the people against the Commonwealth and which protection we propose to extend to the States and Territories, does not in any sense of the word amount to a Bill of Rights. Sir Anthony Mason, the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia, noted that the common law system:

. . . does not protect fundamental rights as comprehensively as do constitutional guarantees . . . The common law is not as invincible a safeguard against violations of fundamental rights as it was once thought to be.

It is for that reason that the Parliament has thought fit to put to the people the question of whether they want to provide an additional safeguard to our general common law tradition, to safeguard those important rights of trial by jury, freedom of religion, and the acquisition of property on just terms by way of constitutional guarantee, against State and Territory governments, not merely the Commonwealth Government of Parliament as is presently provided. The Chief Justice went on to say, in an address to the Australian Bar Association Conference on 11 July, of this referendum proposal:
By no stretch of the human imagination do those modest proposals amount to a Bill of Rights.

It is very important to know that the present Chief Justice of Australia, speaking not from the bench but in an address to the Australian Bar Association, characterised the referendum questions in that way, at least as not amounting to a Bill of Rights. It is very important that we keep in mind that these proposals are modest; they are modest extensions to rights already thought to be important by the framers of the Constitution back in the late nineteenth century. It is important when dealing with the Canadian and the United States experience to concentrate on the actual words contained in their constitutions and bills of rights provisions. The United States constitution, for example, does not use the same words as we propose to use in section 116, despite Senator Harradine's claims last week that identical terms are to be used, and the Catholic bishops seemed to think that they were to be much the same terms. They are quite different terms. Therefore, if one goes to Canadian or United States Supreme Court decisions which interpret different clauses and different words, that is not to find precedents that would appeal to our High Court.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question which arises directly out of the Minister's response. I do not know why he assumed that I was referring to the last question. However, since he has responded to and addressed that question, I ask: is it not a fact that the late Mr Justice Murphy interpreted section 116 in a manner similar to the interpretation placed by the majority of the Supreme Court of the United States in respect of a similar provision, which results in state school children being refused religious education even when request cards are signed by parents? Is it not a fact that Mr Justice Murphy's judgments are now being pointed to by various law schools throughout the country as being highly significant? Will the Minister give the Senate a guarantee that in future, say 20 years from now, there will not be a majority on the High Court of persons with similar mind to Mr Justice Murphy's?

—The High Court decision to which Senator Harradine referred is, of course, the defence of government schools case, the DOGS case, which dealt with the funding of church organised schools by the Commonwealth Government. Indeed, Mr Justice Murphy's judgment in that case was one of seven judgments. It was founded on reasoning which certainly did not compel the concurrence or adherence of any of his fellow judges. The fact is that the six judges of the High Court in that case put forward a compelling series of reasons for rebutting the assertion that the mere funding of schools by the Commonwealth in that instance amounted to an establishing of any religion in Australia. Those words are extremely important and quite different from the United States clause which speaks of an establishment of religion, which is quite a different concept. The decision in the DOGS case opens different angles. Nevertheless, cumulatively the six judgments by the majority of justices in the High Court provide sound reasoning and a sound basis for assuming that that decision will remain as the precedent governing this area.

—My question is also addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer to the considerable activity undertaken recently by the Hon. Gough Whitlam and Sir Maurice Byers, QC, both members of the Constitutional Commission, on behalf of the Yes case in the current referendum campaign. Will the Minister give an unqualified assurance that in those activities no moneys have been expended nor liability for expenditure incurred in respect of any aspect of the referendums in breach of section 11 (4) of the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act?

—I give an assurance that I am quite sure that Mr Gough Whitlam, the former Prime Minister, and Sir Maurice Byers will at all times seek to act in accordance with the law. I am confident that they will seek to do so. As for any application of that clause or their activities over a period of months, obviously I am unable to give a legal opinion as to whether the activities have fallen within the parameters of section 11 (4). But I am confident that it would be the intention of those very honourable gentlemen always to act in accordance with the requirements of the law of the Commonwealth passed by this Parliament.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I do not wish, at this juncture, to question the response that the Minister has given as to the intentions of the gentlemen concerned. I simply ask him: who has been paying the bills?

—In so far as it can be ascertained I will seek to find out whether in fact there has been any expenditure for which the Attorney-General might have any responsibility in relation to these activities. I repeat that, from my personal knowledge and of course the knowledge of other senators and members, it would always be the intention of both the former Prime Minister and the former Solicitor-General to act in accordance with the law.

—I ask the Minister for Finance whether he has seen an article published amongst the Budget coverage in last Wednesday's Hobart Mercury which strongly implies that Tasmania is treated poorly by the Federal Government. Is it in fact true, as stated in the article, that the Federal Government raises more revenue from Tasmania than it gives back? Does the Federal Government spend more on Antarctica than it does on Tasmania, as claimed? Will the Minister give an accurate account of the financial arrangements between the Commonwealth and Tasmania?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen an article written by one Barry Prismall who apparently once worked in the Canberra Press Gallery but obviously did not learn anything about Budget papers while he was there. He asserts in the article:

ANSWER.PARA: In fact, it can be argued that the state's PAYE taxpayers and companies alone pay more in tax to Canberra than the state gets in return each year.

He then goes on to juxtapose the payments of income tax by companies and individuals totalling $917m to the $905m that is returned to Tasmania in the form of Commonwealth payments and Loan Council borrowings as if that were the end of the cash flow to Tasmania. The logic of that argument, of course, is that no Tasmanian should or would receive an age pension, or a totally and permanently incapacitated pension, or a sickness benefit, or an unemployment benefit from Commonwealth resources. A list which one could add of course is that Tasmanians do not want to be defended and the point that is missed is that there are plenty of payments to people in Tasmania and expenses incurred on behalf of Tasmanians outside the category of Commonwealth payments to State and local government. As to the suggestion or the assertion that the Federal Government is spending more on the Antarctic than it is on Tasmania: the total expenditure on the Antarctic will be of the order of $48.2m compared to direct payments to Tasmanian governments of nearly $1 billion and payments to individuals in addition to that. It is very clear that if Mr Prismall has any expertise in any area at all, it is certainly not in the area of accountancy, or he has been fed a line by somebody-perhaps by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, who is quoted in today's Australian Financial Review as saying:
I am not an accountant and I do not approach the problem of cutting government spending as an accounting exercise.
Who needs any understanding of accounting when a bottle of snake oil will do?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in my gallery of a delegation from the Republic of Korea led by Mr Chung. On behalf of all senators I extend to the delegation a warm welcome and trust that their stay in Australia is a success.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In view of the media reports of increased civil unrest in Burma and a further report today warning that action might be taken against any embassy, does the Australian Government have any contingency plans in the event of any further deterioration to evacuate Australian nationals in the region?

—As honourable senators will be aware, since 8 August there have been extensive and serious disturbances in Burma and further large but peaceful demonstrations have been reported in recent days. We are keeping a close watch on the situation and the implications for Australian nationals there. Australians have been advised to defer non-essential travel to Burma. It is our assessment that Australians in Burma do not face imminent danger requiring evacuation although, of course, the situation is being kept under close review. Contingency plans are in place and the Australian Embassy in Rangoon is maintaining close contact with Australian nationals, who are presently reported safe and well.

—Can the Minister for Justice guarantee to the Senate and the Australian people that, as the official Yes case baldly and dishonestly claims, if referendum question No. 1 is carried there will be fewer Federal elections and certainly no Federal election this year? Given that the official Yes case states clearly that the business community strongly supports question No. 1 and in view of the fact that the Business Council of Australia, the Small Business Association of Australia and the Australia Chamber of Commerce-and the six State chambers of commerce and industry-do not support the Yes case, can the Minister let the electorate in on the well kept secret as to who precisely the Government has in mind in making yet another patently dishonest claim?

—The constant bleating by the Opposition that somehow or other the Government has been involved in dishonestly putting to the people its proposal for maximum four-year terms I think will be repudiated by the people on 3 September. The fact is that the proposal for a maximum four-year term does not frighten the electorate as the Opposition would like it to. It already exists in most jurisdictions, apart from Queensland, where of course a four-year term is quite common for the House of Assembly. Indeed, Tasmania has led the way in that respect. Senator Alston asked whether there will be fewer elections. Certainly there will not be any more half-Senate elections, which can be extremely disruptive and can create a situation where there are more frequent elections. That is one result of the passage of this legislation. We will not have those extra half-Senate elections which-
—Will there be simultaneous elections?

—The honourable senator asked me whether there will be fewer elections. I have given an example, constitutionally, where logic suggests that there will be fewer elections. In addition, a political atmosphere will be created where, with the extension of the maximum term from three years to four years, there will be greater stability, and I believe that the penalty exacted on a government which went to an early election would be very severe indeed, as indeed was the fate of Mr Corcoran in South Australia and former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser, when he went early in 1983. Having just voted for maximum four-year terms on 3 September, the people would deal extremely harshly with any government which ignored that expressed preference and called an early election.
—What about the business community? Answer the question.
—Honourable senators opposite have been putting such pressure on the business community that I see that even Andrew Hay may have changed his mind. I have not quite caught up with that.
—It does not take much pressure to make Andrew Hay change his mind.

—Senator Puplick tells us that Andrew Hay is a very malleable person indeed. That is certainly not the impression that he has tried to give the Australian people over the past several years. Indeed, that is one example that I am able to pull out of not very thin air but at least thin air. It is quite clear that any government could be tempted to make decisions not in the overall interests of the economic life of the nation if it had its eye cocked to an impending election which was around the corner. By extending the permissible term of the Parliament from three to four years that pressure or political imperative will be modified to that extent. I believe that it will create a situation where governments will make very sound decisions. We have not succumbed to the temptation I have spoken of under the term of Mr Keating as Treasurer and Senator Walsh as Minister for Finance, but we must remove that temptation and I believe that we can do so by extending the term in the way that has been proposed.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I know that the acoustics are bad on this side of the chamber, but we are still waiting with bated breath to hear the names of those business organisations that remain on board. In view of the fact that all sections of the business community no longer support the Yes case, I ask the Minister for Justice to name one that has.

—The fact is that we had good support from the business community in relation to this proposal because it understood, as apparently the Opposition does not, that the proposal is all about creating an atmosphere in which decisions can be taken without an eye on an impending election. Naturally that lends itself to stability, which is the climate in which business always prefers to operate.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and is also about the referenda next Saturday. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article in a South Australian regional newspaper reporting the comments of Mr Peter Reith, who I understand is the chairman of the Opposition's task force on the referenda? Is it true, as strongly implied by Mr Reith, that should the fourth question providing for freedom of religion in Australia be passed, this Government will abolish Christmas and Easter? Has the Liberal referendum campaign now moved from the sublime to the ridiculous?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps it has moved from the ridiculous to the sublime in considerations of Christmas and Easter. I am confident that after 3 September Christmas and Easter will still be part of our calendar. Mr Peter Reith, the shadow Attorney-General-by the way, he is not in Parliament again today to deal with these important referendum proposals, as happened last week, when I think he was out around the countryside rather than being in here in the Parliament, which is the task for which he was elected-was asked at this forum at the Town Hall at Balaclava, `Will Christmas and Easter be done away with?' His answer was, `We don't know and we don't want to find out'. The final part of the answer-`and we don't want to find out'-really summarises the position of Mr Reith as he has gone around the country on this campaign. He has been arousing fears and misgivings, rumourmongering, allowing people to remain ignorant rather than clarifying the situation, if that would help the Yes case. A clarification, of course, is called for--
—Tell us about the Catholic bishops.

—Senator Bishop mentions the Catholic bishops. Even they have not gone as far as to suggest that Christmas and Easter are about to be abolished if this particular referendum proposal is passed. Senator Bishop, in fact, has made some terrible allegations around the countryside as she has gone around, arousing fear and misgiving, with a particular racist touch.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator has kept on repeating the example of the magistrates court in Melbourne, where a person was convicted of assaulting his wife, having bound her to a bed for three or four days, subjecting her to assault, rape and other terrible abuses. When the man pleaded that the Koran permitted him to exact this sort of discipline on his wife it was rejected by the magistrate. It would continue to be rejected if this proposal were passed, as the honourable senator well knows, because the High Court of Australia has made it abundantly clear, in both the Jehovah's Witnesses case and the Scientology case, that the ordinary criminal law, the ordinary laws which are important for the cohesion of society, are not displaced by this provision. So I do not think I need to listen any further to Senator Bishop's interjections.

The most widespread concern amongst those who are taking a genuine interest in the question of section 116 and its impact on the community is the question of the funding of schools, hospitals and other community organisations which are organised by church bodies for the making available of services to the community. Indeed, the proposal put forward in referendum question No. 4 merely extends a right, a freedom, a guarantee which the framers thought was so important that they should put it in the Constitution and bind the Commonwealth to ensure that the Commonwealth Parliament could not make a law for the establishment of any religion, imposing any religious observance, or interfering with the free exercise of religion. We are simply saying that it is important that the States and Territories be bound in the same way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you change the wording?
—The wording has been altered in order to ensure that not only parliamentary but executive action is also taken up in this provision.
—What about prayers in schools?

—Voluntary prayers in schools will not be affected, as the honourable senator well knows. Sir Maurice Byers, who as Solicitor-General argued for the Commonwealth in the Defence of Government Schools case, has made it abundantly clear that in his opinion and in the opinion of those other learned members of the Constitutional Commission, such as Professor Zines and Professor Campbell, the change of words does not in any way put in jeopardy or imperil the funding of schools by governments.
—The bishops were not convinced.

—Senator Stone says that the bishops were not convinced. The bishops took a cautious approach, which I suppose initially could be understood. The proposed new section 116 is worded in a completely different way to the United States constitutional provision. I am sorry that the Catholic bishops' release uses words which indicate that they thought the provisions were identical in the relevant aspect. I do not think that the Catholic bishops have listened, perhaps, to all the warning bells in our society that they should be hearing. The Supreme Court of South Australia has said that the common law is not strong enough to withstand a State parliament which wished to interfere with freedom of religion. Sir Anthony Mason, whom I have already quoted earlier in Question Time, the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia, has also said that the common law is not the sort of invincible weapon which it was once thought it was, particularly in these areas.

ANSWER.PARA: Even the immigration debate, which we have heard rage over the last month or so, should remind us that the embers of racism being stirred in it can also have their analogy with minority groups who are composed of adherents of sects and religious groups which do not have majority approval or understanding. I believe that when those warning bells are properly heard in our society the case for the passage of this proposal is even stronger.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH SCIENTIFIC AND INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH ORGANISATION

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business to the decision to cut funding for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in real terms for the sixth successive year and remind him of the magnificent and invaluable work CSIRO has done for rural Australia, particularly the division of tropical crops and pastures in Brisbane, a division whose funds have already been cut by 45 per cent. Has the Government given any consideration to the consequences of these cuts on the Australian cattle industry, particularly the export sector, which must have high quality research to remain competitive? Is it not a fact that it is the Government's strategy to reduce CSIRO to obvious professional incompetence by strangling it of funds and then disbanding it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have news for Senator MacGibbon: that is not the Government's strategy, and never has been. The Government has had a strategy in relation to CSIRO which is to provide it with what we have termed a `core charter' for its research activities, which essentially relates--
—You put Neville Wran in charge. What more needs to be said?

—Senator Stone is mumbling away there. I was perhaps to put the CSIRO under him, I think. There has been a core charter devised for CSIRO. The organisation is being asked in respect of that aspect of its work, which will be continually funded by government, to continue with what it has traditionally been doing. On the other hand, CSIRO is being asked to obtain more financial support from the private sector for some of its activities in the more applied research area.
—He could make contributions from his cleaning companies.

—I wish Senator Stone would stop mumbling away. Why does he not go back to the bottom of the barrel and write for the Daily Mail for a little while, instead of interjecting in here? Every decent journalist in this country would not take up the invitation of that scurrilous newspaper, but this bloke did, and he comes in here mumbling away during Question Time. It was garbage that he could not write himself. He is at the bottom of the barrel, the lowest common denominator of Australian journalism. Where did the money go for that? Into the H. R. Nicholls Society, I suppose. I come back to the question, which concerns a great organisation-which I could never in a fit describe Senator Stone as-the CSIRO. The CSIRO is being asked to obtain more funds from the private sector for its activities, and we make no apology for that. The CSIRO budget, if it meets the targets which have been set by the Government, and which the Chief Executive of CSIRO and the Chairman of CSIRO say it can meet, will have a lot more money than the $360m approximately which has been provided by the Government over the last few years. The Government has also guaranteed the same funding in real terms for the next three years. I believe it to be the first time in the history of CSIRO that a government has made that undertaking.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator MacGibbon illustrated his point with a few references to the cattle industry and rural industries generally. The fact is that CSIRO has made a great contribution to those industries and will continue to do so. The Government is concerned that those industries have state of the art technology, as it is in respect of the mining sector and manufacturing industry generally. The CSIRO has a great mission in respect of all these things. Its importance as an institution in Australia cannot be underestimated but we have to get over the problem which has characterised Australian universities and scientific institutions of this kind-a lack of attention to the relationship between the organisation and industry. Anybody who thinks about that issue recognises that fact. The only person who has really advocated significant cuts to CSIRO is the Leader of the honourable senator's Party. He did that in the last election campaign. That was where he was going to bodger up some of the money for his phoney tax cuts, by attacking CSIRO and abolishing the export market development grants scheme. These things would have affected the industry infinitely more than any moderating program which this Government has introduced, which provides continuity for these organisations in a period of change.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Obviously I have a far more intimate knowledge of what goes on on the laboratory floors of CSIRO than has the Leader of the Government in the Senate. If the Government has a strategy of three years guaranteed funding, why are the divisions in my State of Queensland, which are all associated with pastoral or rural industries, running down their staff? Morale is absolutely at rock bottom; professional staff are being fired because the technical staff to support those professional staff have been fired over the preceding three to four years; there is no security of tenure in that organisation; and research programs, which take years to follow through-some of them run for decades-simply cannot exist when there is this continual climate of drastic diminution of funds by an uncaring government, year in and year out.

—CSIRO is subject to a one line appropriation in the Budget. Within the budget which is given to it each year-and it will be maintained in real terms for the next three years-it is the function of the CSIRO executive and administration to manage the priorities of the organisation.
—When every move is being interfered with by Neville Wran.

—The honourable senator should not make silly interjections like that. Neville Wran is Chairman of the CSIRO executive and Dr Keith Boardman is the Chief Executive of CSIRO. As with any board or executive, such people have ultimate responsibility. But it is a management issue and the priorities of an organisation like CSIRO will change from time to time. If they do not, God help us. If they remain the same forever, irrespective of changed circumstances, we will have dreadful problems. The priorities will change. Senator MacGibbon can go around, as a Queensland senator, attracting complaints from people in one division of CSIRO. Any politician can do that; it is not a particularly skilled art form. There are always people who will complain about change, when management makes changes. But it is a management problem and the funding of CSIRO, if it can reach the targets set for it by management-and it says it can-will be increased considerably over the next three years.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to ask a question of the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs under standing order 98a.
—Is leave granted?
—I seek clarification, Mr President. I do not think that leave is required.
—Leave is required to ask it without notice. Is leave granted?

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs assure the Senate that no veterans in receipt of disability pensions have been contacted by departmental medical officers and required to answer medical questions on the telephone on the basis that this will enable a claim or review to be processed more quickly? If the Minister cannot provide this assurance, is she able to state whether this practice is contrary to normal standards of professionalism which require physical examination?
—I am not able to confirm anything relating to the honourable senator's question. I will seek advice and certainly try to get the information by tomorrow.

—Will the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories confirm that the Australian Capital Territory Health Services Branch of the then Department of Health received a report written by a consulting physicist, Mr G. Majors, warning of the dangers of domestic asbestos insulation to both residents and insulation contractors as long ago as 1968? Is it a fact that the use of asbestos fluff was not banned as an insulation material in the ACT for 11 years after this report was received, and a public warning was not issued for 19 years? If so, why were such long delays permitted? In view of the devastating effects of this permitted asbestos misuse in the ACT on the health and well-being of residents, as well as on property values, will the Minister assure the Senate that the Government is prepared to assist private owners with the total and safe removal of all asbestos insulation in the ACT, bearing all associated costs, and to institute a long term monitoring program of possible asbestos related health effects?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I have an obvious difficulty in justifying the actions of governments of 19 years ago. I will not necessarily attempt to do so in answering this question. Obviously, the Government is both aware of and concerned about the problem of asbestos fluff insulation in homes in the ACT. Between 1968 and 1978 asbestos fluff insulation was installed in an unknown number of homes in Canberra. It is thought that up to 8,000 dwellings may have been affected. The type of asbestos used is different from that used in other building materials. The insulation is loose and it is therefore easily disturbed and can enter living areas through the ceiling vents and other openings. Obviously, the Government is concerned about the situation and, because of that concern, has commissioned a survey of all houses built before 1979 to try to ascertain the nature and extent of any health hazard in the community. It has also sought contemporary medical and legal advice. That survey will commence shortly.

ANSWER.PARA: In so far as the question relates to the 1968 report, I am informed that a Mr Majors from the then School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine reported to the ACT Health Services Branch of the then Department of Health on the process of installation of asbestos insulation in ACT homes in 1968. At the time Mr Majors expressed concern about the hazard of the material to installers and also indicated that there was some evidence that community exposure to asbestos dust was undesirable. It is clear that Mr Majors in his report did not identify all of the hazards, given, of course, that he was limited to scientific knowledge at the time.

The use of loose asbestos fluff was finally banned in the ACT in 1978. The use of asbestos was banned totally in the ACT in 1983, in line with the practice in other States and Territories. In the light of all that, of course, the Cabinet had to give some lengthy consideration to the matter. However, given the significance of the problem and the possible solutions to it, it was not decided just to race in and take any action. The Cabinet, therefore, has sought further expert advice. My understanding, and I will try to check it for the honourable senator during the next few days, is that most of that advice has been received. Hopefully, therefore, we will be able to announce shortly what the Government will do. I can promise Senator Jenkins that it will not be another 19 years before we take some action. I understand that a great many citizens in Canberra are concerned about this and have expressed their concern pretty vocally, not just to ACT members of Parliament but also to many people in this building. That being the case, I can assure the honourable senator that the Government will address this problem and hopefully we should have some sort of answer for her over the next few months.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to reports that imprisoned African National Congress leader, Nelson Mandela, may soon be released. My question is: Will Australia continue to demand Mandela's unconditional release and denounce any attempt by the South African Government to issue a conditional release, thereby taking advantage of Mandela's age and current health?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government continues to urge the South African authorities to release Nelson Mandela without condition. Of course, Mandela is the man who pre-eminently symbolises the struggle of black South Africans for political rights. He is revered by an older generation who remember the failure of years of peaceful effort by the African National Congress to obtain democratic rights for the majority of South Africans. Equally, he is a symbol for the current generation of young South Africans, many born after his imprisonment, whose efforts to organise for democratic rights are still met with the iron fist in that country.

ANSWER.PARA: Nelson Mandela has now been in prison for over 26 years. He is in ill health and it would be a tragic waste of an outstanding life if he were to die in prison. The time has come for the South African Government to exercise humanity and release him now. As I have said, the Australian Government continues to call on the South African authorities to repeal current repressive laws, to allow free political expression and organisation, and to negotiate now with authentic black leaders on a non-racist, democratic political system based on equality and dignity for all South Africans.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Chaney proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need to defeat the Hawke government's first referendum proposal so as to maintain the characteristics of the Senate which enable it to protect the Australian people against unwise and oppressive government actions.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition brings this matter of public importance forward for reasons which should be apparent from listening to the proceedings during Question Time when again Senator Michael Tate, on behalf of the Government, was unable to give us a straight answer to the matters which were addressed to him. Let me start by quoting somebody who is not a politician, somebody who has no vested political interest in the outcome of these referendums, and somebody who can escape the accusation that he speaks from a partisan viewpoint. Emeritus Professor Rufus Davis, who was Professor of Politics at Monash University and is a barrister at law at the Victorian bar, wrote this:

SPEECH.PARA: The public must learn that never before in the history of referendums has an Australian government put four complex issues to a referendum with so much concern to hide its motives, or hide the truth of why it has chosen these four proposals from the 80 or more that were recommended by the Constitutional Commission.
Professor Davis went on to say that `the Government is not justified in treating' the people `as infants, insulting their common sense, or tricking them with trick questions'.

He suggested that the Government had `adopted a superficial approach to the constitutional problems' and intended `to market the issues with the insincerity of bizarre salesmen'. We saw something of the bizarre salesmen in Question Time here today when the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) was asked a very simple question by an Opposition senator about the Yes case-the Yes case which claims that business supports the referendum question that we wish to debate today, the first referendum dubbed a referendum about four-year terms. Senator Tate was unable to name a single business organisation that supported the four-year term, yet the Government states in its booklet that the proposal has the support of business.

Australians are facing the most dishonest referendum campaign in Australia's history. the position is one which requires the time of this Parliament to help to explain to people what is going on. It probably sits pretty lightly with some people to hear people on one side of politics accusing people on the other side of politics of being dishonest. After all, we are almost hardened now, thanks in particular to Mr Keating, to continuous political abuse in this country. We have seen time after time argument, logic and fact put aside in the interest of abuse which can be used to hide the issues that people are required to make judgments about.

If we look at what has been said about these referendums by a host of non-political observers we find the common theme that what is being truly asked of the people, what is being put before the people, is being done dishonestly. Paddy McGuinness is a person who has written in Australia's newspapers for many years. He now writes a regular column in the Australian Financial Review, a paper which is read by only 100,000 or so Australians. He writes columns in weekend papers. I will quote a couple of things he has had to say on the referendum questions. He said:

The Federal Government is being very dishonest in its approach to the proposed referendum on constitutional amendments. It is also being quite unjustifiably hasty about the whole thing-itself a reason for suspicion. So it will be only its own fault if even the defensible amendments are defeated.

In the same article he went on to talk about the first referendum, the so-called four-year-term referendum, and expressed what was the question that should be asked if the Government were trying not to mislead the people, if it were trying to be honest with the people of Australia. He did not suggest that it was adequate to be asking, as the Government is asking in this question, `Do you agree to a law to alter the Constitution to provide for four-year maximum terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament?'. Mr McGuinness said the question should be, `Do you agree to weakening the power and status of the Senate?'. We bring this forward again because the Senate, if it is to be defended, must first of all be defended in this chamber.

When Senator Austin Lewis, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, spoke on this same subject matter last week he made the point that if we look at the $1.1 billion cost of this magnificent new Parliament House we might say that the cost has been half occasioned, say $500m worth, by the need to accommodate this Senate. After $500m has been spent on a magnificent palace, a referendum is being put to the people and the Government is now setting about to reduce the effectiveness and functioning of this place. We will have the palace but we will not have any effective use of it. I think Senator Lewis brought forward a very telling point last week: Why do we spend half a billion dollars to have something that the Government is seeking to reduce to a shell? The fact is that Professor Davis, Professor Lane and others have come forward and said that what the Government is doing is dishonest.

If we look at what has been said in the Senate chamber in the debate on these referendums we find that Senator Tate has been called upon time and again to defend the indefensible. So often he has to shillyshally around seeking to avoid the issue and not answer the questions which are directed to him. Senator Tate in the Senate last week responded to Senator Lewis in that debate by saying that Senator Lewis could not get over the hurdle. He said:
. . . not one power, not one ability, not one legislative, deliberative or other function of this chamber is stripped away by this referendum proposal.

What Senator Tate has tried to argue in this place is that this referendum does not touch the powers of the Senate. One can choose to adopt the views of Senator Tate, who has to argue the partisan case for the Labor party, or one can accept the view of Professor Davis, the view of Professor Lane or the view of Mr Paddy McGuinness, that fundamentally what this referendum is about is reducing the power, the independence and the functioning of this Senate.

I want today to address that issue because it is part of the fabric of lies which has been spread about, which has been woven by this Government and which is aimed at trying to trick the people of Australia into making very substantial changes to the referendum which on a proper examination they would not do. Part of the first referendum is to bring about a permanent state of simultaneous elections, to guarantee that the Senate and House of Representatives will always be elected together because the Senate term will be tied to that of the House of Representatives. It is fascinating that the whole notion of simultaneous elections has been omitted from the wording of this referendum. No doubt it has been omitted because on the three occasions that that proposal has been put squarely to the people of Australia without subterfuge, without lies, without deception, without the abuse of taxpayers' funds to put across the Yes case without regard to the No case, the referendum has been defeated. We face a situation where any honest placing of these questions before the people of Australia would guarantee their defeat. Their carriage is made possible only by the deception that has been undertaken by the Government.

What is it that has made this Senate a legislative chamber which, almost uniquely among the many parliaments of this Commonwealth, continues to fulfil a legislative role and to check the powers of government? There is a whole series of characteristics of the Senate, only some of which are affected by this referendum, but two of the vital characteristics will be destroyed if this referendum is passed. There are some things-the sorts of things Senator Tate concentrated on in his answers-which will not be affected. The virtually co-equal legislative powers of the Senate are not affected directly by the referendum. It will continue to be the case that the Senate can defeat any of the legislation, including budget or financial legislation, which is brought into this chamber and can either amend or request amendments to any of that legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Then why won't you do it?

—Another element which is not being changed-I shall come back to Senator Haines's interjection later-is the method of election of senators. There is absolutely no doubt that one of the differentiating characteristics of the Senate as against the House of Representatives is that we are elected on a system of proportional representation. That means that the representation in this chamber much more squarely and fairly represents the voting pattern of the Australian people. Minority parties find it easier to get represented here; the weighting between the major parties is much closer to their respective share of the votes than in the House of Representatives.
—But if you elect less than--

—Only in the case where the rotation of senators applies, so it is certainly not true of the Senate today in 1988. It can be but that is one of the essential limiting elements that was built into the Constitution that we would seek to maintain.

SPEECH.PARA: The two other key differentials between the Senate and the House of Representatives are the fixed electoral cycle, the fixed term for the Senate, a six-year term for senators which differentiates it from the House of Representatives, and what is called the rotation of senators-the fact that half the senators are elected at each election instead of the whole of the Senate coming up for election.

Those points of differentiation are important. It is those four things which have given the Senate its different character. They have enabled the Senate uniquely among legislative chambers, on a regular basis and notwithstanding variations in numbers in the Senate, to continue to act as a check against untrammelled executive power. If one looks at what has been done in this Senate since the last election, one sees a series of things which have been irritating to the Government but of great consolation to the people of Australia. If one goes back further than the last election, one finds that senators such as Senator Button, as a member of the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, and various other senators, including me, joined together in a parliamentary committee in 1975 to report against the Government's national compensation scheme. That was an example of independence within the Senate not welcomed by the government of the day but an independence which prevented a very expensive mistake for Australia.

If honourable senators look at an example when the Liberal Party was in government, when Mr Fraser was Prime Minister, they will find the Senate establishing the Scrutiny of Bills Committee over the objections of the Government; a valuable contribution to legislative scrutiny in this place. Let us look at three things which the Government has sought to do since the last election and which the Senate has prevented. Twice the Government has tried to repeal section 45d of the Trade Practices Act. There is probably not an Australian over 21 years, alive, who has not heard of the Mudginberri case. There are probably very few Australians under that age who have not heard of the Mudginberri case. There will be very few Australians who do not understand that in the Mudginberri case the Trade Practices Act was used to prevent illegal behaviour by trade unions that would have brought that business to its knees. That was a notable landmark case in industrial relations in Australia and twice the Hawke Government has tried to repeal the law that the Mudginberri abattoir was able to rely upon-twice.

Many Australians would know that a few years ago this Government tried to introduce a Bill of Rights. Few would know that the Government put the Bill of Rights through the House of Representatives in a day. It allowed one day's parliamentary consideration of a major change to the law which would have changed the way human rights were defended in this country. We kept it in the Senate for month after month and debated it for month after month. Public ignorance was replaced by public knowledge and the people of Australia flooded this Government with their objections about what was proposed. It is notable to remember that the Bill of Rights was not defeated in this Senate. It was defeated by the people of Australia who forced the Government to withdraw it. What this Senate did was to prevent the precipitate passing of that law and to guarantee that the people of Australia had time to find out what was going on.

In exactly the same way we gave the people of Australia time to discover what was meant by the identity card proposal. When the Government introduced that proposal it said to the people of Australia, `Isn't this a good thing, it will enable us to deal with tax cheats and dole frauds'. Virtually every person in Australia wants to see tax cheats and dole frauds dealt with. It took three defeats of that legislation in this chamber for 70 per cent of the people of Australia to realise that what was proposed was in fact wrong and represented a threat to them and not to the tiny minority of Australians who abused the systems, by they the tax system or the social security system.

Again, the Senate was pressed to the limit by the Government, even taken to a double dissolution election, but it was only the persistence of the Senate that enabled the people of Australia to wake up. It is precisely that that is objected to by senators opposite and lies behind this first referendum proposal. The simple objective of this referendum proposal is to make the Senate more subject to the whim and to the will of the government of the day. I think we can be grateful for the fact that in this, as in a number of other matters, Senator Button, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce who is at the table, has been a little more honest than some other senators. When we were debating and looking at the question of simultaneous elections in 1977, Senator Button said:
Of course the real importance and significance of this proposal from our point of view in the Opposition is that it does what many of its critics say it will do.
Senator Button, I interpolate, was then in Opposition. He was speaking on behalf of the Labor Party in opposition in 1977. He went on to say:

It limits the significance and influence of the Senate . . . we do have a very strong view that the powers of the Senate should be delimited at every opportunity, these are the basic reasons why we will be supporting the legislation. In saying that we are being consistent with everything we have said before.

That is a telling statement by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button. He wants the significance and influence of the Senate to be reduced and delimited at every opportunity and that is not what is disclosed in the question which is being put to the Australian people. All that is being disclosed in the question that is to be put to the Australian people is that it is a referendum about four-year terms. They are not being told that whilst a maximum four-year term means a possible increase in the length of the term of the House of Representatives, it represents a diminution of the term of the Senate and the destruction of the fixed term of the Senate. Indeed, the basic emotional point that the Government seeks to rely on with respect to this referendum-the point that the people of Australia would like to see fewer elections-is in no way guaranteed by this referendum. That has been made very clear--

TALK.START.PARA: —I never said that it is.

—I am pleased to have an interjection from Senator Button to the effect that he has never said that it is. Indeed, in questioning in this place Senator Tate admitted that there will be constitutional capacity for the Prime Minister to have an election for both Houses in October, November or December this year if he wishes. The simple reality-and this point again was brought out by Senator Michael Baume in questioning of the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, in this chamber last week-is that the Australian Prime Minister cannot have an early election for both Houses of Parliament as the Constitution now stands because he is not able, constitutionally, to call an election for the Senate until after 1 July next year. If this referendum is passed, that constitutional limitation on the freedom of the Prime Minister to call that early election is abolished, it disappears, and in fact it will leave an untrammelled capacity on the part of the Prime Minister to have an election for both Houses whenever he likes.
—Are you saying this is retrospective?

—I think I am asked by Senator Haines, who is talking in that far distant corner-and I am not sure whether I heard her interjection properly-whether I am saying that the Prime Minister will call an early election. All I can say is that the Prime Minister has twice promised to go his full term and he has broken that promise on both occasions. I make no attempt to predict what the Prime Minister might choose to do.

SPEECH.PARA: The attitude that would be adopted on any proper and honest assessment of the first referendum proposal will basically come down to whether or not one agrees with the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, that the influence, authority and role of this Senate should be reduced. Those Australians who have seen over the past few years the capacity of this Senate to stop precipitate Government legislation, and who have seen the Senate's capacity, often under very great political difficulties-including at times in the teeth of public opinion-to ensure that there is a lengthy and proper debate on issues such as the ID card and the Australian Bill of Rights, will see the danger proposed in this referendum. It is part of the elaborate hoax that is being wrought on the people of Australia. This chamber, almost uniquely amongst legislative chambers in this Commonwealth, still performs legislative functions and still checks and challenges the Executive when it ignores the interests of the people. The passage of this referendum proposal will reduce the capacity of this Senate to do that, and for that reason it should be soundly defeated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those of us who have actually looked at the proposal and have analysed it can come to only one conclusion on what Senator Chaney has contributed to the debate this afternoon-that is, it was an opportunist contribution and a smokescreen. It was opportunist because Opposition senators know that what they are saying is wrong; and it was a smokescreen because the stand taken by the Liberal Party of Australia on these referendum proposals is just another cover-up for the leadership crisis within that Party.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a right and proper proposal. It is right because it makes the terms of both Houses of Parliament four years. There is some threat that the proposal itself is not adequate. One needs to go no further than probably one of the greatest tacticians in this place, the former Liberal Party senator and leader in this place, Senator Reg Withers. He was not a theoretician but very much a tactician, as not only we found out in 1975 but as quite a successive number of Liberal leaders found out from time to time.

He would be a great authority on the proposition before us, and what does he say? On the Face to Face television program Mr Withers said that, far from harming the powers of the Senate, this proposal will strengthen the powers. Mr Withers argued that in fact the Senate could well become more assertive because it could claim to have the same mandate as the House of Representatives. Senator Chaney is leaving the chamber; maybe he should listen to the words of his former leader in this place.

The powers of the Senate are untouched by this proposal. There is nothing in this proposal that would lead to the alteration of the Senate's powers to reject or amend legislation. That is basic and it is known by everybody. There is nothing which could affect the Senate's clearly proven powers to investigate any legislation. Further, there is nothing that would affect the Senate's powers and the Senate's ability to investigate any other matter in which it took an interest. I ask the Opposition: can it mention one matter in the last five years of this Government, one thing this Government has done in those five years since it was first elected, that this constitutional change would prevent the Senate from doing in the future? It cannot; it knows it cannot. It knows the committee system will not be affected. It knows the powers and the functions of the Senate will not be affected. It also knows that the Senate will be able to continue its work through the systems that we have operated and developed over the years and that those functions will remain completely untouched.

We are told that this proposal will affect the independence of the Senate. There are a number of responses to that matter. Firstly, the independence of the Senate is protected and guaranteed in a number of ways, amongst other things by the proportional representation system of voting for senators. This system, as Senator Harradine and a succession of minority senators know, guarantees that minority groups will continue to have a place and a voice in national affairs. There is nothing in this proposal that will affect that guarantee of independence. There is no diminution of powers or independence of the Senate, and we know it. We acknowledge that there are people who wish to alter the powers of the Senate, but the public would reject that and the Government understands that full well.

What this proposal will do is bring us into line with just about every other parliament in the country. It will set a national standard for parliaments, and that is not a bad thing. At the moment every parliament in Australia, except for Queensland and the national Parliament in Canberra, has a four-year term. What is wrong with bringing the national Parliament into line with the majority of other parliamentary jurisdictions in this country? If the Liberal Party really does not believe in a four-year term, why is Nick Greiner in New South Wales not moving to amend the term of that Parliament? He will not because he knows full well that the people of that State, as in other States as well, are quite happy with the system of four-year terms.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about the upper Houses in the States.

—I will tell Senator Vanstone about upper and lower Houses. More than 90 per cent of all the parliaments in the world have terms of longer than three years. This is not some machiavellian proposal. It is about time those opposite brought themselves into the twentieth century, into the mainstream of Australian politics, rather than withering as a bad taste sideshow.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has brought Australia forward over the last five years. We have done many things since we were elected. We have rebuilt the economic shambles we inherited in 1983. We have given Australia an administrative structure, a government structure, which is appropriate to the late twentieth century. This proposal gives our parliamentary structure a reflection of the attitudes of the twentieth century and not the end of the nineteenth century. We talk a lot about the attitude of the business community. Andrew Hay, interviewed on the subject of the Opposition having a very narrow political focus, said:

Well, on this subject they very clearly have. It's not real life to expect this country to be constrained within a document drawn up in . . . at 1901. There are grounds for constitution reform, and in terms of the Parliamentary system itself, the duration of the House of Representatives, the grounds are very solid for reform.
Andrew Hay acknowledges that there is a need to update the system from that of the attitudes of the late nineteenth century. (Quorum formed)

Everyone in this place and in the community understands that we have had too many elections. Since 1945 Australians have had to go to the polls once every two years, even though during that time we have had six-year terms for the Senate and three-year terms for the House of Representatives. Each election costs $50m. If I had served all the years for which I have been elected since 1981, I would be 17 years older than I am now, having contested four elections, each one being for a six-year term, totalling 24 years. Yet I have been in this place only seven years. The basic point is that since 1964 we have not had a senator serve a six-year term in this place. The last half Senate election took place in 1970. The taxpaying public understands the need for fewer elections.

TALK.START.PARA: —But this will not guarantee that and you know it.

—We intend with this proposal that Australians should go to the polls less frequently and that they should get governments that will have sufficient time to implement programs for the good of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: We refer to business groups. It was not all that long ago, when the bunsen burners of the Opposition were placed on some in the business sector, that the business groups did come out in support of the Government's proposals. Let me refer to what Andrew Hay said a few months ago about constitutional reform:

Well, as far as the referenda questions are concerned, we are. I mean, I think for a long time the business community has argued for an extension of the Parliamentary term. We don't want to see a situation where constitutional reform is continually frustrated because of the application of a very narrow political focus.
That is how Andrew Hay referred to the Opposition. He went on to say, only a few months ago:

Yes, I'm very disappointed. I don't believe that they consulted widely enough and they certainly didn't canvass the matter at all with the business community so, therefore, I can only interpret it as a somewhat ill considered decision which has been based very largely on a narrow political perspective.

The issues raised by Andrew Hay are central to the reasons for this Government taking the decision to the people this Saturday. They highlight the difference between this Government and the Opposition. We are prepared to make the hard decisions. We are prepared to drag Australia out of the economic shambles in which we found it. We are prepared to bite the bullet. The Opposition is just a collection of followers. It is not just Andrew Hay who is on record as saying that sort of thing. Eric Mayer, the managing director of National Mutual, as a representative of the Business Council of Australia, not all that long ago said:

It would indeed be an indictment of this generation of politicians and an ill omen for the opening of our new Parliament House if politicians of all parties cannot act in a meaningful way to obtain a solution that would enable all parties to support a referendum that would give the House of Representatives a four year term.

Yet we have Senator Chaney coming in here today talking about hypocrisy, with all sorts of shallow arguments. The Western Australian Confederation of Industry, from his own home State, makes the point that it would support a four-year term. It is quite apparent that that Confederation would rather talk to us, who run the country, than the sideshow of the political process we have on the other side.

We are told by the Opposition that this proposal would make it easier for the Prime Minister of the day to call an election. Let us look at why early elections have been called over recent years. The main justification put to the people is that we have had early elections to bring the Houses back into line. The reality is that, if adopted, this referendum proposal would do away with the excuse, for any Prime Minister in the future, to call an election because the Houses have to be brought into line. The Opposition's argument is shallow. If any Prime Minister were to go to the people arguing for an election to bring the Houses into line after this proposal was accepted he would be laughed out of court. So would she.

So we have the somewhat strange and bizarre proposition from the Opposition that if we have a four-year term for the House of Representatives, we should have an eight-year term for the Senate. I am sure that would satisfy some Opposition senators. It would mean that after one election honourable senators would be eligible for the pension. Some who have been here for only a short period look as though they are on it already. I am sure that the public would not accept that argument. Does the Opposition suggest that we should continue with the notion of having half-Senate elections? As I said, we have not had one since 1970. They cost an extra $50m a year. Eighteen years ago was the last time we had a half-Senate election. But the Opposition still plods on with this anachronistic proposal.

What do Opposition members say about the proposals? In the last couple of weeks I have spoken privately to about 13 members of the Opposition in this place. They will say then that they will support one or another of the Government's propositions this coming weekend. They will not do that in the Parliament. But some of them are on record as supporting them. In 1983, Senator Walters, talking of an eight-year term, said that the people of Australia would not agree to it. Senator Townley, in the same debate said:
I do not believe that the people of this country will agree to giving anybody an eight-year term.
But the most considered comment in that debate came from Senator Watson, who said in 1983:

Many Australians would welcome a four-year term, rather than a three-year term, but a lot would reject an eight-year term for senators. It would be far too long . . . For example, it would give a non-performer too long an opportunity to remain listless on the back bench. There is a need to be motivated by the needs of the electorate. It would tend to put too many senators far too removed from the feelings of the electorate.

The Opposition is not serious about its alternative proposal; its senators have told us that already. Our bottom line, and what has to be remembered about our proposal, is that we would increase the certainty that parliaments would run their full term.

Let us go back to why the Opposition is pursuing this issue in such a loud and aggressive way. It is a smokescreen for the fact that there is a leadership crisis on the Opposition benches and in conservative politics in Australia. If the Liberal Party had a real leader, it would have joined with the Government to explain these necessary and worthwhile proposals to the Australian people. But the stand of the Opposition on this matter, as on so many other matters, is further evidence of the weakness of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). The Opposition Leader is not a leader. He is a follower. (Quorum formed) The point I was making is embellished by the fact that the Leader of the Opposition, who is not a leader but a follower, dictates the priorities for the Opposition, lays out the agenda, has a matter of public importance called on, and who is here? Two senators from the Opposition. The rest of them certainly would not follow him over hot coals. There is one Opposition senator here, with Senator Vanstone acting as an adviser. If I were taking advice from Senator Vanstone I would give up.
