SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate that is before the Chair has been raised by Senator Chaney as a matter of public importance as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The need to defeat the Hawke government's first referendum proposal so as to maintain the characteristics of the Senate which enable it to protect the Australian people against unwise and oppressive government actions.

At least that is what Senator Chaney and members of the Opposition parties would have us believe. Senator Chaney began his argument by referring to one or two selected authorities. The first person to whom he referred was Professor Rufus Davis. I received the same paper Senator Chaney received. I would have to say that the good professor lost a considerable number of points with regard to credibility, despite his position as Emeritus Professor of Politics at Monash University, because in the same article in which he was putting forward his arguments for the No case he referred to the role of the Senate as being extremely valuable, which indeed it is for most of the time, and cited as one example of this the Senate's role in what he called the defeat of the Australian Bill of Rights. He cites as one example of this the Senate's role in what he called the defeat of the Australian Bill of Rights. He claimed that the Bill was defeated in the Senate. It was not. It was withdrawn by the Government and not proceeded with. As far as I can recall, every clause that was put to a vote in this place was passed. If Professor Davis cannot get something as obviously checkable and basic as that right one wonders how accurate are his assessments of questions one to four.

Essentially, Senator Chaney also echoed the No case that was drafted by the Opposition parties and included in the booklet sent around by the Australian Electoral Commission. The points that are laboured in this No case, and that were put by the Liberal and National parties, are as follows: they argue that the proposal in question one, to increase the maximum term of the Parliament from three to four years, would cripple the Senate's independence. They then argue that the proposal is a direct attack on the fundamental purpose and structure of the Senate, and that the proposal would give the Federal Government more power over the Senate and the States. They point out that the fundamental importance of the Senate is, first, in its capacity as a House of review and, secondly, that it protects the rights of the States and their people. Presumably this is what Senator Chaney was referring to in his motion when he talked about oppressive government and what it was likely to do to the people.

One needs to ask how much protection the Senate has offered the Australian people against the unwise and oppressive actions of this Government in the last five years. The Opposition argues that the Senate is a States House and a House of review, yet its own actions in the last five years, taken of its own accord, effectively have prevented the Senate from operating in either of these ways. When did the Senate last divide on an issue from a States rights perspective? When did we ever see all Queensland senators, for example, aligned together regardless of party affiliation against senators from some or all of the other States? The Constitution and the founding fathers who drafted it certainly expected-and for very good reason-there to be occasions when senators from one State, regardless of their party affiliation, would align on certain legislation. Constitutionally, the Senate was meant to protect the interests of the less populous States from the `unwise and oppressive' or downright discriminatory decisions made by a government or by the House of Representatives as a whole.

After all, the House of Representatives is made up of members representing single electorates; the Senate is made up of members representing an entire State. The more populous the State the more members of the House it returns. I guess that what happens in Cabinet and party meetings is that legislation which suits the needs of New South Wales and Victoria, which return well over half the members of the Parliament, is supported and it is supported regardless of the impact that legislation could have on the smaller States. The Senate, which returns the same number of senators from each State, was intended to offset the possibility of this bias. Yet it does not do that now-and I doubt whether it ever did. What happens is that this chamber divides strictly along party lines. I cannot remember when we have ever decided that something that was bad for South Australians and Western Australians should cause us to divide separately-Labor, Liberal, Democrat and Independent senators-from the rest of our colleagues. Senator Chaney, Senator Teague and others should have been concerned when the Government's Austudy payments for 15-year-olds in the last two compulsory years of schooling were cut back. That did not affect most 15-year-olds in New South Wales and Victoria; but it certainly affected a lot of 15-year-olds in Western Australia and South Australia. I did not see Senator Chaney or Senator Teague voting against the Government's legislation in that regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a Budget matter.

—Senator Teague makes an interesting comment. He said it was a Budget matter. This is the other reason why this chamber no longer operates as a House of review and why it no longer looks at legislation on its merits. When the Liberal and National parties, to their considerable concern, found themselves in opposition instead of in government back in 1983 they made what has to be the most extraordinary decision of all time: they decided that they would not oppose or amend-that is, they would not vote against or change in any way-any piece of legislation that the Government raised as part of its Budget proposals. This produced one immediate effect, and that was that the Government then moved to having two Budgets a year, one in May and one in August. As far as the Opposition was concerned, any legislation that was hinted at in the May economic statement fell into exactly the same category as legislation that was promulgated in the August Budget statements, and was therefore safe, cushioned and quarantined from being opposed, amended or defeated. If that is not rejecting the idea that this place is here to be a House of review I do not know what is, because the majority of legislation that we deal with in this place now stems from propositions put forward in May or in the August Budget session.
—The ID card wasn't.

—No, the ID card was not but it was one of the few things those opposite chose to oppose. Had it been part of a Budget measure, they would not have opposed it. They would have done what they frequently do; stand up and grizzle and complain about how it will affect a group of individuals, an entire State or the whole country but, on the grounds that it was a Budget Bill, they would not have opposed it. To any honourable senator here who is somewhat confused about the difference between Budget and Supply Bills, Budget Bills and money Bills, money Bills and tax Bills, or any one of those Bills and any other piece of legislation that we get, I recommend two extremely good papers. One was written by our own Clerk, Harry Evans, and the other was written by an ex-Liberal Party senator in this place, now a Minister in the Liberal Tasmanian Government, ex-Senator Peter Rae. Those two papers set out very clearly the rights and responsibilities of the Senate-and they are not to revoke unilaterally, as this Opposition does, any right to amend or defeat legislation that comes up in a Budget session.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it extraordinary that Liberal and National Party senators in this place say that question one will reduce the rights of the Senate or will stop it from maintaining its role of protecting the Australian people against unwise and oppressive government actions when those honourable senators have abrogated their responsibilities for the past five years.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will have an ID card if this referendum passes.

—Senator Vanstone says that we will have the ID card legislation if the referendum passes. I cannot see how her arithmetic would lead her to this position. Certainly, if this proposal goes through and the House and the Senate are taken out simultaneously each time there is an election, and prior to that election the tax file number legislation or an Australia Card Bill was defeated, presumably the Government could campaign on that. If it won, which I very much doubt it would, campaigning on such an issue, what would happen presumably is that the legislation would be reintroduced once the Government got back into power. What we can be sure of is that it will not have control of the Senate, because it is now almost impossible, with a double dissolution, for any party to gain a majority in the Senate. If this referendum question is not passed, we will be taken to a double dissolution every time that an election is required, because the alternative is for whoever wins government to face a hung Senate, and a hung Senate is far more unstable than a Senate which is out of the control of the government of the day.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind honourable senators in any event that, to all intents and purposes, over the last few years double dissolutions have become the norm. I, like most senators in this chamber, have not yet served any of the entire six-year terms for which I have been elected, and I have been elected for three of them since 1980. So in three elections for six-year terms since 1980, neither I nor anyone else in this place has served one of them. If this referendum proposal is not passed, we will face the ludicrous situation of the government of the day searching around for a bit of objectionable legislation to put before the Senate so that it can manufacture an occasion for a double dissolution. Thanks to the alignment of the National Party of Australia with the Australian Labor Party Government in 1984, the size of the Parliament and the Senate has increased, which means that instead of five senators being up for election in a half Senate election in each State, six will be up for election. This gives each of the major parties the opportunity to have three out of six senators elected, while in the past they would not have had three out of five elected. A hung Senate is about the last thing that any government of any political persuasion would want.

For Senator Chaney and his colleagues to claim that somehow the passage of question No. 1 will reduce the role of the Senate as a watchdog, reduce the States rights element of the Senate, reduce the power of the Senate to act as a House of review to look at legislation on its merits, is nonsense. The Liberal and National parties have abandoned that review capacity. As long as legislation is brought forward in a Budget, they keep their hands off it. So a 45-year-old widow whose youngest child turns 16 is forced on to unemployment benefits and a loss of disposable income, because while the Opposition said that it opposed this in principle, it did not oppose it in fact.

In the last 20 years we have had elections, on average, every two years and three months. For the Opposition parties to argue that they could be any more frequent is a nonsense. If the four-year term proposal is passed, at least we might stand a chance of having elections every three years and three months and, as a consequence, having not only more accountable senators, but also better government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating why it is so very important that the people of Australia, when they go to the ballot box next Saturday, should vote no on the first question in the referendum-in fact, on all four questions-and so preserve the rights of the States and of individual Australians. Senator Haines, who preceded me in this debate, did not honestly state the vested interest of her Party; that is, if question No. 1 is passed on Saturday, if the Yes vote is in the majority, her Party will find it twice as easy to get its members elected to the Senate. Yet she did not refer to that point once in her speech. I say to Senator Bolkus, who has also spoken, that the vested interest of the Australian Labor Party (ALP)-it has been part of that Party's platform for decades-is that it wants to destroy the powers of the Senate. If this referendum question is passed, it will effectively do that.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party is advocating a Yes vote on question No. 1 in the referendum because it wants to destroy the powers of this chamber, and the Australian Democrats are advocating a Yes vote because they will find it twice as easy to get elected. Let me cite the precise figures: a quota in an ordinary Senate election under the present Constitution requires them to get 14.3 per cent of the votes in any State-a fairly tall order. I pay Senator Haines a compliment in that she is the only member of her Party in the country who would go close to getting elected. She manages to gain about 11 per cent of the vote, and the allocation of preferences would trip up that figure to 14.3 per cent. All the other Democrat senators would be history in an ordinary Senate election, but if question No. 1 is passed on Saturday, they would have to gain only 7.7 per cent of the vote. Because there are twice as many senators to be elected, the quota for election is so much reduced. This would give the Democrats the same kind of chance as in a double dissolution election, in which one member of that Party is elected in each State and two are elected in Senator Haines's State. So they have a vested interest, and there should not be any obfuscation about it by the Democrats or the Government.

As for the Opposition's point of view, the reason that we have raised this matter in the Senate today, just six days before this important referendum, is our vested interest in the rights of ordinary Australians and the established powers of this chamber to act for the States and to act for the electors of Australia. That is why the terms of our matter of public importance are as follows:

The need to defeat the Hawke government's first referendum proposal so as to maintain the characteristics of the Senate which enable it to protect the Australian people against unwise and oppressive government actions.

Some of those unwise and oppressive actions have concerned the Australian Bill of Rights and the identity card. Because of the debate in this chamber neither of those proposals saw the light of day. The Government feels resentment about that, and it wants to take away powers from the Senate, and the ability of the Senate to act with its current powers that defeated those two measures, so that it can more easily get its programs in place.

Senator Haines said in her speech that Professor Davis did not know what he was about because he claimed that it was the Senate that had blocked the Bill of Rights. I say that Professor Davis is right; that because the Bill of Rights was blocked in the Senate-there was days, weeks, even months of debate on the Bill of Rights-the people of Australia were alerted to its real nature. Such were the expressions of public support for what the Opposition was saying in the Senate that the Government withdrew the measure, said that it would not proceed with it and took itself off the hook.

With regard to the ID card, as everybody knows, the Opposition forcefully opposed it and, happily, Senator Haines and her colleagues in the Australian Democrats agreed with the Opposition on that occasion. We were able to refuse twice, by direct vote, that measure in this chamber. As a result, the last election was called in mid-1987 on the double dissolution grounds that Government legislation had been twice refused in the Senate. The resentment of Mr Hawke, Mr Keating or the Labor Government is no reason for the people of Australia to say, `Let's give them question No. 1 so that the Hawke-Keating program can be all the more easily achieved and so that the Senate will not deter it'.

There has been a longstanding commitment in the Labor Party, that has only recently been amended, to abolish this chamber. The Labor Party has had the abolition of this chamber on successive platforms. It wanted to have an untrammelled right in the House of Representatives to put up legislation that fitted its socialist policies, so that there would be no check, no balance, no House of review, no Senate to stand up for States rights. Therefore, it would have untrammelled power; a single chamber in the national parliament.

When the Government saw how unpopular this was, because of the Opposition's coherent arguments, it changed it. Guess what? The Labor Party no longer wants freely to admit to the public that it wants to abolish the Senate. It just wants to take away its powers. So it wants everyone to vote yes on question one at next Saturday's referendum. Do not be fooled. Do not be deceived. Study the implications of question one. Read the circulated booklet of the Electoral Commission, which sets out the Yes and the No case and which has at the end of it the precise words that would be changed in the Constitution.

Let me turn to the actual questions that will be on the ballot paper. When we all go to vote next Saturday and we pick up the ballot paper, we should write `No' in all four of the boxes, in answer to each question. The statement to the first question is:
To alter the Constitution to provide for-
wait for it-
4-year maximum terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament.

That is a very acceptable concept. Most of us have been arguing for four-year parliamentary terms. If people did not know anything else and they just went in and read that simple proposition they would say: `Fair enough. South Australia has four-year terms; Victoria has four-year terms; New South Wales has four-year terms. There are lots of arguments for it'. If that were all people knew-this Government wants to gull the public into believing that they do not know any more than that-they would be likely to write `Yes'. But they must write `No' because-what would it do? It would immediately abolish the six-year fixed term of the Senate. It would give a flexible period for all senators alike-it could be one year; it could be two, it could be three; at the maximum, four-and the actual term would be determined by the decision of the Prime Minister. It would no longer be fixed in the Constitution, above the grubby hands of Canberra politicians. It would be squarely in the decision-making power of the Prime Minister to take out the House of Representatives when he liked, and at the same time all of the Senate would have to go.

Secondly, it would abolish the concept which we call the rotation of senators. At the moment, half the Senate is elected at each Senate election and the other half three years later. Six-year fixed terms for the Senate are in the Constitution. That has been the case for the last 88 years, and it has served us well. Instead of this rotation, whereby half the Senate is elected at one election and the other half at the next, the House of Representatives and the Senate would both be elected together. That would give Senator Haines and the Australian Democrats their precious little advantage, and that is, to make it twice as easy for them to get the quota needed to be elected. But it would mean that at any one election, the whole of the Senate is determined at the same time as the determination of the government of the day. There would be no check and balance, such that some senators are elected at another time and can continue into the second half of their term. In fact, the Senate would become a rubber stamp for the House of Representatives and at the beck and call, as far as its term goes, of the Prime Minister of the day.

My colleagues and I have written a summary on this question. We say, in a nutshell, that proposition one does not mean four years between elections. It does not mean fewer elections; we could have many more. It does not require a government to serve out its term. It does not mean better government. However, it would radically change our parliamentary system. It would abolish the Senate's fixed term. It would abolish the rotation of terms for senators. It would reduce the Senate's independence. It would make it easier for a government to control the Senate. Is that what the people want? Of course they do not! It would give a Prime Minister scope to call more early elections. It would give nothing, but it would take much away.

Let us see what the leading pollster in this country, Mr Gary Morgan, said about this. He is asking questions of the public every day through the Morgan Research Centre. When this proposition was first announced he is reported to have said that there was no doubt the questions were biased to try to obtain a `yes' response from voters. I quote him directly:
Any public opinion polling company who asked questions as blatantly biased as the Government proposes would completely lose credibility.

Is that the kind of record that the Government wants before the public as it comes towards this important referendum? It is gulling them with simple words on the ballot paper and it is deceiving them so that they do not understand that it would be achieving ALP objectives to take away powers from the Senate.

Let me note what the Australian has said in most responsible editorials on this question. On Thursday, 16 June, in the middle of the discussion of this whole matter, it had an editorial on question one headed, `Question really is, do you want a Senate?' The editorial stated:
Do you want to keep the Australian Senate or would you rather we got rid of it?

If you believe that the Senate is not worth keeping, you should vote `yes' on September 3 to the referendum proposal that there be a four-year maximum term for both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament.

After many weeks of letters columns and invited articles on all four referendum questions, weeks later, on 5 August, the Australian then carried a consolidated editorial of its opinion headed `Referendums-conclusion'. The subheading was, `Our federal system is now at stake'. The editorial stated:

When Australians vote in the constitutional referendums on September 3 they will be able to make a choice as to whether the growing drift towards centralisation of power in Canberra will be accelerated or resisted.

My time has nearly gone. I can only say that the Government is not acting on the report of its Constitutional Commission. That report, which came down only in May, recommended that the Senate have two terms of the House of Representatives-not one. The Government has rejected its own expert advice. Let me quote from a learned man of the law in my State of South Australia, Mr Andrew Wells, a former Crown Solicitor, a former Solicitor-General and a former Justice of the Supreme Court. In a long paper entitled `The Rule of Law or the Rule of Lawyers', he firmly advocates that before people vote, they should study the fine print and not be gulled, and that they should vote no on 3 September. I do not have the time to cite all of the aspects of his argument. I can only urge people to vote no on Saturday on the referendum questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add at the end of Senator Teague's speech the words `Written and authorised by Baden Teague' et cetera, or whatever it is, because it was basically a campaign speech. Of course, that is what this whole debate is all about. This matter of public importance debate, brought forward by Senator Chaney, seeks to protect, in theory, the position of the Senate in the Australian political framework. Most of his arguments and the arguments of those people on the other side of the chamber who support them revolve around the view that, first of all, the Senate is the proper House of review, that it protects States rights, and that it protects civil liberties and individual rights against oppressive governments. Implicit in the criticisms that they have made of the Government's constitutional referendum proposals, particularly the first proposal, is the view that the Government has a hidden agenda-namely, the destruction of the Senate. Senator Teague has already implied that once again.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to examine some of those criticisms because I believe that despite the fact that we are in the middle of what appears to be some sort of semi-election campaign, it is important that we put the whole issue in some sort of perspective. The proposals for the constitutional changes arise almost wholly not from the Government but from the Australian Constitutional Commission. It has put 2 1/2 years work into these proposals. It received 2,000 submissions. The Commission met and talked with a significant number of interest groups and individuals throughout this country. The Commission was established with the particular view in mind of making Australia's constitutional framework a matter for proper public debate. At the end of the day, action by the Government of the day would allow the people of Australia to make a decision about the sort of constitutional framework they wanted. Without a doubt, in the back of everyone's minds were the events of 1975 when Australia, for the first time in many years, got to the stage of having its politics go beyond a democratic framework: where the elected Government of the day was twice sent to the people by this Senate, where that Government was dismissed by the Governor-General, where the majority party in the House of Representatives-that is, the Whitlam Government-having been given a vote of confidence in the House of Representatives still could not see the Governor-General and say, `We are once again, the elected Government'. That issue was in the minds of all those who supported the establishment of the Constitutional Commission. They knew then that the constitutional framework of Australia, the political framework of this country, is a delicate one; it is a question of give and take, of ensuring that everybody who is in a key position plays within the rules. Those rules were broken. The framework that we had in those days was not sufficient to deal with the issues that came up. The Commission was set up on that basis, to make recommendations to the government of the day, having listened to the people of Australia about the best sort of political framework we should have.

It is impossible to understand how a group of men and some women in the 1890s, coming from various fractious colonies, could write a blueprint for the way politics should operate in this country and be totally right. Of course they were to draw up a document for the good conduct of politics that had to be flexible, hence the provision for constitutional reform through referenda. Yet here we have today the Opposition raising a matter, with about two hours' notice, asking for a debate about an issue of major importance. The Opposition does not heed the dangers that we all faced in 1975. Honourable senators who have looked at political systems around the world will know that democratic countries are few and far between, and that some countries that were democracies, say, 20 years ago are no longer democracies simply because, in many cases, their political framework, their constitutional framework, could not tolerate the stresses and strains of party politics.

Let us look at some of the principles that were raised by the Opposition today. The important one, of course, in the question of the Senate itself. Is it worthwhile? I came to this Senate not as some green, young boy out of the backwoods; I came here with six years' experience in a State parliament, three of those years as a Minister involved in seven portfolios. I expected this place to be different from what I found it to be. I was terribly disappointed, and I have not changed my mind. If the Senate is to fulfil its function as a proper House of review, I believe that rather than oppose every constitutional change everyone in this chamber ought to look very closely at the way we operate in this place. I ask honourable senators to look around this chamber. Some people have dropped in to see the Senate in action. There is one member of the Press in the gallery. There are four Opposition senators in the chamber to hear a debate on a matter they raised. (Quorum formed) That is now the third quorum which has been called by the Opposition in this debate. It is its debate and it has had to call four quorums to get its own people in the chamber. There are still only four Opposition senators sitting there, and another standing.

The point I am making is that if the Senate is to be considered a proper House of review, it ought to be behaving as a House of review. For example, it ought to be ensuring that there is proper debate in this chamber without the constant misuse of the calling of quorums to stifle debate. The calling of quorums has taken four minutes out of my 15 minutes and eight minutes out of Senator Bolkus's 15 minutes. The Senate ought to ensure that that sort of thing does not go on because it is that type of behaviour that gives this House a bad name.

Let me look at the third principle that Senator Chaney raised, that the Senate is a States' House. I ought not to spend too much time on this, given that the Opposition has already cut four minutes out of my speech. I recall two Liberal senators crossing the floor to vote with the Government of the day on a matter of principle. They were Senator Townley and Senator Jessop, and I look in vain for their positions or nameplates on the other side. I can tell the Senate why they are not there. They were dumped by their Party because they decided that matters of individual principle-States' rights, for example-were matters that were going to be put into operation and they were going to vote as their consciences dictated. What happened? The Liberal Party says, `We have no caucus. People are free to do what they wish in this chamber. This is a States' House; a House that is concerned with the rights of individuals'. But it dumped them both. One wonders what will happen to Senator Peter Baume, a man for whom I have an enormous amount of respect, a man who has the concerns of individuals at heart, a man who is prepared to vote with his conscience, a man who has crossed the floor twice since I have been in the Senate. I guarantee that at the next election Senator Peter Baume will be struggling for preselection because the Liberal Party has shown that it does not believe that this place is a States' House. It does not believe that this is the place where people vote with their conscience. It believes that this is a party political House. If that is accepted as a matter of principle, why are we in this chamber pretending that we are a collection of individuals, a collection of senators supporting our States and looking after the interests of only our States? It has become a farce.

Once we recognise that this is a party political House in almost exactly the same way as the House of Representatives is a party political House, once we accept, for example, that as a House of review it has not always done what it should, particularly in party political work, we cannot put the Senate on a pedestal. We cannot say that it has a special position in the Australian constitutional framework. We cannot allow it to have untrammelled power in future to send a duly and properly elected government, such as the Whitlam Government, to the people on two separate occasions within three years. The people of Australia will not accept that any more. This humbug about a States rights House and a House concerned with individual conscience has to go.

The House of review principle is important. When I first came here the first thing that impressed me about the way the Senate operated compared with the House of Representatives was the way in which the committee system worked. People worked across party lines to examine major issues in this community. Many valuable reports were written. The community was given an opportunity to have its voice heard directly in this chamber. Executive government was restricted to some extent by those reports. But the Senate has never taken to the full extent the powers of those committees. It has never utilised the capacity of those committees to provide for individual liberties, to ensure that this House is a proper House of review. Again I ask the question: Why put the Senate on a pedestal?

Let us face the fact that what the people of this country want is stability of government. They want to know that when they elect a government to the House of Representatives that government will run its full term, hopefully of four years. Businessmen want to know when they plan for the future that the government that was elected four years ago will go its full term, so that they know that the management of the economy will be at least consistent. The population at large wants the right to say, `Yes, we have seen that government in operation for four years. We are now in a position to make an assessment of its capabilities and performance'. They have the right to throw it out. If the Senate is in a position, as it was in 1972 to 1975, to reject a government on two occasions and send it to the people, how can the electorate at large ever make an objective judgment about the value of that government? If the electorate cannot make an objective judgment about the value of a government, we are in deep trouble in terms of the future of politics.

I am saying, this Government is saying, that people out there who have an opportunity on 3 September to vote in favour of the four proposals should do so keeping in mind that the protection of the Senate, of the whole Constitution, of the Parliament lies best in ensuring that the Senate runs in the most efficient and effective way-and it will not do so if it continues on the path we are following. I oppose the motion. It has been a waste of time to bring it here today. Nevertheless, we will debate it--

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The four referendums which next Saturday the Australian people are to be asked to vote upon are among the most important for many years. One would not have that impression from the manner in which the Government has proceeded to put these referendums to the Australian people. We are this afternoon addressing particularly question No. 1, but I make the point in passing that each of these questions is very important, although it has to be said that of all of them the first proposal is overwhelmingly the most important. It is that question which, if passed, goes to the heart of the constitutional framework of this country in that it goes to the heart of the relationship between the Senate and the House of Representatives, to the heart of the relationship between Parliament and the Executive, and to the heart of the power of the Prime Minister of the day. I refer not merely to the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). We might all have our views about the manner in which the present Prime Minister would exercise his powers, but I look to the future. I would be just as disturbed about placing in the hands of a Prime Minister from this side of politics the powers that this proposal would place in his hands, as I am about having such powers placed in the hands of the present Prime Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: I have worked in this town for 30 years and during that time, before moving out and then coming into the Parliament, I saw a continual process involving the drift or accretion of power from the periphery to the centre; that is, from the States to the Commonwealth, to Canberra. I saw a continual shift of power from the Parliament to the Executive, that is, to the Ministry. Within the Ministry I have seen a continual shift of power from Ministers to the inner Cabinet and from the inner Cabinet to the Prime Minister. This proposal, if carried, will represent a further and even a quantum leap in that process. It would give power to the Prime Minister of the day to sack the Senate.

Let us look at the genesis of these proposals because the Australian people, in judging them, are entitled to look at the honesty, or lack thereof, of purpose with which this Government has brought these proposals forward. I put it to honourable senators that the genesis of these proposals is flawed. They have nothing to do with constitutional reform as such. They have a great deal to do with distracting the attention of the Australian people from the terrible mess in which the Australian Labor Party found itself in April this year.

Let me take the minds of honourable senators back to that time. Earlier this year the Labor Party went through a very bad patch indeed. There had been a disastrous outcome of the New South Wales elections on 19 March. There had been the loss of a Federal seat previously held by the Labor Party-a very safe seat, the seat of Adelaide. There had been the near loss of a blue ribbon Labor seat in Port Adelaide following the retirement of the Hon. Mick Young. There had been massive swings against the Labor Party in two State by-elections in Western Australia following the retirement of the Premier and Deputy Premier of that State. Following all that, Senator McMullan-and I have much respect for his sagacity-in an interesting article in the Australian gave his Party some gratuitous but nevertheless undoubtedly sound advice. In that article he said that the Government would be well advised to embark upon what he called some low risk political distractions, such as constitutional reform. That is precisely what the Labor Party proceeded to do: it embarked on a low risk political distraction.

As a consequence of that decision taken some time during April the whole of the due processes of the Constitutional Commission, which was set up over two years earlier by the present Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), were truncated before it had time to come to a conclusion. The Government pushed forward these four proposals, three of which have either no support or only partial support in the reports of the Constitutional Commission; we know that now that we have those reports after the event.

Let us take the first proposal, which is the subject of this afternoon's matter of public importance proposed by my colleague Senator Chaney-the so-called parliamentary terms proposal. Let us take that as an example of the extent to which this Government has been guided by the Constitutional Commission which the Government itself instituted, and which was to provide us with the basic guidance and counsel against which the Australian people were supposed to examine the processes of constitutional change. The proposal which is being put to the Australian people next Saturday is not what the Commission recommended. It recommended a four-year maximum term for members of the House of Representatives and to that extent, and to that extent only, this proposal follows the recommendation of the Constitutional Commission. But it also recommended a three-year minimum term because the Commission took the view that there would indeed be, as other speakers have said in this debate, merit in having fewer elections. Therefore, it provided to ensure that outcome by suggesting or recommending a three-year minimum term. That recommendation has not been picked up by this Government.

Honourable senators will not find that recommendation contained in the proposal before them next Saturday because this Government does not want to have fewer elections. It wants to keep its hands entirely free to have elections just as frequently in the future as it has had them in the past under the present Prime Minister, who has broken a series of promises in the process of achieving that outcome. Nor did the Constitutional Commission recommend simultaneous terms for the election of members and senators, which is the proposal contained in the referendum Bill on which we will be asked to vote next Saturday. It did not recommend that at all. It recommended that a senator's term should be equal to two terms of a member of the House of Representatives. As a matter of fact, in passing I note that that proposal itself is not altogether without its difficulties, but the key point here to note is that it is not what the Government has put before the Australian people. What the Government is putting before the Australian people is a proposal for simultaneous elections. The same proposal was put to the Australian people in 1974 by Mr Whitlam, in 1977 by Mr Malcolm Fraser-I was about to say a Liberal Prime Minister but there are some doubts about that these days-and in 1984 by Mr Hawke. On every one of those occasions the Australian people rejected the proposal.

Madam Acting Deputy President I ask you: Why is this Government wheeling up this proposal for simultaneous elections once again, it having been defeated by the Australian people on no less than three separate occasions within the last 14 years? Does it not suggest the desperate need which the Australian Labor Party feels to get this proposal for simultaneous elections passed? Of course it does and it is entirely in keeping with the views of Labor Party members and senators that it should do that.

The whole purpose of this proposal is to muzzle the Senate to give the Prime Minister of the day the power to sack the Senate by simply obtaining from His Excellency a decision for an election of the House of Representatives which under this proposal would automatically send the Senate also to the polls. I do not need to spell out the intimidatory powers which that would give the Prime Minister of the day for people to understand the additional power which that places in his hands. The Prime Minister would get his way in this chamber in a way in which he was unable to do at the time of the Bill of Rights, unable to do at the time of the identity card debate, and unable to do on many other such occasions when this chamber has carried out this role as the people's chamber. This is quite contrary to the view being put from the Government side that the House of Representatives is the people's chamber. It is the Executive's chamber; it is the Minister's chamber. There was never a case when any Government backbencher got up in the House of Representatives and said boo to a proposal being brought forward there by the Government of day. That is no longer the people's chamber. This is the people's chamber today.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has never been.
—You have got to be joking.

—I ask Government senators who are interjecting to express their pride in the fact that it is. The Government's whole approach to this and indeed to all four questions has been one which I can only describe as calculated deceit. First of all we have had false and misleading descriptions certainly of three of the proposals before us. I might allow some validity to the recognition of the local government proposal but the other three are totally false descriptions. The first proposal which we are now debating is a proposed law:

SPEECH.PARA: To alter the Constitution to provide for 4-year maximum terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament.

That is all it says. It says nothing at all about the simultaneity of elections except very indirectly. It says nothing at all about the other complexities of the Bill itself which will form part of the Constitution if this proposal were to be carried next Saturday which I devoutly hope it will not be. The other proposals are spelt out in language just as deceitful. Then we have had what I might call the crooked case being sent out to Australian electors with the Yes case printed in enormous typeface and the No case in extremely diminutive typeface. I can only say, because I do not have the time to spend on it here this afternoon without elaborating, that the Electoral Commissioner carries a heavy responsibility for allowing that document to go out to the electors of Australia and it will rebound against the Australian Labor Party that he has done so.

Next we have had the so-called ticks and crosses rort where again, if I may say so, the Electoral Commissioner has played an interesting part-I use a low key description-in the procedures which apparently are to be still used in counting the votes following next Saturday. Many members of the Australian public, I think still to this day, are unaware that according to the instructions sent to the scrutineers by the Electoral Commissioner if people complete their ballot papers next Saturday, not by voting yes or no as they should, but by voting with ticks and crosses, four ticks will be counted as a valid vote; that will be interpreted as four yeses. A mixture of ticks and crosses will be counted as yeses and noes respectively, a valid vote, but if anybody should fill in his ballot paper with four crosses because he wants to vote, no, no, no, no-as I hope everyone will do-that vote will be counted as invalid, it will not be counted. What a travesty of an approach to electoral justice.

I simply hope for the future of the constitutional debate in this country that they do not get any of these questions passed next Saturday but if any of them should be unfortunately passed I certainly hope that they do not get passed on the basis of the invalidation of a number of votes marked with four crosses.

We have had the illegal advertisements rort under which the Attorney-General was authorising the expenditure of $3m of our taxpayers' money to put over a series of four separate television and other advertisements which, on challenge in the High Court of Australia, the High Court ruled two of them to be illegal and there was a good ground for thinking that if in fact we had been a little bolder and had sought to invalidate the other two as well they also would have been ruled illegal. What a travesty of the approach to fair and honest electoral or referendum procedures from this Government. We have had what I call the mushroom approach by Mr Lionel Bowen. The mushroom approach: keep them in the dark and feed them manure. That is what Mr Bowen has been doing with these proposals from the day when he first set out across this country. He has failed to tell the Australian people about them. Mr Bowen is still out there saying he does not want the politicians to be involved in this debate. He wants them to keep out of it. He said that it is just left to the people. How can one leave these things to the people when the Government is telling the people nothing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Except lies.

—Except lies as the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, has just quite truthfully interjected. We have had the untruthful statements in the Yes case. For example, we have had the statement that the first proposal, the one we are talking about, enjoys the general support of the business community. This very afternoon at Question Time the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, in response to my colleague Senator Alston, was unable to name a single business organisation which supports this proposal-not a single one. Of course we have also had the statement in the same document in relation to the Yes case, prepared by this Government, that this proposal if carried will lead to less frequent elections. The hole in this is simply demonstrated by Senator Robert Ray who, when we were debating these Bills as they were being guillotined through the Senate on 31 May 1988, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there is no guarantee that a government's term will run for four years if this proposal is carried in the electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —(Senator Bjelke-Petersen)-Order! Senator Stone, your time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a lot of puff and wind spoken about this particular matter this afternoon. The constitutional question that is asked in this first referendum is quite clearly set out. It is a Bill for:

SPEECH.PARA: An Act to alter the Constitution to provide for 4-year maximum terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament.

It is said that there have been illegal advertisements. What happened, of course, was that the advertisements were challenged, and two deletions were made which this Government accepted. It did accept the judgment of the High Court of Australia and did accept the umpire's decision. What is the position on the other side? One of the ways these referenda are attacked is to say that the High Court cannot be trusted with interpreting the fourth question; that is the one that gives the three rights. It was not the Government that attacked the High Court and said that it could not be trusted; it was the Opposition which brought that body into question. It is the Opposition which has brought the Electoral Commissioner into question, as has just been done. We are not the side in this debate which picks on traditional institutions which have served this country well over the years; it is the Opposition which has done that.

Honourable senators opposite say that this is a House of review. As I look across the Senate chamber I notice in the Opposition former Ministers from past governments. How can this be called a House of review when Ministers sit in it, when the Ministry is responsible to this chamber and when Ministers can initiate legislation in it? It is not a House of review similar to the United States of America where Congress has only legislative powers and no executive powers. How can this chamber be called a House of review? The Opposition says that the Government attacks the Senate, and it says that the Government wants to defeat the proposition that the Senate should be a chamber which looks at and reviews legislation. The Senate can review legislation because there is a fine balance between the parties-the Government, the Opposition and the Australian Democrats-and therefore there can be an independent mind. How did that independent mind come about in the Senate? It came about because in 1948 the then Australian Labor Party Government legislated for proportional representation and increased the size of the Senate from 36 to 60 senators. It is that proportional representation, that balance of the parties in the Senate, that makes it democratic-it is not the fact that it has two terms.

When the Labor Party introduced that change it had a majority of senators. In fact, it had every senator apart from three. The Government, being in that position, with 33 of the 36 senators, it brought in the sort of change that has made this chamber a democratic institution. That is what has made the Senate a democratic institution-it is not as a result of anything done by the Opposition, whether in government or otherwise.

Let us make it quite clear. Insofar as this is an effective chamber, it is because of what the Labor Party has done. It is an effective chamber because of the committee system. The great initiator of that system was Senator Lionel Murphy. It is the committee system and the fact that this chamber is evenly balanced that makes it a democratic place. Great play has been made of simultaneous elections, but the Constitution itself contemplates that there will be simultaneous elections for the House of Representatives and for half the Senate. Over the years that has been mainly the case. Indeed, when the elections have been forced out of kilter Prime Ministers both of conservative and Labor persuasion have called elections to bring the two Houses back into kilter. So let us not have all this nonsense about objecting to simultaneous elections. The Constitution itself contemplates that there will be simultaneous elections. Of course, that was the position adopted by the Liberal and National Party coalition in 1988 when the then Attorney-General said:

Under the existing provisions it is theoretically possible to keep the elections for the two Houses in phase by holding elections for the House of Representatives whenever half Senate elections are due. However, the exigencies of political life are such that synchronisation on this basis is difficult to maintain.

On that basis the then Attorney-General introduced the reform which at that stage was supported by everyone. Referring to the Constitution Alteration (Simultaneous Elections) Bill the then Attorney-General of the coalition Government said:

It provides for half Senate elections to be brought into line with elections for the House of Representatives whenever those elections may occur. Apart from the benefits of public convenience and savings of expenditure the proposal will benefit the parliament. By ensuring that the people's will is reflected simultaneously in both Houses, it will provide a more satisfactory electoral basis upon which the Government of the country can proceed.
It is so that, if elections are held at the same time for the House of Representatives and the Senate, the will of the people is reflected.

We have heard much about the rights of the Senate and the rights of the States, but what about the rights of the people who, in 1977 the coalition supported simultaneous elections, as is illustrated by the words of its Attorney-General. It has now turned away from that position. It is said that similar Bills have been defeated in the past. Of course, one was supported at referendum by over 60 per cent of the Australian people but, ultimately, it was defeated because it was not supported by a majority of the States. That point was not made clear by the Opposition. Why do honourable senators opposite stand up and make the bald statement that similar referenda have been defeated by the people in the past when the clear evidence with respect to one referendum at least is that the people accepted it-indeed, it was endorsed by over 60 per cent of the people-but it was defeated because it was not supported by a majority of the States?

Let us be quite clear about what has happened. The proposal is for reform-that is true-and it is a reform that has been accepted all around Australia other than in Queensland. The reform is for the House of Representatives to have four-year terms. Senator Stone said that the Constitutional Commission suggested a minimum term of three years. If we are to have a minimum term of three years, we must deny the Senate the right to deny money Bills. In other words, we must introduce changes to the Constitution to weaken the Senate to enable three-year terms to operate. Do honourable senators opposite want the Senate to be weakened? The only way that it can be suggested that the Senate is weakened under this proposal is that senators must face the people at the same time as members of the House of Representatives. What would have been the reaction from the other side if we had come into this Parliament as a government and said that we were going to reduce the power of the Senate by denying it the right to reject Supply? There would have been an unholy cry. So for Senator Stone to stand up and say that we have not followed the Constitutional Commission's suggestion is absolutely correct. However, we did not accept the Constitutional Commission's proposition because we respect the Senate and we respect its powers.

The only argument put against a reduction in the term of office for senators from six years to four years is that the Prime Minister may call an election. How many times over the many decades since the Commonwealth of Australia was constituted in 1901 have there been early elections? In other words, what the Opposition is doing to oppose this proposal is to extrapolate from a long history some instances where a Prime Minister has called an early election and has said, `Look, that is what this Bill is all about'.

Of course, the Prime Minister can go to the people. He will do so if he is ruling well and his Government is in favour. If that is the case and the Prime Minister wants the endorsement of the people with respect to what he or she is doing, why should he or she not have that endorsement? Support for that proposition comes from the fact that that is the constitutional convention in England which is where, ultimately, we derive our conventions. So, if it is good enough for England, why is it not good enough for Australia? It is almost absurd to say that a much needed reform-and everyone agrees that the House of Representatives ought to have a four-term term-a reform that has been carried out in every State, as I have said, except Queensland, should be rejected on the sole ground that the Senate must face the people every four years or every time that an election is called. It is correct that, if all 12 senators go to the people at the same time, it is more likely that the minority views in the community will be reflected in the Senate because it is quite clear that there are parties in this chamber which are not present in the House of Representatives as a result of the voting system set up by the Labor Party.

It is not this side of the House that is rejecting the calls for democracy; it is the other side of the House, which wants to deny minority parties the ability to be represented in this chamber. It is not the Opposition on its own that has set up opposition to the various Bills, it is also the Australian Democrats who, may I say, have blackguarded others most unmercifully in respect of this proposition as well as many others. That is hardly a democratic approach to take.

It is said that the Senate is a States House. That furphy has been met again and again. This House, as was foreseen by some of the founding fathers, is very much a party House, and Senator Aulich illustrated that most eloquently. If anybody on either side moves out of line then heavy punishment can follow. In that context of electoral reform, who has a better history around Australia than the Australian Labor Party? I have indicated that over the years it has been the Australian Labor Party that has introduced legislation to make this a proper House of review, in so far as it can be that, which has led to the balancing of the parties in the Senate. In state politics all the reforms that have been carried out around Australia have been carried out by the Australian Labor Party, with the exception of the South Australian electoral system, which was reformed by Steele Hall. Of course, the reaction of the Liberal Party to Steele Hall is well and truly documented. He was downgraded and has never been a Minister here. He is not in the shadow Ministry now--

TALK.START.PARA: —He never will now.
—And never will be, simply because he carried out electoral reform. He is the only Liberal that can be pointed to in the history of Australia as having introduced any electoral reform.
—They threatened his preselection.

—Yes. So it fits ill in the mouths of the Opposition to berate us about this much needed reform. Where were the screams and yells when the term of the House in which the government is formed in the States was increased to four years? I have not heard them take Margaret Thatcher to task. Thatcherism apparently has limited attraction for the Opposition. Margaret Thatcher is able to hold office for five years and there are no great yells and screams from the other side about that. Yet when the Government wants to introduce four-year terms, to bring us into line with every House in Australia other than in Queensland in which the government is formed, the Opposition opposes it.
—We are talking about the Senate.

—Senator Hill asks about the Senate. If the House of Representatives moves to four-year terms, the Senate has to move to either four-year terms or eight-year terms. I think it is ridiculous that politicians should sit here for eight years without being subject to the will of the people, particularly when many Ministers come from this chamber and help form the government. Why does the Opposition want eight-year terms? Why do Opposition members want to sit on their seats over there for eight years? Why do they want to get their pensions in one term? Why do they want to capture a job for life and not face the people? What is wrong with facing the will of the people? What is wrong with the people of Australia having a constitutional right to say who their representatives will be? What is wrong with the people of Australia saying what they want in their government, which is formed not only in the House of Representatives but also in the Senate?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise for not being here for the duration of the debate but there was a meeting of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform which a number of us from both this chamber and the other place had to attend. However, I have heard Senator Cooney and he put in an appeal for the minority groups and for minority representation in this place. If I had my own self-interest at heart I would be voting yes for this proposition because what it would do, in effect, is reduce the quota from 14.2 per cent to 7.82 per cent. If I were self-interested I would vote for that proposal, but I am very strongly opposed to it because it will affect and alter and undermine the special characteristics of this chamber, this Senate, which is a House of review and not a rubber stamp for the government of the day.

SPEECH.PARA: I have heard people quoting the Opposition when it was in government as saying what a great thing this would be. I must say to honourable senators that that is precisely the reason that the people of Australia should reject this proposal. This proposal does not guarantee four-year parliaments. We have heard arguments about sitting here for eight years. That is a nonsense. I have never voted to sit here for eight years. I am quite happy with the Constitution as it is, provided that each government that is elected goes its full term-that is, three years. That has happened only twice since Federation. Why do governments not go their full term? I think the people of Australia want to see a fixed term for Parliament, as is the case in the United States of America. Thus, of course, the executive government in the US cannot manipulate public opinion and then go to the people when it suits it. It has to go to the people when it suits the Constitution and when the Constitution says it may. The people are certain that a government will last its full term.

This proposition is very deceptive. It would undermine the power of the Senate although, as has been said, there is no limitation to the power of the Senate to reject government legislation or to initiate Bills; the power is still there in the Constitution. Let me use the example of the identity card. The ID card was defeated because the Government had to go through the processes of section 57, which gave people time to wake up to what was going on. It was the people who really defeated the ID card. If the people had already voted yes to proposition No. 1 and if it were in the Constitution, we would have an ID card today. There is no doubt about that. At the time of the initial hysteria about the ID card the Government would have rammed the Bill through the House of Representatives, put it up here, it would have been rejected, and then it would have gone to the people immediately, without having to go through the section 57 constitutional requirement.

As my time has almost expired, let me say to the people of Australia: this proposition is not a guarantee of a four-year parliament at all. The proposition could well be posed thus: Do you agree to abolishing the only fixed term in the Constitution, namely, that of the Senate, and do you agree to giving more power to the Prime Minister of the day to call early elections?

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The annual report of the Australian Customs Service is a very important document. At the beginning of 1988 we saw the introduction of the harmonised tariff system, under which products that were not manufactured in Australia attracted a minimal 2 per cent tariff. However, along the line, the Government has made it difficult for importers of goods to get concessional orders for them should they not be available in Australia. It is one thing for the Customs Service to say that the goods can be manufactured in Australia; it is another to say that they are available in Australia.

I will give the Senate three examples of areas where we have trouble. A local manufacturer of tractors, who has to import a number of components used in their manufacture, must pay duty on them. However, his competitor, who imports the whole machine, pays none. An importer of fire pumps for replacement on fire engines must pay a hefty duty on them because no local manufacturer is prepared to manufacture a one-off replacement, although they may have the capacity to do so.

Another point, which concerns women in the home, is the hefty tariff on imported hobby tapestry and embroidery kits, there being only limited local production. Small flat electric motors are not available in Australia, yet hefty import duties have to be paid because motors of similar horsepower are available in Australia-although they are round, not flat.

These four examples show the absurd situation that has been created by the introduction of the harmonised tariff system. The problems could be overcome by quicker concessional orders. It is difficult for small manufacturers, employers or anybody who wants to import a one-off part to have to go through all the manufacturers in Australia to find out whether it is available. Let me relate a personal experience. I wanted an odd part which was not available in Australia. There was a hefty duty on its import. I took the working drawing on it to an engineering shop and asked the engineers whether they could make it. They said, `You have to be joking. If you gave us an order for 1,000, we would consider making it. But you only want one, so you will have to import it'. So I had to import the part and pay the hefty duty on it, which I considered unnecessary because duty should not have been payable on such items. That must happen a thousand times every day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the annual report of the Australian Customs Service, firstly I would like to congratulate the Comptroller-General, Mr Tom Hayes, on being elected as Secretary-General designate of the Customs Co-operation Council, a post he is to take up on 1 January 1989. Mr Hayes has had his hand on the tiller of the Australian Customs Service at a time of rapid technological change and has been subject to severe fiscal restrictions. His task cannot have been easy.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to congratulate the Comptroller on successfully persuading the Government to refer the Customs Act and other legislation to the Australian Law Reform Commission for comprehensive review. That was certainly long overdue. I would also like to thank the Australian Customs Service for the many briefings it has given me and to my staff during my term of office as shadow Minister responsible for this area.

The introduction of the harmonised tariff, which was intended to simplify classification of imported goods for duty purposes, created many anomalies and a great deal of effort by the Opposition has been put into seeking to remedy these anomalies. The harmonised tariff was expected to be revenue neutral, but it is interesting to note that, despite reductions in tariffs, Customs collected more than $13,800m, or $13.8 billion in revenue-an increase of nearly 7 per cent on the previous year. The new anti-dumping legislation was successfully amended by the Opposition to meet the concerns of industry about response time, and the creation of an anti-dumping authority is yet to prove its worth.

It was pleasing to note that the contraband enforcement teams to target high risk port and airport areas were introduced during the year and that the number and quality of seizures has risen, but there remains concern about the effectiveness of the Customs barrier operations, particularly on our northern coastline. This was evidenced by the recent discovery of jetsam containing huge quantities of compressed cannabis. The continued intrusion of Indonesian fishing vessels into northern Australian waters and the seizure of 15 such vessels indicates the size of the problem. The chance discovery of arms in a 12-tonne container of `used machinery' from North Yemen being transhipped to Fiji also indicates that adequate resources may not be directed to barrier control operations. The decision to transfer primary responsibility for northern surveillance to Customs does not appear to overcome many of the bureaucratic problems associated with the previous arrangements and the Opposition believes that the defence forces, with their sophisticated command and control arrangements and their assets, would be in the best position to undertake this task.

The commercial tariff concession system appears to be another area in urgent need of reform. Complaints have been received from industry about the slowness and other difficulties in dealing with tariff concession orders and indications are that staff reductions were premature and have greatly added to the difficulties in reducing the harmonised tariff anomalies that I referred to earlier.

It is noted that the report states that it is expected the customs tariff and excise legislation which we successfully deferred in November last year will be re-presented in this Budget session. It was deferred because the Opposition and Australian Democrats were very concerned about its draconian provisions. We determined that the Government should be given an opportunity for proper consultation with industry. Our indications are that proper consultation has not taken place. A team was sent out to discuss things with industry in this area, but in our view that team was unsuccessful in meeting the genuine concerns of industry. We look forward to that legislation to see whether the Government has turned its mind to the problems which were raised by industry when the legislation was introduced last November.
This report is comprehensive. It is impossible to do more than touch on some of the problems in this important area, so I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to comment on the annual report of the Australian Customs Service. My association with the Customs Service goes back to my childhood. I have many acquaintances in the Customs Service, including an uncle, who was a collector of customs in Hobart. So I have always had a close affinity with the Customs Service. The report covers quite comprehensively all aspects of the operations of the Service. One aspect that concerned me somewhat was the report on the investigations into drug trafficking. The total amount of seizures in kilograms for 1987-88 of restricted drugs is quite impressive-737 seizures and a total of 4,174 kilograms. However, the page describing comparisons of drug seizures with previous years leads me, and, I presume, would lead the Government, to have some concern. In 1984-85 there were 168 seizures of heroin, 32.9 kilograms. In 1987-88 there were 74 seizures of heroin, 17.3 kilograms. One would be foolish to believe that the heroin trade diminished by half in that time. One would think, therefore, that the detection rate is not as it should be.

SPEECH.PARA: With the other forbidden drugs, cocaine and cannabis, there is a similar story. The amount of cannabis seized in 1988 was similar to that seized in 1984-85, and almost half the amount of cocaine seized in 1984-85 was seized in 1988. If we take out the two large hauls made in north Queensland and off Sydney, involving something like four tonnes of cannabis, there would probably have been a very diminished amount seized.

I was a member of a very recent delegation to South East Asia. One of the things we did there was talk to the members of the Australian Federal Police there. Our bipartisan delegation will be making a report to the Government. I am sure that in that report we will be strongly asking the Government to support the Federal Police in their work in those areas. We will be saying that we should be giving more backup to the one or two officers who are there: we seem to have only limited numbers of Federal Police in those areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to that part of the Australian Customs Service annual report entitled `Barrier Control'. The definition of `barrier control' given in the `Objective' section is:

SPEECH.PARA: To protect the community by maintaining the integrity of the Australian Customs Barrier against the importation or exportation of prohibited goods, particularly illicit narcotics, and the unlawful movement of cargo and people.

Since the report was published the Customs Service has assumed wider responsibilities than it had at the time that the report was written. It now has been virtually tasked with the whole of the management of surveillance of Australia's northern approaches and has taken over the management of the functions of the Coastwatch and the littoral survey service. There is a very great, constant and continuing worry in northern Australia about the way in which this Government has left northern Australia wide open to entry by anyone. It was apparent in the 1970s that something needed to be done about it. The Liberal and National parties instituted the first of the surveillance schemes. They were experimental and developmental. They were progressively better year by year. But in the five years in which the Australian Labor Party has been in government, it has been downhill all the way.

I will give two examples of that. In the 1970s 30,000 hours were flown by the littoral survey group. The figure is now down to 10,000 hours being flown by Coastwatch. The P3Cs of Nos 10 and 11 squadrons of the Royal Australian Air Force, which patrol the Australian fishing zone, are flying only 700 hours this year. Last year they flew 1,220 hours and in 1985-86 they flew 1,450 hours, which represents over twice the effort that they are currently putting in. That has occurred in the short time span of three years. One can argue about effectivity and suitability of equipment, but at least it provided some deterrent factor, and that factor is no longer there.

The principal deterrent to the present has been the Coastwatch system, which carries out purely a littoral survey, which is operated at predictable times along predictable tracks, over the beach, in daylight, using only eyeballs to find any intrusions-directed primarily towards quarantine breaches. I think that the Customs Service was quite successful, but it did its own thing in its own way in isolation from the other services. Of course, the defence forces-the Navy and the Air Force-also made some contribution. The system that is in place is a daylight system. There is no radar surveillance, so it cannot check aircraft flying in and out. It is entirely predictable and it has very low grade intelligence support.

The Labor Party has decided to take away this role from the Australian Federal Police and give it to Customs. While I think that Customs has done quite well with the limited resources available to it, one must recognise that there are about 14 different Commonwealth departments involved, each with their own jealousies and priorities. Coordination is critically important to making it work. Quite bluntly, Customs does not have the muscle to make it work. We have been bedevilled by the `user pays' doctrine in this regard. One department, jealously, will not give any service to another department unless it charges it at the marginal rate. There is no prospect of Customs being able to make the system work any better than it has in the past.

Senator Michael Baume said that there are manpower problems, which seem to be endemic under this Government with respect to departments. The Customs Service is on strike because it is overloaded, and there are no resources, no budget allocations, for increased capabilities to cope with these increased responsibilities. The situation is not quite as bad as that in the defence forces. About 44,000 men and women out of 70,000 have resigned from those forces in the five years since Labor came to government. But the proposals put forward for Customs to operate this service simply will not result in a better service.

We must have a 24-hour capability in the north. We must have flexibility, good intelligence and good coordination. That is why the management of it, not the execution of it, in the eyes of the Opposition, should be with the Australian defence forces. Customs simply cannot cope with the situation at present. Even if the money were given to it, it would have to develop a whole new range of skills to provide the surveillance that we need in order to prevent illegal activities, such as those involved with the seven 44-gallon drums of cannabis which were apparently anchored on the reef and which became known about only when they were washed up, having been blown away by a storm. That sort of thing is quite intolerable. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
