The speech read as follows-
Mr President, this Bill will amend the capital gains tax and substantiation provisions of the income tax law and the fringe benefits tax law.
Capital Gains Rollover Relief

The Bill gives effect to the proposal announced on 28 January 1988 to extend relief from tax on capital gains to a number of kinds of business reorganisations, and to make a number of technical amendments to the existing rollover provisions. Generally the rollover amendments in this Bill will apply to reorganisations commencing after 28 January 1988.
Interposition of a Company into an Existing Business Structure

Rollover relief will be given where a resident company is interposed between an existing resident company and its shareholders who dispose of their shares in the existing company for non-redeemable shares in the interposed company.
Crown Leases

The Bill will allow rollover relief from 20 September 1985 where a crown lease of land is converted to freehold or to a lease in perpetuity, or is renewed, extended, reduced or expanded in size, subdivided or consolidated with another crown lease held by the taxpayer. The 28 January 1988 announcement indicated that rollover relief would be available where the land under the new lease was the same, or substantially the same, as that under the original lease. This Bill clarifies what is meant by substantially the same by broadly proposing that rollover relief be available to the extent to which land under a new lease or a freehold interest comprises land held under the original crown lease.

A related amendment to apply from 20 September 1985 broadens the scope of the principal residence exemption to include a dwelling on land under a crown lease, regardless of the term of the lease. Rollover relief will also apply if the crown pays compensation to the lessee where a crown lease of land has expired and is not to be renewed and the lessee acquires a replacement asset.
Renewal of Licences or Authorities
Rollover relief will be extended from 20 September 1985 to the renewal or extension of a statutory licence, authority or permit.
Prospecting and Mining Rights

Specific rollover relief applicable to the mining industry will be widened from 20 September 1985 to include renewals, extensions, consolidations or splits of prospecting rights or mining rights and the relinquishment of part of an existing prospecting or mining right on the issue of a new right.
Involuntary Disposals

Rollover relief will be extended from 20 September 1985 where a government or government authority acquires an asset by voluntary agreement rather than under the compulsory acquisition processes. Also, a replacement for an asset acquired before 20 September 1985 will be taken to have been acquired before that date if its acquisition cost does not exceed 120 per cent of the market value of the original asset immediately before its loss or destruction.
Transfer of Asset to Wholly Owned Company

The Bill will extend the rollover relief available to a partnership that transfers assets to a wholly-owned company where one or more of the partners are trustees and the requirement that at least one of the partners be a natural person is to be removed.
Public Trading Unit Trusts

Rollover relief will be extended where the trustee of a public trading trust established before 20 September 1985 makes, as a result of a reorganisation, a proportionate distribution in specie to unitholders of shares acquired before that date. Generally, the amendment to extend relief in this way will apply to transfers of shares after 28 January 1988 and before 1 July 1988.
Marriage Breakdown

The scope of the present rollover for the transfer of assets on the breakdown of a marriage is to be extended to include a court-directed or court-sanctioned transfer between a company or a trust and one of the spouses.
Unit Trusts/Companies

Categories of rollover relief now available for certain transactions by companies are to be extended to comparable transactions by trustees of unit trusts. Relief will also be extended to splits or consolidations of company issued rights or options to acquire shares and to rights or options to acquire units in a unit trust.
Transfer of Assets to Non-Resident Companies

In the announcement of 28 January 1988, it was said that where a taxable Australian asset was transferred to a non-resident company in circumstances in which rollover relief was available, the asset would be taken to be a taxable Australian asset in the hands of the transferee and an asset received in consideration for the disposal would also be a taxable Australian asset. On further review it was found that a more satisfactory approach is to provide that rollover relief will be available only where the asset is in fact a taxable Australian asset of the transferee company, instead of treating the asset as a taxable Australian asset.

To ensure that there is no element of retrospectivity in this approach, the limitation of the availability of rollover relief will apply only in respect of assets disposed of after today. Amendments to treat the transferred asset as a taxable Australian asset will apply in respect of assets disposed of after 28 January 1988 and on or before 25 May 1988. Mr President, the nature of these rollover amendments is such that a reliable estimate of the revenue effect cannot be made.
Substantiation Rules
The substantiation rules will be amended in a number of respects.
Overseas Travel Expenses

Employees in receipt of a reasonable travel allowance will, with effect from 1 July 1986, not have to substantiate claims, within that allowance, for expenses in respect of food, drink or other expenditure incidental to overseas travel. Travel diary requirements for members of the crew of an international flight will also be removed from the substantiation rules.
Motor Vehicle Fuel and Oil Expenses

The substantiation rules were amended in 1987 to allow fuel and oil expenses for cars to be verified by a record of total kilometres travelled during the year. From 1 July 1986 this Bill allows similar treatment for other vehicles such as motor cycles and small trucks.
Car Hire Expenses

Care hire expenses incurred after the start of the 1988-89 income year are not to be treated as car expenses for the purposes of the substantiation rules. Instead, they will be substantiated as employment-related expenses or, if the hire car is used for overseas travel or extended travel within Australia, as travel expenses.
Reimbursements
The Bill also makes it clear that reimbursements of fringe benefits tax are exempt from income tax.
Fringe Benefits Tax

Several refinements of fringe benefits tax rules, generally having effect from 1 July 1986, are also proposed. Employers meeting the reasonable food, drink or incidental expenses of overseas travel by their employees will be able to appropriately reduce the taxable value of the relevant fringe benefits without first obtaining documentary evidence of those expenses. To ease the paperwork burden on fringe benefits tax employers, the Bill provides that employers may specify certain information about car fringe benefits in records to be retained by them, rather than in fringe benefits tax returns. From the start of the 1989-90 fringe benefits tax year, car records will have to be in a form approved by the Commissioner of Taxation. The remote area holiday travel concession, under which employers pay fringe benefits tax on only one half of the taxable value of fringe benefits arising from reimbursing employees' holiday costs is to be extended to cover cases where the benefit is an allowance paid to an employee's spouse or children.

Another change is the exemption from fringe benefits tax of the cost to employers of compassionate travel. Broadly, the exemption will apply where an employer meets the cost of an employee's travel to visit a seriously ill spouse or child or to attend a family funeral. It will also be made plain that an employee contribution to an employer's fringe benefits tax liability does not reduce the taxable value of the fringe benefits the employer provides. Other minor technical amendments are included in the Bill. The fringe benefits tax and substantiation measures in this Bill will have a negligible effect on revenue. I present the explanatory memorandum and commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Reynolds) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill is an omnibus bill for legislation administered within the Primary Industries and Energy portfolio. Its introduction will facilitate the passage of amendments to existing legislation. The Bill contains minor typographical and administrative amendments to the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977, Dairy Produce Act 1986, Pig Industry Act 1986 and Rural Industries Research Act 1985; and repeals a redundant Act, the Dairy Industry Act 1967. These amendments will be self evident and are sufficiently explained in the Explanatory Memo- randum circulated with the Bill. I propose to confine my comments to addressing the more significant changes which will be made by the Bill.
Canned Fruits Marketing Act 1979-Repeal
Canned Fruits Levy Act 1979-Repeal
Canned Fruits Levy Collection Act 1979-Repeal

The Bill provides for the repeal of the Canned Fruits Marketing Act 1979 and two associated Acts, the Canned Fruits Levy Act 1979 and the Canned Fruits Levy Collection Act 1979. These amendments were foreshadowed in September 1987 in the announcement of the Government's decision on the Industries Assistance Commission Interim Report on Canned Fruit (Statutory Marketing and Interim Assistance Arrangements).

Under the Canned Fruits Marketing Act, the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation is empowered to acquire canned deciduous fruit produced in those States where complementary State legislation exists and to market the acquired product in Australia and overseas. In addition, the Corporation operates a pooling scheme whereby returns from gazetted pool markets are equalised and an equalised return is paid to canners.

The Government considers that the canned fruits statutory marketing arrangements have served their purpose of bringing about a degree of stability to the industry. However, the industry now needs to adjust further to changing market circumstances, and the repeal of the legislation will allow for necessary structural adjustment and encourage more innovation.

In reaching its decision to wind up the Corporation, the Government has also taken into consideration the possible future relationship of the canned deciduous fruit industry to the Australian Horticultural Corporation, for which legislation has recently been passed. The Government believes that certain functions currently performed by the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation could be transferred to the Australian Horticultural Corporation either directly or on a fee for service basis. These are matters to be decided upon by the industry.
Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation Act 1977

The purpose of this amendment to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act is to make clear that shipping lines involved in the carriage of meat or livestock on behalf of licenced exporters do not themselves need to hold a meat or livestock export licence.

Whilst this has always been the understanding and intention of the legislation, recent legal advice to the Government has indicated that the matter is not beyond doubt and that clarification is therefore desirable. The amendment maintains the status quo, and has the support of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation.
Export Control Act 1982

The amendments will restrict `authorised officers' to persons appointed under section 20 of the Act, will put beyond doubt the power of an authorised officer to take photographs or video tape recordings as evidence of a breach of the Act, will permit the regulations to impose penalty for non-payment of fees and will clarify that the orders can impose penalty for the non-payment of fees but cannot impose penalty for offences against the orders.
Fishing Industry Research and Development Act 1987

This amendment is to place beyond doubt the power of the Fishing Industry Research and Development Council to enter into arrangements with the Department of Primary Industries and Energy for the provision of, and payment for, clerical and administrative services.
Meat Inspection Act 1983

The amendments will permit the regulations to impose penalty for non-payment of fees, will put beyond doubt the power of an authorised officer to take photographs or video tape recordings as evidence of a breach of the Act and will clarify that the orders can impose penalty for the non-payment of fees but cannot impose penalty for offences against the orders.
Minerals (Submerged Lands) Act 1981

The Minerals (Submerged Lands) Act 1981 provides for a regime to allow exploration for, and exploitation of, minerals from the seabed. Administration of this regime will be shared between the States, the Northern Territory and the Commonwealth in accordance with the Offshore Constitutional Settlement of 1979. Although passed in 1981, proclamation of the Act has been held up pending the passage by the States and the Northern Territory of complementary legislation which is necessary before a common regime covering offshore minerals activity can be established.

The purpose of this amendment is to remove the current requirement that the States and the Northern Territory pass legislation to authorise their respective Ministers to carry out the day-to-day administration of offshore minerals activity under the Act. Instead the States and the Northern Territory will be able to authorise their Ministers by administrative action.

The Commonwealth has received expressions of interest from companies seeking to explore the seabed for minerals beyond the three nautical mile territorial sea and the Government does not wish to unduly delay exploration pending the establishment of a common offshore minerals regime. The Commonwealth is therefore considering proclaiming only those portions of the Act as will be sufficient for a regime covering exploration. Once the complementary States and Northern Territory legislation has been enacted the Commonwealth will proclaim the remaining portions of the Act.
Plant Variety Rights Act 1987

Subsections 3 (1) and 3 (7) will be amended to change ``public knowledge'' to ``common knowledge''. The concept of public knowledge requires only one person to know about the new variety whereas common knowledge infers that the variety is known within the trade, ie by experts in the field.

This change is in line with the intent of the Act and will more closely reflect actual practice. Common knowledge is used in Plant Variety Rights legislation overseas and in the International Convention of the Union for the Protection of New Plant Varieties. Australia will now conform with international practice.

Section 46 of the Act will be amended to remunerate all part-time members of the Plant Variety Rights Advisory Committee equally. Under the current legislation only two of the six part-time members receive Remuneration Tribunal allowances and remuneration. The others only receive Senior Executive Service travel allowances. This is clearly an anomaly as the members all contribute equally to the working of the Committee and were appointed for their expertise and experience in areas specified by the Act.
The extra cost involved will be $3,000 per annum which can be absorbed in the current appropriation.
Wool Marketing Act 1987

Wool tax, paid by woolgrowers into the Market Support Fund, administered by the Australian Wool Corporation for the operation of the wool reserve price scheme, is refunded when market circumstances and the amount in the fund allow. The Bill provides for the Commissioner for Taxation to provide specific information to the Australian Wool Corporation to facilitate the payment of the refunds of wool tax to woolgrowers.

These provisions effectively reinstate two paragraphs from the part dealing with refunds in the new repealed Wool Industry Act. It was the original intention that all the administrative procedures relating to refunds should be included in Wool Marketing Regulations. However, advice from the Attorney-General's Department was that delegated legislation could not confer powers over another Commonwealth body. Accordingly these provisions are to be reinstated in the Wool Marketing Act, with the concurrence of the Treasurer.

Wool is expected to be Australia's major export income earner in 1987-88. To preserve the market dominance of Australian wool and its competitiveness relative to other fibres, everything possible must be done to ensure that wool sold for export meets the quality requirements of buyers.

The Australian Wool Corporation has powers under Section 74 of the Wool Marketing Act 1987 relating to quality assurance. These provide for the Corporation to prevent the sale, at export auction, of wool which does not meet industry standards. This includes wool which contains unacceptable levels of pesticide residue and wool which has not been classed by a registered wool classer.

These powers are limited to the sale of wool at export auctions and do not cover the 20 per cent of the wool clip which is sold outside the auction system. They are also inconsistent with the Corporation's power under section 63 to formulate and secure the adoption of industry standards and terms for the sale of wool at auction or otherwise.

Therefore, the amendments will bring the Corporation's powers under both Sections of the Act into line and enable it to prevent the sale of wool contaminated with pesticide residues, for export, by private sale as well as through the auction system. These powers are necessary to ensure that the international reputation of Australian wool is maintained.

Attorney-General's Department has advised that the present penalty provisions of the Wool Marketing Act and Wool Marketing Regulations are ineffective with respect to the prosecution of corporations. Accordingly the corporate knowledge provisions to the Bill, based on those of Section 84 of the Trade Practices Act 1974, have been developed to enable successful prosecution of corporations.

Section 127 of the Wool Marketing Act provides for regulations to be made in relation to registration of wool test houses, but not for their inspection. The lack of any legislative authority to inspect test houses, for the purpose of registration or to ensure compliance with approved procedures, could jeopardise the confidence of buyers in the integrity of Australian wool testing and description, with adverse effects on our wool export trade. A regulation-making power providing for inspection of wool test houses will therefore be inserted in section 127 of the Act. I commend the Bill to the honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS BILL 1988INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 August, on motion by Senator Tate:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week, when the debate on the Industrial Relations Bill was adjourned, I was expressing concern about many areas of the Government's handling of industrial relations during its term of office. Not the least of those concerns was the Government's being controlled by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and, added to that, the bullying tactics used by union officials to make many people who do not necessarily wish to be members part of a union. I was also saying that, given the choice, the majority of those people would prefer not to be in a union.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a difference between the public propaganda of the ACTU as to how popular unions are and the quoting of statistics to their own members. I think that real distinction needs to be drawn because it becomes very clear that a great many Australians do not want to belong to a union; yet, as I have said, they are being bullied into it by the pressures of de facto compulsion in many industries. It must also concern the ACTU that, in all industries, total unionisation of private enterprise stands at 35 per cent compared with 71 per cent of the public payroll. Especially significant is the fact that, by occupation, 44 per cent of trades people in the private sector are unionised compared with 82 per cent in the public sector; for clerks, the respective proportions between private and public sectors are 21 per cent and 61 per cent unionisation; and, for labourers and other unskilled workers, 45 per cent and 74 per cent.

To shore up the power of unions, clause 122 of this Bill continues to enshrine the powers of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to grant preference to unionists and that is of great concern to me. I state unequivocally at this juncture that a Liberal Government will legislate to remove this power in accordance with our objective of ensuring that no Australian is required to join, or remain in, a union against his or her will. Surely that is what we are all about-true and total freedom of choice. Neither will we allow union dues to be collected by employers without the specific request of the individual employee. In so doing, we will be responding to the wishes of the 83 per cent of Australians who totally reject compulsory unionism-a figure from September 1986 that included 76 per cent of trade unionists themselves. So the trade unionists are of that belief, contrary to what the ACTU is constantly telling us.

We will also be in accord with the 78 per cent of Australians who believe that unions have too much power. We have seen the unions flex their muscles over recent years and, again, bully and harass employers. Employers, after all, are the ones who are providing the jobs, but that seems to matter not to the union movement. That is where the Liberal policy for a future Liberal government is particularly pertinent. The trade union officials have done very well out of this Labor Government. In return for $1.14m in recorded donations to the Australian Labor Party (ALP) between 1984 and 1987, unions have received a total of $5.8m in various Federal Government grants-that is not a bad return on $1.14m-not including the cost of running union elections or those of the Trade Union Training Authority. Clearly, these handouts of taxpayers' funds are not enough. The ACTU is demanding the implementation of at least some of its own agenda. That is where the flexing of its muscles comes in time and again. That is where we see the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) time and again, also, ensuring that he consults Mr Crean, the other Prime Minister of this country, to ensure that Mr Crean agrees with whatever he does.

Much of this agenda was set out last year in the document Australia Reconstructed. If Australia were to be run along the lines of this document, it should be named `Australia Deconstructed'. It is a document in which it is proposed that all restrictions to union amalgamations be removed so that the 326 unions in Australia be rationalised to 20. Just imagine the muscle they would have then. No further organisations would be registered unless they were the result of amalgamations. That is a very dangerous position; it is a very dangerous proposition that the ACTU is demanding. This quest for bigness, eliminating many smaller and more moderate unions, can be achieved only through the further curtailment of the right to freedom of association. This Bill takes major steps to fulfil the ACTU proposal and in doing so tramples several articles of the International Labour Organisation's convention regarding freedom of association. No one in this Government can honestly say, if they really believe in freedom of association, that they go along with what has been happening in the past.

Article 2 of that convention, for example, gives workers the unfettered right to establish and join organisations of their own choosing `without previous authorisation'. This right is definitely circumscribed by clause 189, which will not allow the registration, except in what are described as `special circumstances', of any new union that has less than 3,000 members that is not industry based and that may impinge upon any union `to which members of the association might conveniently belong'. The whole thrust of this legislation will be to force many Australians to remain members of organisations whose methods and political stance may be absolutely and utterly repugnant to them, or who simply do not represent their general industrial interests. But that seems not to matter in the slightest. As long as they are members, that is fine. Existing unions will be freed from the threat of a rival union seeking to represent their members. For example, it would be impossible for moderates who had lost confidence in a radical union, tightly controlled by its leaders, to establish an alternative body-once again, removing the freedom of choice or freedom of association.

Can any honourable senator who claims to uphold the principle of freedom of association deprive Australians of that specific right? Surely, that is what Australia is all about. It is one of the great freedoms we have enjoyed for time immemorial, yet it is something that is being put at risk. Whether or not we would concede that guaranteed industrial harmony is worth the sacrifice of any individual right, the fact is that that heavy-handed prohibition of new unions, and the pressures of amalgamations, cannot promise freedom from demarcation disputes and industrial strife generally. It is a very large price to pay. It is a price that we should not be considering paying for one moment. In Japan, for example, industrial peace is not threatened by a large number of small unions. Nor should it be inferred that demarcation disputes are likely to be caused by small as opposed to larger unions. The record of recent demarcation disputes is otherwise very small.

The Liberal Party believes that our industrial system would be better served by the substitution of unions based on enterprise rather than on occupation as the only effective means of preventing demarcation disputes. We must ensure that that is prevented, because enterprise-based unions are a very different matter from the creation of a small number of massive union structures that are the objective of both this Government and the ACTU. The formation of enterprise-based unions in accordance with the wishes of the employees concerned may well require secession from existing unions as well as amalgamations. It is obvious that this Government is carrying out the wishes of the ACTU to ensure that the current political stance of Australia's major unions is not threatened by the rise of any alternative bodies. Avoidance of demarcation disputes is the cloak for this real motivation. That is where we have to look at the bottom of this whole thing. What is the real motivation?

The Government, in framing this Bill, has not worried at all about International Labour Organisation convention article 4, which states that neither employers' nor workers' organisations shall be dissolved or suspended by administrative authority. Under clause 193, small unions of fewer than 3,000 members will, after three years, be deregistered by the Commission unless `special circumstances' allow them to continue `in the public interest'. This threatens to close down half of the 148 federally registered unions as noted by the Minister, by what can only be described as administrative action.

I state clearly and unequivocally that the Liberal Party is not against unions. It is very much in favour of the moderate unions that seek to do the best possible job for their members, but we do not see that this Bill, by amalgamation, will achieve any of those objectives. The proposals are far harsher than interference with their freedom of association than was proposed even in the 1987 Bill that was rather selectively or judiciously removed prior to the last election because it was seen to be too hot to handle. That bill provided for the deregistration of unions of less than 1,000 members after five years. It should be added that clause 261, ordering unions to admit as members anyone applying and eligible for membership unless of `general bad character', is also a restriction on freedom of association. How outrageous! Until there is genuine voluntary unionism in Australian industrial relations, unions will be subjected to this kind of governmental interference ad nauseam. I do not think this country can afford that for one moment. Nor ought we to forget that while the rights of small unions which may well be doing an effective job in representing their members' interests are disregarded by this Government, the ACTU, on whose behest these changes are being made, is not itself a registered trade union.

This Bill is all about industrial politics, not effective industrial relations or the rights of workers. Industrial relations politics are very obvious in clause 128 which allows the full bench of the Commission to restrain a State industrial authority from dealing with a dispute. The ACTU is, I think, smarting over the action of the Queensland Government in recent years to protect its citizens from the blackmail of certain unions and wishes, therefore, to reduce the authority of the States in industrial matters. That is a great tragedy. It was obvious a few years ago that the Queensland Government had the courage to do what its citizens wished and it was admired by many Australians throughout Australia for having that courage. It is therefore highly doubtful that this clause will do anything positive to protect Australians from irresponsible union action, and it may indeed have the reverse effect.

The Liberal Party equally does not regard as positive the extension of the power of the Commission by clause 124 to consider claims for strike pay in those instances where employees had `reasonable concern', in the words of the Minister, for health and safety. We saw what happened on this very building site in the new Parliament House and remember some of the concerns that people had. Frankly, I believe that many people should have had more concern about what was not going on in the construction of this building at times than about what was going on. It will be likely that health and safety aspects will be found in what are nothing more than applications for strike pay. We saw that once again during the construction of this building. There is nothing to be gained in enabling the Commission to ratify what are simply destructive industrial fixes. I recall being told about one strike that was held on this site for health reasons. One of the toilets was out of toilet paper. A strike took place over that.

The Liberal Party stands firm on the principle that payment and acceptance of strike pay should be an offence, that industrial action to obtain strike pay should be prohibited, that those causing loss by such action should be liable for damages, and that such action should be grounds for union deregistration. I think that is a responsible proposal. Altogether there is a very real difference between the approach of this Government/ACTU-it is one and the same-and that of the coalition to industrial relations reform.

The coalition's stress will be on the voluntary principle which the so-called industrial relations club finds totally inconvenient but which the Australian people find totally convenient. While we believe in enterprise-based unions, we believed that union structures must be determined by the wishes of membership expressed through secret ballots. If we are to continue with an arbitration commission, the Opposition realises that it must have recourse to effective sanctions to ensure compliance with its directives and appropriate penalties-matters which the Government in this legislation fails to tackle. It goes nowhere near even looking at those matters. Such compliance provisions are complementary to the proven sanction of the civil courts and of the Trade Practices Act against secondary boycotts. A future coalition government will allow the Federal Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) to bring proceedings under this Act to further industrial relations justice.

Unlike the Opposition, this Government steadfastly refuses to learn the positive lessons of industrial developments in Britain, where union structures and general problems are not dissimilar to our own in Australia. The present British Government promised to deliver ordinary citizens from the tyranny of arbitrary union power, and to a large degree they have done so in a very short period of time. An essential feature of change has been the prohibition of secondary boycotts and the increasing subjection of trade unions to civil law. Enforcement of the rule of law means that the consequences of holding the community to ransom can become prohibitively expensive for unions that break the law in so doing. The breaking down of the closed shop has brought immense benefit not only to these workers no longer compulsorily dragooned into union membership but also to those who do belong to those unions that have adapted to new realities. The electricians and the engineers, who make up Britain's second and fourth largest unions, have adopted a firm policy of providing maximum service to their members, and of taking industrial stances in the interests of members. This has involved making no-strike deals with employers to the financial benefit of the workers concerned. It is part of a process where union leaders put the interests of their workers ahead of any policy adopted by the British version of the ACTU, the Trades Union Congress.

This Labor Government, however, has failed dismally to grasp the truth that the interests of Australian workers, inside and outside trade unions, are not the same as the interests of the ACTU. The interests of the ACTU are totally different from the aims and objectives of many of their members. This legislation perpetuates these weaknesses and injustices that exist in the current industrial relations system, and its initiatives constitute a further assault on freedom of association in seeking to build super unions, as desired by the ACTU. The proposal for super unions must be resisted at all levels. I know that once the people of Australia become more and more aware of the ACTU proposals they will resist the notion put forward in the document Australia Reconstructed. Australia needs industrial reform that will enforce the umpire's decision and the rule of law. That gives scope for agreements between individual employers and their employees; it promotes voluntary unionism; and it gives scope for enterprise-based unions. As a member of the coalition industrial relations committee, I am pleased that we have given all due consideration to all aspects of the importance of the responsible areas of the trade union movement and the important role of employers to ensure that there is a real possibility of total harmony between the two, but also remembering the rights and freedoms of the individual. It is clear that it is up to the Opposition to deliver these reforms, and that the ALP and this Government dare not and will not do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this my first speech in the new Parliament House, on our fourth sitting day here, I wish to support the Government's Industrial Relations Bill. However, I assure honourable senators that this will not be my last speech in this place. The Bill before us represents the conclusion of a process that was set in train soon after the Australian Labor Party's election to government in 1983. In commissioning the Committee of Review into Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems, the Government recognised the broad concerns about the present functioning of the industrial conciliation and arbitration system. In recent times we have seen attacks on the functions of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. One regrets the extent to which that system has been denigrated by those who believe that its function is not in the best interests of the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's concerns were varied and the solutions put forward following the report of that Committee were often completely opposed to the system as it presently functions. There was a strong mood for change, however, among unions, employers, the general public, and indeed the Government. The mood for change had much to do with the approach of the previous Liberal-National Party Government to industrial relations. The wages freeze, the ad hoc approach to amending the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, anti-worker legislation, such as the Commonwealth Employees (Retirement and Redeployment) Act and the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act, restrictions on union amalgamations and interference in union affairs were some of the hallmarks of the years of conservative government. It was pleasing to note in the debates that took place in the old Parliament House in the last year or so how even Opposition members were prepared to concede that perhaps they had been too conservative in respect of union amalgamations.

It is no surprise that the anti-union, pro-capital industrial relations stand of the previous coalition Government led to a serious decline in industrial relations, in national productivity and, as a natural corollary of that, in the country's economic performance. The bad industrial relations environment and the callous `inflation first' and `jobs last' policies pursued by Messrs Howard and Fraser, coupled with an increase of nearly 200,000 in the unemployment queue in 1982-83, led to a change in political attitudes and the election of a Labor government. The emergence therefore of a new, reinvigorated government with strong union support, based on the prices and incomes accord, heralded a new era in relations between workers, business and government. I want to pay public tribute to those union officials who put together the prices and incomes accord and particularly to those members of the Left in the trade union movement who initiated and gave strength and leadership to establishing a much better working relationship between government, unions and the private sector. In seeking to institute cooperation instead of confrontation this Government acted swiftly to appoint a committee of review, a move which was welcomed by all of the parties concerned. It was chaired by Professor Hancock and reported in the middle of 1985 and then spent two years conducting widespread negotiations and consultations with interested parties. The outcome of this was the Industrial Relations Bill of 1987. History now records that the Bill never progressed beyond the Minister's second reading speech because, after all the consultation and the research over a period of nearly four years, employer organisations would not wear the compliance provisions of the Bill. I will return to a discussion of the compliance provisions later.

The Bill now before the Senate resulted from another year of extensive consultation between unions, business and government. That consultation underlines the strength of the Bill and must surely be one of the most comprehensive and exhaustive since Federation. The 1980 Bill is different in a number of ways from last year's Bill. I wish to outline the strengths and some of the weaknesses of the present Bill with references where appropriate to the changes from the 1987 proposals.

At the outset the Senate should take note of the fact that this Bill is the first update of the 1904 Conciliation and Arbitration Act. Consequently, upon the passage of the associated legislation, I have confidence that that will be the situation in the Senate. This historical Act will be repealed. One has to draw attention to the fact that the conservative parties had 39 years in the post-war period to bring about a more modern industrial relations Bill but failed to do so as indeed they did in respect of the legislation which I was proud to be associated with, the repatriation Bill of 1987.

Since 1904 the Conciliation and Arbitration Act has been amended so many times that in many areas it has become unworkable. Largely this has been as a result of attacks on the system by conservative governments over those periods. In the dying days of the McMahon Government I told the Senate the following and I quote from my speech recorded on 25 May 1972:

. . . in the period of 22 1/2 years that this Government has unfortunately been running the affairs of this country it has passed 185 Acts or amendments relating to trade unions. Since federation and the establishment of the early legislation, it has been amended 52 times. Of that number, 23 amendments were associated with the Conciliation and Arbitration Act.

As I mentioned earlier, in 1975-1983 conservative government continued in the same fine amending tradition as its predecessors in the pre-Whitlam era. It is ironic that the senators opposite, as they follow the speeches made by their counterparts in the House of Representatives, continually complain, whinge and whine about the unions' alleged contempt for the rule of law. To the contrary it has been successive conservative governments which have amended, appended, enacted and repealed legislation to hamper the legitimate role of the unions in representing their members, both inside and outside the arbitration system. It is not to be repudiated in this legislation that it is essential now for the Parliament to pass legislation to strengthen the role of the trade unions, not in some capricious way, but to counter the immensely strengthened role that private capital plays in the development of our country.

We have seen the great mergers and amalgamations taking place in recent years and that very strength of capital reflects itself in political power. It is essential therefore that the trade union movement that represents the organised working class people who work for their salary and wage have sufficient resources and strength to play a fair part in the relationship between labour and capital. This Government has sorted out the mishmash that existed when we came into office and for that the Minister, Mr Willis, deserves our applause and support. Of course, there are a number of additions to the consolidated Bill. Amalgamation of trade unions has been made much easier. There are 148 federally registered unions in Australia and of these the smallest 72-almost half of them-cover only 2.9 per cent of the total membership. One wonders what sort of a strange registration system we have. For example, from my personal knowledge we have a shop assistants union but we find an association of pharmacy employees gaining registration. Obviously these people are performing the same function of dealing with customers. One can give many other instances of the small unions which have been established and which have a very slight variance with a Federal or State registered union.

Altogether there are about 300 different unions in Australia and this contrasts most unfavourably with countries like Sweden and West Germany. I know that the Opposition will talk about Japan but there is no magical number of unions that one can accept. One has to have regard to the historical conditions and positions that labour and capital play in the development of a modern society. I pay tribute at least to some members of the Opposition parties in the House of Representatives who acknowledge that there are too many unions. It is very difficult for the employers and for business organisations to negotiate with too many unions that are at the workshop or factory level. There is a need for a reduction in the numbers and hence an increase in the size of unions in this country. This is recognised by most unions and by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). This is also recognised by this Government and for some reason that could only be associated with a bias on behalf of the Opposition, it seems to believe that if there is some arrangement, some understanding and some agreement between the ACTU and a government that that is a very negative situation. Of course that is absurd.

There has to be an arrangement and an agreement between the peak organisations representing the workers' of government and of the employers. This Government makes no secret of the fact that it supports that particular approach. The reduction in the number of unions will substantially reduce the bureaucracy of the conciliation and arbitration processes and will allow industry based discussions between business and the unions to proceed on a much more efficient basis. Larger unions will be able to provide a better service for members without increasing membership dues. We will have a stronger hand in the bargaining processes and the bargaining processes can only succeed on the basis of a superior argument and evidence that will be produced either in private negotiations with the employer or through the conciliation and arbitration system.

Another change from the existing Act involves the efficient encouragement of workplace dispute settlement. Clauses 91 and 92 of the Bill recognise the positive role of the procedures in defining a process which can often resolve a dispute without the Commission's involvement. The Commission is to be seen as a last resort. We will still encourage the agreements between employers and employees and that is recognised by this Government. The great underlying philosophy of this Bill is that the Industrial Relations Commission should avoid involving itself in disputes where employers and employees can settle them themselves. Where the Commission does get involved it should be by way of conciliation rather than arbitration.

I find it somewhat strange, although I suppose one should not be surprised but nevertheless can be dismayed, that we see that the linchpin of the Opposition's attitude to industrial relations is to rely upon voluntary agreements between the employer who is in a much more superior position and the employees who are in a much more inferior position, particularly in the smaller establishments, in isolated areas, and in those areas and agencies where they are few in number and are disorganised. To rely on that process is quite inadequate in today's modern industrial world. It is a disgrace that employers insisted that the new compliance provisions, as included in the 1987 Bill, be dropped. At the centre of the employers' objections was that a common law injunction could no longer be sought, and that before an action around the secondary boycott provisions of the Trade Practices Act could be availed of there had to be a process of conciliation. Rather than accepting that there are legitimate reasons for industrial action by workers, the employer organisations fought strongly to keep open the avenue to the courts as a first resort.

If any process has had a negative and alienating effect on unions and dispute resolution in this country, it has been the rigid, complex, impersonal and strictly formalised process of the common law courts. One would hope that there will be some change in attitude because that is what finally must be recognised and applied when we deal with industrial relations. Despite all the employer objections about lack of sanctions, the original legislation had vested power in a labour court to issue directive and injunctive remedies and to impose penalties. Presumably employers felt that there was something to fear about that process. In my view and that of the Government a labour court would have greater expertise in industrial matters, and it seems to me that it would involve more than a contract in the relationship of employer to employee.

The Bill before us also contains provision for greater coordination between the Federal and State industrial tribunals. Senators are aware of the complex situation that exists with respect to responsibilities in this area, based on interpretations of section 51 (xxxv) of the Constitution. This Federal-State division has made the system of industrial relations much more bureaucratic and complex than it should be. Many of the requirements flowing from this division of responsibility in the Commonwealth and State industrial jurisdictions are absurd in that we see people perform the same functions but nevertheless have different awards and a different approach depending on their geographic position. The provisions of this Bill pave the way for the appointment of joint Federal and State commissioners and they formalise consultations between the States and the Commonwealth. Therefore, they are to be welcomed. These provisions allow for a streamlining of the tribunal process without exceeding the bounds of the industrial relations power.

I now wish to discuss some areas of the Bill which cause me concern. My concerns relate to long-term trends for the union movement. It is a matter of fact that the level of unionisation in Australia is on track for long-term decline. The explosion of anti-union employment practices such as casual work, outwork and contracting out and a sustained anti-union propaganda campaign over a number of years has led to a decline in the number of workers unionised in our country. For the first time in memory the officially recorded worker unionisation rate has fallen below 50 per cent; and among young workers it is even less and, in fact, I believe that it is about one-third. It seems that the conservative elements within our society have had some deal of success in spreading the myth of union power. If unions had real power, real wages would not have fallen year after year; unemployment would not stand as high as 7 per cent; investment would not be at such low levels; and the social wage aspects of the prices and incomes accord would be much nearer to fulfilment. I find it difficult therefore, when one is dealing with subjects as sensitive as this, that the Opposition brings forward matters of public importance on the decline in living standards. Of course, there has been some decline and that is acknowledged. However, it arises out of the arrangements and agreements that have been reached between the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

It is Liberal and National Party policy to criticise this Government when that process brings about a reduction in actual living standards. However, that is seen by government as an essential part of the process to reinvigorate Australian economy. Of course, if that had not occurred we would have a fairer society, albeit one that certain vested interests would prefer not to contemplate. As the ranks of organised labour thin out at this time, the fight for a better deal for workers falls on fewer and fewer shoulders. To that extent the trade union movement needs to have both human and financial resources and the strength that will come about as a result of union amalgamations. Many of the disputes that take place in the manufacturing sector of our economy arise because of the craft nature of our industrial development since the colony of Australia achieved some form of self-government more than 150 years ago.

It is essential that unions have the power to put a case before the industrial court if negotiations with employers are unsuccessful. The unions should have sufficient resources and strength to present their viewpoint and to represent workers, particularly those in the lower wage brackets.

The principle of wage productivity has long been a tenet of Australian industrial relations. No worker is happy or prepared to watch fellow workers bound ahead in the income stakes. There is no doubt that the very rationale behind the national wage case is to ensure a broad and even approach to wage fixation. That is why the Government supports the current processes, which serve the worker, the employer and the economy. Yet many workers are not prepared to take action to achieve some improvement in their living standards. Is it any wonder then that those workers who lose pay in order to fight for industrial gains feel betrayed and are often angered by fellow workers who refuse to act but who benefit equally through wage relativity? Of course, that is what the centralised wage system does. It provides a degree of uniformity for those who lack the understanding, the ability and the resources to act in concert with other workers who are better organised, better researched and better able to exert some strength in their consultations with the employer or through the industrial relations processes. These emotions of betrayal are felt not only in the work force.

I remind the Senate of my personal experience in the company that I worked for prior to becoming involved in World War II. There were something like 70 women working in a clothing industrial enterprise. In those days those young women were not members of a union. They sought to have annual leave recognised. Under my award I was able to have a fortnight's annual leave, but the employer was not prepared to grant female employees the right to have an annual holiday. So every Christmas eve the female employees were sacked and then re-employed on 2 or 3 January following a 10-day break. It was not until they were unionised when a Labor government came into office that a fortnight's annual leave became part of the award of that organisation. So one cannot rely purely on the voluntary arrangement between employees and the employer, and I refer to the period just following the Great Depression. What strength did those 70 women have against the employer who was not prepared to negotiate on the right of other employees to receive a benefit workers in my union received. So there is a need for workers to appreciate unity and cooperation because only through that process can they realise the objective of improving their living standards. Therefore, it is disappointing to see that the provisions regarding conscientious objection and protection of non-members' interests are still maintained.
