SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is about to debate the Government's Budget brought down last week. Already it seems semi-forgotten in the light of other events which have drawn greater attention. It is important that over the course of this session, with respect to both the Budget and the other opportunities that will be provided in the Appropriation Bills, the Senate focus on the economic situation of Australia and on the failure of the Government to come to grips with some important elements which do require attention in 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: There are three fundamental things that I want to say tonight about the Budget. The first is that it is a high risk Budget, that it sets a course which does not take into account the risks Australia faces, that it is a Budget which leaves Australia exposed in various circumstances, and I will expand on that a little later. The second thing, which probably does not need lengthy addressing because it is evident to every taxpayer, is that it is a high tax Budget. That is related to the high risk element because what is needed in Australia at the moment is not merely tax relief for personal reasons but tax relief in terms of encouraging people both to work and to invest. One of the serious deficiencies in this Budget is that it continues a succession of high taxing Budgets. It continues a record level of taxation in this country, and that is not in Australia's current interest.

The third matter I wish to raise with respect to the Budget is that it is socially unfair. It is possible for the Government to point to measures in the Budget which go to the relief of poverty and hardship. The Opposition in no way joins issue with or complains about those relatively small changes that have been made which will give assistance to some less fortunate Australians. What is socially unfair about this Budget is that it provides absolutely no fairness or justice for middle Australia. In particular, it provides no fairness or justice for those Australians on moderate incomes who meet their responsibilities and who are looking after dependants. Later in my speech I will address that matter in more detail.

At this stage I simply wish to say that we have heard a lot of talk in this country about the terms of trade. We have heard a lot of talk about the fact that the terms of trade moved against Australia in 1985 and 1986. We have heard much less talk from the Government about the terms of trade moving back in favour of Australia in 1987 and 1988. The fundamental thing that can be said about the position of Australian families under this Government is that the terms of trade have certainly moved against the family. The conditions of families have deteriorated under this Government because the tax system has moved against those who meet their responsibilities to their dependants.

With respect to the risk element, if I may return to the first point, let me remind the Senate that in 1986 the Treasurer (Mr Keating) told us that we were at risk of becoming a banana republic. He was moved to that comment I believe because of the balance of payments crisis which Australia faced at that time. There were various other indicators that things were seriously wrong but, fundamentally, Australians were deeply concerned because month by month we saw incredibly bad trade figures and month by month those figures caused the dollar to decline. In 1986 there was a deep understanding in the Australian community that the economy was in significant difficulties.

We have had a great deal of self-congratulation from the Treasurer over the last few months, and indeed from all of the Ministers and supporters of this Government. Yet if one looks at the fundamentals and at the continuing deficit on our balance of payments, which the Government predicts might be something in the order of $10 billion this year, one sees that the improvement relates not to improvements in the volume of goods and services we are selling when compared with what we import but to the improvements in the terms of trade Mr Keating was so keen to talk about until they improved and went in Australia's favour. The improvement in our balance of payments situation is not an improvement that can be sheeted home to improvements in our fundamental situation. It relates to improvements in the prices we are getting for what we sell abroad. That is fortuitous from Australia's point of view. It has to do with the condition of the world economy and the demand for what we produce. It is totally beyond Australia's control. To have a steady as you go Budget, a take it easy on reform Budget, which this Budget certainly is, in those circumstances is extremely foolish and is playing games with Australia's future.

It is important to note that last year the physical volume of goods and services we exported deteriorated against our imports. That is why within days of the Budget we received a report from the Reserve Bank of Australia which made it quite clear that we remain in a situation of risk. The report makes it clear that there are some hopeful signs in the outlook, but let me quote a couple of passages. The Reserve Bank said:
The higher prices-
I interpolate that that is the higher prices we are getting for our commodities-

should be regarded as a windfall which provides the opportunity to reduce markedly the balance of payments deficit. It would be tragic if they were absorbed in an overly rapid increase in domestic demand, with the pressures that would unleash, or if we were deflected from the long-term task of adjusting the structure of the economy.

Again I interpolate that the first leg of my criticism of this Budget squarely lies within those words I have just quoted. The Government has been deflected from the long term task of adjusting the structure of the economy. A little later in the report the Reserve Bank stated:
. . . it is disappointing in that context that Australia's high economic growth in the year just closed largely reflected strong domestic demand with no further gains in volume terms in net exports.

Again, this is a vital point. We have a situation where our net exports position has not improved. The gain simply lies in the improvement in the prices we are getting for our commodities. Finally, the Reserve Bank said:

International competitiveness is vital. For this, further reductions in the rate of price increases, to levels more consistent with those of our competitors and trading partners, are essential. Whilst the link between prices and wages is well recognised, greater productivity offers opportunities for both real wage increases and lower costs.

It is quite clear that the working men and women want real wage increases. Indeed, we would say they are entitled to real wage increases. But those real wage increases cannot be delivered by a Budget or by some stroke of the pen of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Real wage increases can come only if there is an increase in productivity, as the Reserve Bank observes and in this Budget, of course, we find recorded the fact that productivity in this country is stagnant. The reality is that, year by year, our productivity is simply not rising in a way that enables us to solve these fundamental problems. The latest figures from the Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development (OECD) show Australian productivity is rising at about half the rate of the OECD countries.

For the Opposition there is something of a dilemma in criticising the Budget on these terms because it can be said that one is being pessimistic and looking for reasons for gloom. Yet if we go back to last Friday, a matter of a few days after the Budget is delivered, we hear the British Chancellor of the Exchequer on Australian radio recording yet another rise in British interest rates because of a great blow-out in the balance of payments deficit. On the very same day we find that Paul Keating has done it again-he is the fastest working Treasurer Australia has ever known. On Friday we find that he has managed to get two months of our annual deficit crammed into one month. In other words, in July the deficit figure announced by the Australian Bureau of Statistics was about twice as high as the monthly average that we require if we are to meet the Budget prediction.

The response from the Government has been careful. After all, it is one month's figures, although if we look at the last six months' figures a disturbingly high pattern appears to be emerging. Senator Walsh, who is said to have expressed concern before the Budget about the terms of trade forecast in the Papers, has said that he is shocked by the $1.7 billion trade deficit for July. He described the nation's foreign debt and current account deficit as the pall that hangs over the Australian economy.

It was a matter of days before we had at least some warning signs about the variability of the international economy with rising interest rates in the United Kingdom and the United States, and the fragility of our own situation, with a lowered volume of exports compared with imports and a $1.7 billion deficit on our current account in month one.

What ought this Budget be trying to achieve if we want long term solutions? The Government should be going for reduced inflation. It should be watching the link between prices and wages and the risk for Australia that the Government has now embraced-a wage fixing arrangement which will deliver wage rises and, of course, inflation twice as high as those of our trading partners. They are the sober realities that this Budget is delivering to the Australian people. The Government should be concentrating on greater productivity. There is little or nothing in this Budget which goes to that end.

In the view of the Opposition these should be the key areas for the Government's attention. If we are to meet the social requirements of the Australian people, if we are to stop the squeeze on people's incomes from rising taxes and inflation, we have to do something about this issue of productivity. The Government must give it attention. What we said about the Budget in 1986, the year of the banana republic, still applies. I have noticed in the Senate an increasing tendency for honourable senators to quote their own speeches. I have found it so engaging that I am going to quote one of my own, my response to the Budget Speech in 1986. I said:

Clearly, what has to be done, what is needed at the moment, is that we have to overcome our fundamental problem of buying more than we can sell. That really is the basic problem that Australia has . . . So the questions have to be posed: What can the Government do about that, what can we do about that and how do we reverse that situation? We have no choice but to produce our way out of our difficulties, to produce more and to produce more efficiently. This Budget does nothing to achieve that.

In the two years since I said that, Australia has had an appalling lack of productivity improvement. Again that is a mark of failure and a mark of why we still have fundamental problems. Instead, the Government has taken fright at its election losses. This Government has now suffered a series of debilitating losses at by-elections. We have seen losses in South Australia. We have seen losses in Queensland. We saw the loss of the New South Wales State Government election. We saw massive swings away from Labor in my State of Western Australia. The lack of action on the part of the Government can, I think, be attributed to its loss of nerve. It has adopted the approach that it can gamble on taxing rather than axing, that is, by increasing taxes instead of reducing government expenditure. It is gambling that it can hold back tax cuts to the pre-election Budget next year. It has failed to do what it could have done, which was to arrange a wage tax trade-off this year.

That last point is of deep concern to the Australian people. There is an enormous pressure for increased wages in this country. That pressure flows quite naturally from the reduced living standards of those people who are paying a higher proportion of their income in tax-I will come to those figures shortly-and the very high rates of inflation in this country. Under those circumstances it is not surprising that the people of Australia are demanding wage increases. What the Government has done, however, is, for its own electoral advantage, put off tax relief, put off any idea of a wage-tax trade-off-in other words, offering people more money in their pockets by reduced taxes instead of increased wages-because it wants to give some of that tax money back just before the election. In the view of the Opposition, that is economically unsound and certainly totally irresponsible.

The Government says that it would have been economically unsound to give tax reductions this year because it would have increased consumption and forced up imports. That is the sort of economic argument the Government is using-that it would be irresponsible to give tax cuts now. Yet, at the same time, it is, by allowing taxes to remain as high as they are, fostering a situation where wage rises in this country will be anywhere between 6 1/2 per cent and 8 per cent, perhaps even 9 per cent. In those circumstances the Government is losing a great deal economically, in terms of both increased inflation and increased demand until inflation catches up with those money wage increases. To argue that it would be irresponsible to negotiate a lower level of wage rises in return for a tax trade-off is obviously absurd. The Government is allowing workers to get hold of extra money which will be destructive in two ways. It will be destructive because it will be inflationary as far as workers' purchases are concerned and it will be destructive because it will reduce our international competitiveness. What is happening-it needs to be said over and over again-is that earnings in our competitor countries are growing half as fast as those in Australia, yet the workers in our competitor countries are better off because they are getting real wage rises, and not the fictitious wage rises that are delivered in inflation-ridden Australia.

The area which has been most substantially omitted from the Government's reform program is the labour market. I have already touched on the issue of wages. It is important to remember that just a few months ago Mr Keating was saying that what was fundamentally required was labour market reform. He described it on 26 May as the last great area of change to be overcome. He said that the policy objective was to create a flexible industrial relations system in which wages and conditions reflected the different levels of prosperity of different industries. That was targeted by the Treasurer, on the day of Mr Howard's response to the May mini-Budget, as the critical area for reform.

What we have in this Budget is virtually no reference to that critical area of reform, an anodyne booklet issued by Mr Willis, the Minister for Industrial Relations, and an embracing by the Government of a continuation of a system which is simply not delivering the sort of flexibility that the Treasurer says we need. We will be debating this in much more detail in the debate on the Industrial Relations Bill, which is currently before the Senate. The simple illustration of the lack of consistency on the part of the Government with respect to that is the fact that that Bill specifically provides that as far as possible wages and conditions should be uniform across an industry. In other words, specific provisions in that Bill go against the flexibility which is required.

We believe that the changes which are currently occurring in the wage fixing system, if anything, have been a step backwards. The second tier wage negotiations last year at least required people to focus within the work place on productivity improvements to pay for wage rises. But now the Commission has moved to requiring no more than an argeement for people simply to look at award restructuring. Certainly the Commission is doing its best to focus people's attention on the need to find more efficient ways to work.

If we look at the first agreement that has been approved by the Arbitration Commission we find the union saying, `There is no agreement set in place, there is no trade-off. We agreed to take a genuine look at the prospects for improvements in the industry and to sit down with employers'. Specifically the representative of the Australian Glass Workers Union said, `There has to be no agreement set in place, there is no trade-off'. In other words, wage rises are flowing through now without any requirement that there be any offsetting improvement in the efficiency of the firms involved. That is in stark contrast to what the Commission sought to achieve last year in the second tier wage negotiations. It is going to require a herculean effort by employers to ensure that these negotiations do take place and that there are some productivity gains. The reality is that the system which is now in place has little guarantee of change-indeed, no guarantee of change-in this vital area of how we work more efficiently.

In the Budget Papers we find the comment, `There are many such mullock heaps on the Australian landscape which could produce rich rewards from a careful combing'. The mullock heaps that the Budget Papers are referring to are the restrictive work practices which bedevil Australian industry. The Government's Budget Papers acknowledge that we have heaps of inefficiencies which currently are not being tackled. The sad reality about the industrial relations system, which is receiving the full support of this Government and is being amended in a way which will make it even more centralised is, as I pointed out the other day in the debate on the industrial relations legislation, that it actually stops people working together efficiently. There are circumstances of the sort I outlined in your State of Queensland, Madam Acting Deputy President, where agreements between an employer and employees on more efficient ways of working were obstructed by the Commission and the employer was told that he could not talk to his employees directly; that he had to involve the trade union. It is the implementation or maintenance of that sort of inefficiency in our economy that lies at the heart of the failure of this Budget.

The other areas which go to making the economy more efficient and go to our capacity to respond to the world situation when the terms of trade turn against us, as inevitably they will at some time, areas in which we could increase efficiency to enable us to give Australians better working conditions, higher wages and improved standards of living, are privatisation and those areas of the economy where there is little or no competition. Again, this is not the time to make a speech about privatisation, but I remind honourable senators of how, after the 1987 election, Ministers from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) down were acknowledging that privatisation provided an avenue for real efficiency gains in the economy.

We know that purely for ideological reasons, the ambitions and efforts of Ministers such as the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) to see some effective privatisation to enable greater competitiveness and greater efficiency in the economy and a greater capacity to improve the living standards of Australians, have been thwarted. There is no mention in this Budget of the means which could be adopted by the Government to get greater efficiency in many areas of the economy. Indeed, we have seen from this Government clear evidence that in terms of protecting vested trade union interests, it is prepared to attack even proposals for reform.

Let us look at Senator Ray's response to the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) report on coastal shipping-that is a classic area of the economy. The Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), who is at the table, is from Tasmania, a State which is dependent upon coastal shipping as its lifeline. He, more than anyone, should know of the gross inefficiencies of Australian coastal shipping, identified by the IAC as costing Australian consumers hundreds of millions of dollars a year-a classic case of Australian inefficiency in circumstances where there is featherbedding which flows from undue protection from competition. The response from the Minister was to put the report down. It was not to say, `Here is an area were we can set about improving the living standards of Australians and the efficiency of the economy'. Instead, he protected the vested interests which had been protected for so long, instead of protecting the public interest and the interests of consumers. Let me now turn to what this Budget really means for the people of Australia, people who, in increasing numbers, are no longer voting for this Government. Let me explain the attitudes which are arising because of the figures I am about to give, figures affecting the position of families in this country. A few months ago there was a State Parliament by-election in the seat of Balga in Western Australia, a seat which had been held by Premier Burke-a classic Labor seat with an enormous Australian Labor Party majority. It is an electorate consisting almost totally of State housing commission areas-Homeswest areas-with a great number of welfare people and a great number of people working on relatively modest incomes.

The matters I want to talk about affect the sorts of decent, hard-working, honest Australians who are trying to meet their obligations and bring up their families under the circumstances imposed on them by the present Government. I was talking to a fellow handing out Liberal Party how to vote cards. He told me that he had been a Labor supporter. He explained to me why he was handing out Liberal how to vote cards and why he was no longer a Labor supporter. He explained that he could not pay his bills. He said, `I have to try to find part time work because I can no longer pay my bills with the pay I get from my job'. The swing against Labor in that seat was 23 per cent. I do not know whether that is a record but it says very clearly how those people feel about the treatment that has been meted out to them. I put it in those terms because I sometimes think that this Government will listen only if the matter is put in those terms.

Let me now put the problem in more general terms. The simple reality, when we look at the situation of an average earner with a dependent spouse, is that when the Fraser Government lost office, the average earner was paying an average tax rate of 17 and a bit cents-somewhere around 17 1/2c in each dollar of income.

TALK.START.PARA: —If they were working. How many were unemployed?

—I do not mind interjections from the honourable senator from Western Australia because he is one of the people who have led the Labor Party down the path of deserting its constituency. If he is proud of it, that is fine, and I do not mind his interjecting. Let him identify himself. But the truth is that in that short period of Labor rule from 1983 to 1988, the average tax rate has gone from about 17 1/2c in the dollar to something over 22, nearly 23, cents in the dollar-and it is continuing to rise. Those people have been told that they cannot have tax relief-although business got a 10c reduction in tax from 1 July-for another 12 months. The increase in pay as you earn tax under this Government is 13.8 per cent, or something just under 14 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The total increase in taxation caused by no more than fiscal drag, the amount that people's taxes have gone up because of inflation since the Government last gave a tax cut, will be $10 billion by the time of the next Budget. In other words by the next Budget, which is the Budget until which this Government has postponed tax relief, it will have taken another $10 billion from the working men and women of Australia, purely through the inflationary rises in their wages. That rise gives them nothing in terms of increased living standards and is taken as a higher proportion of their wages. That is the reality facing people.

What has this Government done about this matter? It has provided further assistance for families on the bottom quarter or so of the income scale. I welcome that. But it has done nothing in the last five Budgets for the 75 per cent of working families-nothing. So we have a record of five years of neglect which has seen, as I said before, the terms of trade move against families with dependants. Let me give some specific examples. We tend to think of people on low incomes as the sorts of people who are getting assistance from the Government's family assistance supplement. Let us look at the people referred to in the weekend edition of the Catholic Leader. They are what we would call middle income, even higher than middle income, earners who are feeling the squeeze drastically under this Government. A senior technical officer with Telecom Australia is getting something around $600 a week. That is a little over $30,000 a year. He is paid monthly. He said: `In the last week of every month we wonder if we are going to make it through. We are penalised because we choose to have my wife at home caring for our family'. A draftsman with a consulting engineers firm is supporting a wife and three children on about $500 a week and is barely surviving.

These people talk of the need for tax relief because they cannot pay their bills. They are finding that their lives are very difficult. Yet these are the people who have seen their family allowance, which was to give them some relief from their taxation burden, reduced by over 40 per cent in value under the Hawke Government. I suppose that these people are the `fatbacks', the people who are not worthy of consideration by a Labor government. These people, in my view, represent the heartland of this country.

I am not suggesting that those who are poor, unemployed and on very low incomes should not get assistance. As a Minister in the Fraser Government I introduced the family income supplement which forms the basis of the Government's family assistance arrangements. We are not arguing about that. What we are saying is that there are hundreds of thousands of decent Australian families on modest incomes who have been squeezed more and more under the policies of this Government. That is a disgrace. The fact that they are being kept waiting for tax relief for another 12 months-for 12 months after this Government was able to reduce the company tax rate from 49c to 39c in the dollar-tells one something about the changes in this Labor Government.

I believe that it is absolutely true that having a sound economy is the fundamental contribution that government must make in its caring for the Australian people. I agree with Senator McKiernan's interjection that the Government is entitled to express its satisfaction and to say that the welfare of many Australian families has been improved by the growth in employment under this Government. I think that is a legitimate and appropriate point to make. But the truth also is that this Government's priorities have become political, and the political priorities of this Government have overtaken its duty and obligations to middle Australians. The fact is that those middle Australians are among those who are demanding wage increases of their unions. Who can blame them? It is within the capacity of this Government, this year instead of next year, to do a wage-tax deal which would give those people financial relief without adding to the nation's costs, without adding to inflation. Suggesting that that would be economically responsible demonstrates that the Government is not prepared to do its sums in a global fashion.

The cynicism of Paul Keating, the cynicism of Bob Hawke, the cynicism of all of those senators opposite who have supported this approach to those middle Australians must be exposed and talked about. It will bring the electoral contempt that was shown for the Australian Labor Party in that Balga by-election, when people from Labor's heartland changed their vote-many after a lifetime of commitment-because they saw that they had been treated with absolute cynicism.

I find it offensive that matters relating to family justice are regarded as welfare matters. The health of Australian families is not a welfare matter; it is a matter of common sense and a matter of seeing that there is some justice. I am sick of the proposition that anyone who is earning a decent salary is well off. I remind the Senate that there are enormous discrepancies in the disposable incomes of individual Australians, not just according to their incomes but according to the degree of family responsibilities that they maintain.

TALK.START.PARA: —The bachelors are well off.

—I acknowledge the interjection from Senator Harradine that bachelors are well off; so are many single people. But let me not put that in general terms. I remind the Senate of the research by the Australian Institute of Family Studies which shows that a one-income family with two children requires an income of approximately $42,900 in order to have the same disposable income as a single male on average yearly earnings of $24,000. The same study shows that a family with a dependent spouse and three children requires an income of $51,000 to have the same disposable income as a solitary earner with no dependants on average weekly earnings. Yet this Government has taken away the entitlement of many of those families to family allowance, on the basis that they are well off. The Government is denying tax justice to those families. It is not denying them welfare; it is denying them tax justice.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Senate that in our approach to the people of Australia at the last election, as was the case in the previous election, our tax policy contained specific concessions aimed at those families with dependants. The matter has been raised in the Senate before, I raise it again, and I stress it in this Senate debate because I think the Labor Party has forgotten the reality of Australia. The revulsion which people feel about the association of senior Labor politicians with wealthy businessmen is not because Australians do not understand that it is important to have close understanding and rapport between business and the government of the day. Of course there must be communication. But this Government, by its actions, has demonstrated that it has remembered business and forgotten its constituency. I find that revolting, and I object to it. I believe that if this Government had any spark of decency it would not have framed the Budget in the way that it has.

I return to the economics of the Budget. Our concern is that it will do virtually nothing to improve productivity, competitiveness or our ability to stand independently in a rapidly changing world. From an individual's point of view, the bottom line is that it offers little opportunity for sustainable increases in living standards. The Government is taxing more; it is encouraging a welfare mentality; it is ignoring real reform in the labour market; it is sweeping privatisation under the carpet; it is steering a course around strong, privileged union interests; and it is undermining the process of individual enterprise and improvement.

I think it goes without saying that the Government must be praying for a stable world outlook because it is doing nothing to ensure that we can respond to sudden adverse conditions. It has implicitly acknowledged this by admitting that if things go wrong, monetary policy-that is, higher interest rates for the men and women of Australia-will be used immediately. In other words, other major policy instruments, fiscal and wages policy, will not be flexible enough to cope. All I can say is that we have not come very far since the 1985 depreciation.

The Opposition's approach combines economic responsibility with the opportunity for higher living standards by freeing up those elements of the economy which can and would produce more. It combines greater individual freedom and responsibility with greater rewards and choice. The only solution that we have to our ongoing economic problems is to be more productive and to earn more. There is no magic solution to be given by government, but hope for the future could be offered in a Budget. The Government's strategy is about balancing the books by draining the most productive elements of the economy. I believe that, socially and economically, it is a dead end.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can recall back in 1981-82, when this process was being undertaken in the old Parliament House, listening to speeches somewhat similar to the one made by Senator Chaney just now, delivered instead by people like Senator Don Grimes and Senator Walsh and directed then at Government Ministers such as Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle and Senator Chaney himself. We heard complaints in 1981-82 that the then Liberal Government was paying far too much attention to the demands of big business and far too little to the needs of Australian families and to the plight in which the Australian taxpayer was finding himself or herself. The Budget that we are discussing tonight is the last in a long line of Labor Government Budgets that indicates quite clearly that there are two classes of groups in Australia-businesses and families. There are two classes of people in Australia, if this Budget package is any indication-business people and ordinary Australians. One is favoured by the tax system under this Government; one is not. The favoured group and the favoured people are businesses and those who run them, in particular big businesses and those who run them. There is little joy in this Budget, as in previous Budgets, for the owners of small businesses. The less favoured group is the Australian family and the less favoured people are ordinary wage and salary earners. Anyone with any doubt about this need only look at the Government's priorities in this Budget, as with previous Budgets, to see just to what extent ordinary Australians are suffering from the damage done to our economy by some big businesses as the Government uses the surpluses to pay off the foreign debt run up, in the main, by those big businesses.

SPEECH.PARA: This Budget does nothing for families, for ordinary Australians, or for small business. It does nothing to stop the foreign debt increasing while, at the same time, we see the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Government patting themselves on the back because they are able to use the tax paid by average weekly income earners to pay off that debt. This Budget is for big business, for banks, both foreign and domestic, and for beer drinkers. It does nothing to increase the disposable income of women and their families and it does nothing to increase their standard of living. It is a Budget that sounds good on the surface; certainly it has pleased the Treasurer and, I presume, the rest of his front bench-or rather the front bench of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), if we are to believe that he is still in control of that front bench.

Underneath the rhetoric of the Treasurer, this Budget is a con trick. The top rate of business tax was dropped a few months ago to 39c in the dollar. This was done despite the fact that when the top tax rate for business was 49c in the dollar the average tax paid by the top 200 companies in Australia was a mere 28c in the dollar. Despite that, the Government felt able to drop the top business rate-the only business rate-from 49c to 39c. Indeed, almost at the same time that the Treasurer was announcing that the country could not afford to drop the marginal tax rate for individuals, Alan Bond was announcing that his company had posted a profit of nearly $400m on which $4m would be paid in tax-a tax rate of one per cent, a little over 1c in the dollar, to be paid on a profit of almost $400m-and this when most individuals and families in this country are paying, on average, at least 20 times that amount. What is worse, those families will be hit hard as far as household expenditure is concerned. We discover in Budget Paper No. 1, the section devoted to wholesale sales tax, that the Government's priorities with regard to the income tax structure are repeated. Under the heading `Anomalies and Inconsistencies' the Government has applied the following:
Tax at 20% goods of a kind used to wrap up or secure goods for marketing or delivery . . . and wrapping materials marketed for household use . . .

So we are seeing the ordinary cling wrap, or Gladwrap, that most women use to preserve food to make it go a little further, taxed at 20 per cent. Also taxed at 20 per cent are prepackaged coffee, chocolate and malt flavoured milk drinks with less than 95 per cent milk content. Bad luck about the fact that these are sometimes used by mothers to encourage recalcitrant children to drink the milk that we are told is so good for them. Taxed at 10 per cent are containers used by retailers in marketing biscuits, snack foods and ice creams made on their premises, containers used by retailers in marketing take- away food or beverages, muesli bars and similar health food bars, thick shake mixes and those ice cream mixes previously exempt.

The disposable income of most families will be cut back considerably by these sorts of additional taxes. The woman who runs the household budget, whether she stays at home or whether she is working as well, will find it increasingly difficult to make ends meet, because I can pretty much guarantee that the cut in the cost of beer for her husband will not be passed on to her in additional disposable income. Instead, the cost of everything from Gladwrap to the kids' takeaway treat each week will be increased. Mind you, at the same time there were some sales tax reductions and I think we need to acknowledge those. But again, they apply not to those people in need or to Australian families but to Australian business. So we now find that all aircraft, except gliders, are sales tax exempt. Food we tax, wheelchairs we tax; private aeroplanes we do not tax. What an extraordinary set of priorities!

TALK.START.PARA: —Put wings on wheelchairs.

—One of my colleagues has suggested that we should put wings on wheelchairs. Maybe that is the only way we will get the sales tax removed from that item. Year after year my colleague from Queensland, Senator Michael Macklin, has been attempting to amend the sales tax exemptions and classifications legislation to have the sales tax dropped from wheelchairs. What do we see in the 1988-89 Budget? A government that finds itself ideologically and financially capable of removing the sales tax from private planes but not able to remove the sales tax from something as basic to the needs of a disabled person as a wheelchair.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as low income families and the needy generally are concerned, I think the Press release that was put out by the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission probably says it all. In the letter that accompanied the Press release the National Director, Reverend Caldwell, said:

While the Commission is very much in favour of the Government's policy to help the most needy through the Family Allowance Supplement, it is concerned that this assistance goes to less than 10% of families.
Reverend Caldwell expanded on this in the Press release:

Unfortunately, Family Allowance Supplement goes to less than 10 per cent of families, some 140,000 out of 2 million, and tends to discourage self-sufficiency by those families because it is income-tested.
Reverend Caldwell went on:
The Federal Government's Budget does not return to most families what has been taken from them since 1983 and earlier.

I think that point is worth stressing. A lot of what has apparently been returned by way of largess to low income families in this Budget is nothing more than a partial recoupment of assistance that was taken away from them in previous Budgets-taken away from them, I might add, with the cooperation of the Liberal and National parties, which refused to amend or oppose any of those pieces of legislation that hit hard at widows, at children, at supporting parents and at 15-year-olds in their last two years of school. The Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission's Press release goes on to point out:
Families are being discriminated against in the tax system, because tax allowances for expenses for dependants have been abolished or eroded by inflation.

Yet tax deductions that encourage our businesses to play monopoly with companies inside Australia and increase our foreign debt by negative gearing continue to exist. As a result, our gross foreign debt-that is, the amount that our various governments, public enterprises and the private sector have borrowed from overseas-has risen from $6 billion in 1975 to $67 billion in 1985 and was $115 billion at the end of the last financial year.

To keep the banks lending to us, the Government pursues an economic strategy that maintains the bankers' confidence. Bankers would like to see Australia increasing its foreign currency earnings through increased exports-and would not we all! If that happened we could stop borrowing to pay for previous borrowings. However, this Government has been either unable or unwilling to achieve a substantial increase in exports or a reduction in imports. It has done very little to encourage the manufacturing sector to increase its export potential or its import replacement potential. It will not be able to encourage the manufacturing sector to do that while it continues to cut assistance to export industries. If we look again at Budget Paper No. 1, we find that there has been a significant cut, a little over 3 per cent, amounting to almost $70m, in industry assistance and development outlays. The Treasurer admits to this quite cheerfully saying that apart from the outlays he mentioned earlier in the section headed `Industry Assistance in Development' `considerable assistance is also provided to industry through special provisions in the taxation system which, as they result in a reduction of Government revenues, are as much a call on the Budget as are outlays'. He then goes on to say:
Outlays on industry assistance and development are expected to decrease by $69.5m or 3.2% in 1988-89.

That is a great way of encouraging and assisting Australian-based industries to get their act together sufficiently to increase our export markets and to come up with import replacement items that will assist our balance of trade figures. Instead of doing all this the Government has elected to attempt to placate bankers by reducing expenditure in areas such as welfare-and, like Senator Chaney, I resent the fact that money paid to Australian families is regarded as welfare-by reducing wages in real terms, by deregulating the financial system and by producing big Budget surpluses. In doing so it has forced average and low income Australians to bear the brunt of reducing our foreign debt. It has done all of those things under pressure from a big business sector, including the big banks and the rest of the financial sector that, as I said earlier, are contributing far less than ordinary wage and salary earners to Consolidated Revenue. Fiscal drag, bracket creep, or whatever else anybody wants to call it, has meant that ordinary Australians and their families have contributed to the surplus through an unfair tax system and a reduction in their real disposal income.

If we analyse the composition of our foreign debt we can see an alternative course of action if the Government is prepared to take it. Currently, 54 per cent of our foreign debt is due to private sector borrowing. While I accept that that is down from the 66 per cent that it was a couple of years ago, we still need to acknowledge that the majority of our foreign debt is being run up not by governments or the public sector but by the private sector. Foreign borrowing is one way in which the largest private companies can reduce their tax liabilities to as little as the one per cent that the Bond Corporation will pay this year. Had Mr Keating chosen to disallow the practice of Australian companies borrowing overseas and then claiming the cost of borrowing as a tax deduction, he could have reduced Australia's level of foreign debt and increased tax revenue from companies such as Bond Corporation and Elders IXL Ltd which paid last year, I think, around 10.6c in the dollar in tax. A great deal of our foreign debt is tax driven.

The rationale for allowing negative gearing is certainly, at least in part, to encourage efficiency, to encourage expansion, hence to encourage employment, job opportunities, and so on. But it is no longer justified. Most of the borrowings are undertaken simply in order to give the business doing the borrowing a tax break. It has very little to do with generating new investment or increasing production, yet the Government lets this private foreign debt accumulate and then uses it as an excuse to reduce the living standards of average and low income Australians. This has put the Hawke Government in something of a predicament because this sort of foreign debt is not regarded as acceptable by the very bankers who do the lending. So the Government is now so desperate for foreign currency that it has reduced the controls on foreign investment in Australia. The result is that foreign investment here has almost doubled in the last 12 months from $9.8 billion in 1985-86 to $19.5 billion in 1986-87.

The Foreign Investment Review Board has suffered staff cuts, and the Government is exempting more and more transactions from their surveillance. To all intents and purposes the Foreign Investment Review Board is now a foreign investment approval board. It seems to do very little knocking back of requests. Unfortunately, nobody is really aware of what the level of foreign investment is and, until we get a national register of foreign ownership, Australians will not be able to know what proportion of the total value of Australian land, social infrastructure, factories and residential development is owned outright, in part, or through exotic financing mechanisms by foreign residents. It seems that with our massive foreign debt, accumulated by the borrowings of private corporations, the Government is prepared to do anything to bring foreign currency into Australia. In effect, it is replacing our foreign debt problem with a foreign ownership problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is selling the farm.

—Yes. In fact, it is selling more than the farm; it is selling our central business district and anything else that people are prepared to buy. For the moment, the foreign currency value of increasing levels of foreign investment can be used to service the foreign debt; a foreign debt, I remind honourable senators, that would not be there if negative gearing were not allowed to run rampant. But how will we meet the foreign payments when rent, profits and dividends will need to be paid overseas to those who are currently investing in Australia? The economic rationalists who dominate the Labor Party-to say nothing of the Liberal and National parties and the big business community-are not concerned about this issue. If they are they are hiding their concern particularly well. But all Australians eventually will be. They must be concerned if they are not already concerned about the level of foreign investment in Australia through this sort of purchasing of everything that is not tied down or even a lot of things that are.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a lot for the Australian community to be concerned about in this Budget; not just the disparity between business tax levels and its contribution to Consolidated Revenue and that applying to Australian individuals and families. The community will live to regret very much the Government's proposal to tax or to apply fees to tertiary students. I hope that the Opposition parties will acknowledge that because this proposal has stemmed from the Wran Green Paper-ultimately refined, if we could call it that, by the Dawkins White Paper-it is no longer a Budget measure and deserves to be defeated. I appeal to honourable senators opposite not to hide under the Budget measure tag that they have hidden under when it has come to depriving Australian families of other benefits in the last few years. Let us make no mistake about it: if Australia wants to become a Third World country by the year 2010, hitting our university and tertiary education students in the way that this Government proposes to do is the fastest way of going about it. Yet again the Government has succumbed to pressure from the big business community, and in the way that it has attacked health care expenditure, welfare expenditure and education in other areas it is now attacking the tertiary sector. Certainly the tuition tax or the tertiary tax-because it is not a graduate tax, but will apply to anybody who undertakes any studies at tertiary institutions, whether or not he or she graduates as a consequence-may make some sense to an economic rationalist who believes in the user pays principle, but it can only be justified if the user is properly defined. In fact, the user is not the student. The user is the community at large, and business and industry in particular. I find extremely offensive the Treasurer's Budget statement that:
All taxpayers fund the education of a minority who, by virtue of their qualifications, enjoy a higher income throughout their working life.

What Mr Keating has carefully ignored is the fact that graduates have in the main given up three to six years of income in the process of getting that degree, and that it will take them a long time indeed in their working lives to make up that difference. It also ignores the fact that, as those graduates move into higher income brackets, they pay back through the progressive tax system the benefits that have accrued to them through their education. Indeed, an Australian National University study showed that the Federal Government actually makes a $13,000 profit on average from each higher education graduate.

It is absurd to say that students are the users. It is absurd to argue that most taxpayers neither use nor directly benefit from higher education. If a taxpayer does not use a doctor or dentist or lawyer, if a taxpayer does not ride in a car, does not use the sewerage system, drink water from the tap, watch television, use a computer or wear clothes, presumably that taxpayer, and only that taxpayer, could claim that he or she does not directly benefit from higher education. All those areas are assisted by the qualifications that individuals gain at some tertiary institution.

I issue a warning now that this is only the first step in a return to full fee-paying, regardless of whether the Liberal Party or the Labor Party wins the next election. It does not take a giant intellect to work out that at the next Budget there will no longer be a discount applied to the up-front fee payment. In the Budget after that the tax option will no longer be an option if family income is say, $25,000 a year or more. In the Budget after that, the fee component that has to be repaid will have doubled, and within five years there will be a return to the full fee paying system that applied prior to the election of the Whitlam Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Inevitably.

—As Senator McLean says, inevitably this will spill over into apprenticeships, technical and further education colleges and other areas. Sooner or later this ideology will be used to argue that those people who obtain unemployment benefits should pay them back through an additional tax after they obtain employment. It will be argued that those women who receive widows' pensions should pay them back if they remarry, that the sick should pay back invalid pensions if they get healthy again, that single parents should pay back the supporting parent benefit if they find another spouse. It makes a nonsense of what is known laughingly in this country as the progressive taxation system.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I turn to one of the areas that the Treasurer waved gaily under our noses last Tuesday night-the issue of child care. In his speech the Treasurer said:
. . . the vastly improved budgetary position-
a budgetary position, I remind honourable senators, which is only vastly improved because of fiscal drag-
has enabled the Government to embark on three major programs to enhance health and community services.
The first will expand by 30,000 the number of child care places over the next four years-
that is, 7,500 new places per year. I remind honourable senators that we have heard those sorts of promises from this Government before. The Treasurer continued:
Two-thirds of these places will be for care which extends outside school hours, particularly helping working parents.

It is useful to look at more precise details. That sounds fine, assuming one believes that it is any more likely to happen than under previous promises. The following statement is to be found on page 167 of Budget Paper No. 1:

The Government has decided to further expand the Children's Services Program by the provision of an additional 30,000 places over the next 4 years made up of 4,000 centre-based places, 4,000 family day care places-
a scheme which encourages one group of women to exploit another group of women because the hourly rates paid for family day care are appalling-low-

2,000 occasional care places and 20,000 outside school hours care places. Of the 4,000 centre-based places, 1,000 have been assigned for a new initiative with industry aimed at the expansion of child care provided by employers for low income employees.

In other words, 1,000 of the new 4,000 child care places per year will be assigned for industry involvement. Yet business-in particular big business because it will be hardly likely to apply to small business-has already indicated that it is not interested in partaking in this scheme. Indeed, big business is about as interested in making access to the work force easier for women as is the Government.

There is nothing in this Budget to give joy to low income families. There is nothing in this Budget to give joy to women, either those who are at home caring for children and managing a budget, or those who are in the paid work force and who probably also are devoting much of their time at home to caring for children and to balancing the budget. There is nothing in this Budget to assist ordinary Australian taxpayers and their families. I repeat that it is a Budget for big business, for banks, both foreign and domestic, and for beer drinkers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Haines at least closed on a cheerful note compared to most of the rest of her speech. I do not want to follow Senator Haines's rather doleful remarks based, so far as I understood, on the philosophy that resources are free and therefore they should be provided to Senator Haines's clients. I would rather talk about the Budget as such. In particular, I suggest that in addressing this Budget people should take care not to buy the sizzle, but rather to look at the steak. There is no doubt that the Budget has a considerable sizzle pertaining to it, the most important element of which is, and was intended to be, the figure of $5.5 billion surplus-that big fat figure which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) put up last Tuesday evening and expected everybody to focus upon that and on nothing else. That was quite a sizzle, combined with the estimate that in this financial year the whole of the public sector borrowing requirement would be totally eliminated. Those two things together the Treasurer calculated, because he is a considerable calculator, would enable him to sell this Budget to the financial market in a way which, regrettably no doubt, he failed to sell his two previous Budgets to the financial market. Along with these other elements of the sizzle there is the inflation forecast and I note the careful choice of words by the Treasurer in his Budget Speech on that matter. He forecasts the consumer price index to be `running at 4 1/2 per cent by the end of the financial year'. I take the Treasurer to mean by those very carefully chosen words something like a rate of 1.1 per cent on some kind of seasonally adjusted basis in the June quarter. Well, we will have to wait and see how that actually works out but again it is an attractive forecast by recent Australian standards, although not by the standards of most of our major overseas trading partners.

SPEECH.PARA: There is also the attractive forecast of business investment being up by 12 per cent in real terms and at first sight the attractive forecast of the balance of payments deficit being down by almost $2 1/2 billion to a level of $9 1/2 billion. I note in passing that this would still be 3 per cent of the national product or the domestic product which by traditional standards, even if those standards were still appropriate which they are not, would still be a very high figure. This is all part of the sizzle. There is also the promise for the repayment of Commonwealth debt and if one has a surplus of $5 1/2 billion or indeed any other figure there is only one thing one can do with it and that is to repay the debt. The Treasurer has undertaken to repay some debt of the Commonwealth Government currently domiciled overseas and some currently domiciled in Australia. As to the latter he indicates that he expects, as a consequence of that, to see some downward pressure on interest rates. Finally, there is that element which Senator Haines referred to, the cut in the beer excise, combined with the one which he did not, I think as far as I recall, refer to and that is the tax cuts of undetermined quantity and kind which are promised, held out to us, to commence on 1 July next year.

Up to a point one will have to say the sizzle sounds fine. What about the steak? Well, the surplus of $5 1/2 billion and along with it the removal of the public sector borrowing requirement is, as I said, an excellent outcome until one recalls how it has been achieved. Quite contrary to-I suppose one would have to say regrettably-the characteristically boastful claims in the Budget Papers, the achievement of that is not by genuine cuts in spending but by an enormous increase in the yield of taxation. The answer indeed as to how the Treasurer has obtained his surplus is to be found in the fine print, not in the Budget Speech which is television glossy, but in the fine print which is where one will find most of the steak. The sizzle is up front; the steak is in the fine print.

What we find, if we turn to Budget Paper No. 1, in the tabulation of the revenue estimates is that the yield from net pay as you earn (PAYE) taxation-that is the tax paid by ordinary wage and salary earners not by the Treasurer's friends, not by Alan Bond, Mr Anderson and people like that-is estimated to be up by 13.8 per cent, an amount no less than $4.3 billion. That increase alone more than accounts for the improvement in surplus between the $2 billion of last year and the $5 1/2 billion estimated for this year. Indeed, not only should PAYE income taxpayers expect to pay a lot more tax this year, but individual taxpayers generally must expect to pay a lot more tax this year because, taken as a whole, they are estimated to yield an increase of 14.6 per cent of taxation revenue to the Treasurer's coffers. Companies also are expected to do their bit. It is true, I think, that companies had a good year in 1987-88 which is the tax base upon which this year's company tax receipts will be levied and it is therefore not surprising that they should be estimated to be paying almost 16 per cent more company tax this year. Last in this litany but not least, sales tax is estimated to yield an additional 14.4 per cent this year; an additional $1.1 billion.

There are a couple of interesting reductions in the revenue receipts for this year and one of them is in the crude oil and liquefied petroleum gas levy which is estimated to fall by $670m. That has been in the making for some time now and we are beginning to see a sharp decline in that area of the tax field. The other significant decline in the non-tax area of the government revenue is in the dividend estimated to be payable by the Reserve Bank of Australia this year which is down by over $1 billion because of the significant change in the Reserve Bank's losses as distinct from previous gains in its sales of foreign exchange.

Let us have a look at that part of the sizzle which constituted the inflation forecast, that is that 4 1/2 per cent by the end of the current financial year which the Treasurer has arrived at by allocating approximately $500m of revenue to reducing the excise on beer. All of that is estimated to reduce the consumer price index this year by one half of one per cent in direct terms-it may be a little more than that taking direct and indirect effects together-and that is no doubt a useful element in achieving that 4 1/2 per cent figure which otherwise the Treasurer might have found to be unobtainable. The other element which will have a worthwhile effect in restraining price inflation this year will be the restraint flowing from the lower Australian dollar prices of imports as a consequence of the appreciation of the exchange rate which has taken place recently.

Let us come to the improvement in the balance of payments deficit. The balance of payments deficit is estimated to improve by $2.4 billion this year but the Treasurer has assumed, in his Budget, that the terms of trade will be 9 per cent better on average this year than they were last year. That is an estimate which flows from the assumption that commodity prices or export prices will on average remain where they are now, that there will be no decline from their current levels during the course of the current financial year. A 9 per cent increase on average in the terms of trade on our balance of payments is worth about $3 to $3 1/2 billion. The Treasurer estimates that our balance of payments will improve by $2.4 billion, so that we are roughly going backwards in some underlying sense of what one might call a cyclically adjusted sense. In other words, if we exclude the `fortuitous' terms of trade effect, we are going backwards by $1 billion in the balance of payments this year. I use the word fortuitous advisedly because it is precisely the word the Treasurer used when talking about the fortuitous improvement in the terms of trade and hence the balance of payments which had been achieved by the Government in the last financial year. He described that phenomenon as fortuitous when he spoke, using his prepared statement, to the Premiers on 12 May last at the Premiers Conference and Loan Council meeting on that date. It is worth while reminding ourselves that just as the balance of payments is, on the Treasurer's own forecasts, estimated to be going backwards by $1 billion in an underlying sense this financial year, if his forecast should be realised, so it went backwards by about $1 1/2 billion last financial year. Again we had a large improvement in the terms of trade-9.4 per cent on average-last financial year, and yet our balance of payments improved by only $1.3 billion. In fact, I understated it when I said that we went backwards by $1.5 billion; we went actually backwards by about $2 billion last year.

There is a very interesting table on page 23 of Budget Paper No. 1, in which the Treasury has very helpfully set out figures for the net interest deficit and the net income deficit in our balance of payments. The table shows that for the year just ended, 1987-88, the net interest deficit-that is, the net amount of interest paid by Australia to foreigners less what we received from foreigners by way of interest payments-amounted to 70.5 per cent of the total current account deficit on the balance of payments. In fact, if we take on board property income as well as interest on debt, so that we arrive at what is called the net income deficit, we find there is a net income deficit of almost 90 per cent of the current account deficit. They are continuing outgoings. I think that that is as indicative a symbol of the continuing mess with respect to our balance of payments as I have seen previously in an official document.

As Senator Chaney indicated during his remarks earlier, the Reserve Bank of Australia has expressed a degree of concern about the present external adjustment process-or rather, I should say, the lack of external adjustment-which goes considerably beyond the very guarded language used by the Treasury in its description of those processes in its statement No. 2 in Budget Paper No. 1 and certainly beyond that used by the Treasurer in his Budget Speech. The Reserve Bank, apart from those passages quoted by Senator Chaney, says on page 12 of its annual report, which was published two days after the Budget:
The current account deficit was smaller-
that is, in 1987-88-
both in absolute terms and as a proportion of GDP. However, most of the improvement-
in fact, it was more than most of the improvement-
was due to gains in Australia's terms of trade as a result of the strength of commodity prices.
The Reserve Bank report goes on to say:
. . . the strength of domestic demand contributed to higher import volumes, which grew more rapidly than export volumes. Unlike the two preceding years, net exports did not contribute to growth.

The Reserve Bank also has something to say, no doubt in an appropriately guarded way, about the high risk nature of the assumption on which the Treasurer has based his Budget. At page 15 of its annual report the Reserve Bank remarks:
. . . small, open economies-
and I wonder which ones it had in mind-
are vulnerable to sharp shifts in world sentiment, the more so when, as in Australia's case, the current account deficit is being balanced by basically short-term capital flows.
It might have called it `hot money'. Of course, the Reserve Bank is perfectly correct in drawing attention to that danger, and it goes on to say:
Foreign exchange intervention by the authorities-
such as the Reserve Bank itself has been conducting-
does not, of course, deal with the fundamental issues . . . it can provide a breathing space while other policies are coming into effect or are being further adjusted.

It is quite clear that underlying those words is the concern of the Reserve Bank that other policies are not coming into effect and that further adjustments are not taking place. I must say that I share the Reserve Bank's clear concerns in that regard. Indeed, those concerns are expressed even a shade more sharply at page 31 of the Reserve Bank's annual report. I always find that the language gets a little more direct the deeper one gets into a document. Most people assume that one will read only the first few pages and therefore they can be franker on, say, page 31. Page 31 of the Reserve Bank's report states:
The major medium-term issue for Australia continues to be the need to correct the balance of payments deficit and the high level of international indebtedness.
It goes on to say:
Despite the evidence of a further reduction in the current account deficit in 1987-88-
because of the terms of trade improvement-

there were some signs that the pace of underlying adjustment was not proceeding as in the previous two years. The reduction in the deficit in 1987-88 was due to a sharp rise in commodity prices and a consequent improvement in the terms of trade; the fall in import volumes was reversed.

The Reserve Bank is pointing to a very serious situation, a situation symbolised by the fact that by the end of June 1988 our net foreign debt amounted to $88.7 billion compared with $82.1 billion 12 months earlier-and, if I might interpolate, a figure of only $23 billion shortly after this Government came to office in June 1983.

It is also fair to add that during the June quarter this year there was a fall in our foreign indebtedness, as revealed by the statistics published by the Australian Statistician on, I think, 15 August, amounting to $3.4 billion. However, when one looks at these figures it is clear that they were more than entirely due to a valuation effect. During the June quarter this year the Australian dollar appreciated against the US dollar and indeed against foreign currencies generally. That reduced the Australian dollar value of our foreign currency denominator debt by $4,000m, which more than wholly accounted for the $3,400m fall in our debt during that quarter. But for the valuation effect, in other words, our debt continued to expand by $558m. Of course, the valuation effect is perfectly legitimate and I do not question the fact that it is there. I am asking whether the Government is going to bank on it continuing to reduce our debt through the continuing appreciation of our Australian dollar. I do not think so. So what will the Government do for an encore?

In his Budget Papers the Treasurer says that he proposes to repay some Commonwealth debt, which is part of what I earlier called the sizzle. He will repay some foreign debt and he will repay some domestic debt. It is very important, to be quite clear, that any repayment of foreign debt made by the Treasurer this year-that is to say, foreign debt of the Commonwealth Government-will not in itself make one iota of difference to Australia's total foreign indebtedness, because our foreign indebtedness flows from our balance of payments deficit. We finance our balance of payments deficit either by borrowing or by selling off bits of Australia-selling off the farms, as I think Senator Haines said earlier.

The fact that we have chosen to pay off a particular piece of debt does not affect that outcome in any way other than in the longer term through the reduced interest payments that we will have to make on it, and that may make some difference to our current account deficit to be financed. So let us be quite clear that when we see the Treasurer being photographed up in Tokyo repaying a bit of Australia's debt to Japan he is not reducing Australia's debt in any net sense; he is simply getting Japanese yen from the Reserve Bank's holding of foreign exchange and paying it to the Japanese banks, thereby reducing the debt owed by the Commonwealth to those Japanese lenders. Therefore, on that side of our balance sheet the debt is reduced, while on the other side, that is, the foreign exchange assets of the Reserve Bank, there is an equal and opposite reduction. The worth of the country is totally unchanged as a result of that process, as anyone who can read a balance sheet would understand.

As to domestic debt, it is true that if the Treasurer does, as he must if he has a surplus, repay the domestic debt he will make Commonwealth bonds a somewhat scarcer form of debt instrument within our markets than they have been otherwise and certainly relative to other forms of debt instruments such as bank bills, corporate debt, and so on. That does have some implications for the relative interest rates to be paid on Commonwealth bonds compared to the relative interest rates to be paid on other forms of debt instruments. Let us be quite clear again: that does not have any particular implication for the general level of interest rates in Australia, contrary again to the implication the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is seeking to convey to us by that magnificent sizzle which constituted the Budget Speech last Tuesday.

The general level of interest rates, of course, is a function today of two things, roughly speaking. One is the need to go on borrowing to finance that underlying balance of payments deficit which continues, even on the Treasurer's estimates, at $9 1/2 billion this year, or 3 per cent of domestic product. There is the need to go on financing that by borrowing and hence having to pay the interest rates to attract that foreign capital, those foreign loans to Australia. The second is the interest rate relativities between Australia and the international markets. So far as that last point is concerned-as I think Senator Chaney may have remarked-there have been in the last couple of months some rather disturbing signs that interest rates internationally are beginning to rise. Indeed, we saw another such rise, in London at least, only last Friday. I think it was the eighth successive rise in the course of the past two and a half months, making a total rise of 4 1/2 per cent during that time.

Finally, we come to the tax cuts. I do not often appeal to our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) for authority on economic matters or indeed, for that matter, on any other matters, but I have to say that in an appearance on the Sunday program a week ago our Prime Minister did deliver himself of a piece of excellent economic analysis in response to a question asked of him by Mr Laurie Oakes.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was an aberration.

—Senator Short suggests it was an aberration. I am prepared to defer to his opinion in that regard. He has known the Prime Minister, at least in these halls, longer than I have. Mr Oakes put to the Prime Minister on the Sunday before the Budget:

SPEECH.PARA: If there is a huge surplus then people are going to start really demanding to know why they can't have tax cuts now?
That is fair enough. The Prime Minister said:

Well, you see I disagree with you on that . . . Now I think it's quite clear that when we've still got a significant external problem, large external debt, current account deficits, the ordinary Australians know we've got to be careful about running up high import bills. Demand is running strongly in the economy at the moment and if we were to significantly increase the level of demand in the Australian economy-
that is to say by giving tax cuts-
our import bill would go up to unacceptably high levels and it would be dangerous.

As I say, the Prime Minister's analysis is impeccable. It happens to agree, as a matter of fact, entirely with the analysis spelled out during the course of last year's election campaign by Mr Maximilian Walsh, a well known correspondent with the Sydney Morning Herald, when he was attacking-admittedly on the basis of a false assumption-Mr Howard's tax policy.

What I would like to know-you may recall, Madam Acting Deputy President, that I put this question to Senator Walsh on Wednesday of last week, the day after the Budget, and I put it again to the Senate tonight-is this: by the end of 1988-89 will we not still have, to use the Prime Minister's words, `a significant external problem'? Even on the Treasurer's assumption, we will still have a balance of payments deficit of $9 1/2 billion at that time. Even if he is right, will we not still have, again to use the Prime Minister's words, `a large external debt'? From all the signs, it will be larger than it was at the end of June; it will probably be in the order of $95 billion by that time. Will not demand, again to use the Prime Minister's words, still `be running strongly in the economy' at that time, or is the Treasurer anticipating a recession by the end of the year? Again, his forecasts do not suggest so. He is forecasting a growth of 3 1/2 per cent in real terms in gross domestic product this year.

If none of those things is going to change from the present position, if at that time, again to use the Prime Minister's words, `we were to significantly increase the level of demand in the Australian economy'-that is, by giving a massive tax cut, which the Treasurer is apparently promising us-would not our import bill, to use the Prime Minister's words once more, `go up to unacceptably high levels'? Why would that not be just as dangerous then as the Prime Minister says it is now?

The only answer I received from Senator Walsh last week was to say, `Well, we will have another nine months of adjustment between now and then'. As I have said, the only adjustments we will have during that time will be that the debt will be $6 billion, $7 billion or $8 billion higher than it is now and the balance of payments deficit will have gone backwards in underlying terms by another billion dollars, and so on. The other part of Senator Walsh's answer at that time was that we will be having at that time a wage-tax trade-off. We will have to wait and see whether that will solve the problem for the Government.

What I would like to put to honourable senators is that all of this is on the basis of the Government's own forecast. It is all assuming that nothing goes wrong. Yet even on the basis of nothing going wrong, it is very difficult for me to see that it is possible for the Treasurer responsibly to make the tax cuts at that time that he is promising now. Of course, he can always do so irresponsibly. Perhaps if he calls an election quickly enough after doing so he might even get away with it. It is just possible. It would certainly be helpful to him in that case if he were to get this referendum passed shortly. We will have to wait and see about that.

I put to honourable senators: What will happen if things do not go right? What if between now and then we find that the terms of trade have not improved by an average of 9 per cent over the year, that export prices have begun to droop, that the balance of payments figure, instead of improving by $2.4 billion, has only improved by $1 billion, or has not improved at all, and looks like deteriorating in the period beyond that time-in 1989-90? Will this Government at that time have the consummate hide to say that it can still give the tax cuts the Treasurer is promising us today and on which he will be going early next year to negotiate with Mr Kelty for a wage-tax trade-off? What kind of steak will that be? Very much underdone, I would suggest.

What we are dealing with here is not a promise at all. Even on the basis of the Treasurer's own assumptions, that is to say, if things go right, it is very difficult to see how the trade-off can be delivered responsibly. If things go wrong it is very difficult to see how it can be delivered at all. It is a conditional promise only but a typical disposable promise, of which the Treasurer of this country has become over the past five years such a master.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robert Ray) adjourned.
