SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was talking about the difficulties facing the trade union movement in regard to conscientious objection and other provisions in the legislation which allow for people to refuse to belong to unions. I pointed out how over time union activity had won many of the improvements and important gains that have been made for workers. I instanced the case involving the industry in which I worked prior to World War II. Examining the Opposition's philosophy of voluntary unionism, I point out the tragic event in Western Australia some two years ago when two young men went to work on a non-unionised pastoral property. There was no award covering them. As the result of a disagreement with someone involved at the management level at that pastoral property the young men lost their lives. Earlier I gave the example of women not receiving annual leave. They are both examples of the sorts of problems that beset workers if we rely upon the Opposition's philosophy of voluntary unionism.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Senate that it was the conservative attitude that existed a couple of centuries ago-which brought about the Tolpuddle Martyrs and early events which formulated the principles of trade unionism-which gave rise to that terrible period of English history as industrialism was developing which is often referred to as the Dickens period. In that atmosphere and with that attitude in this country 100 years ago, when the trade unions were endeavouring to express their point of view about decent working conditions and decent incomes, they took the step of forming the Australian Labor Party. Their experience at that time of being unable to have any impact on the employers and community attitudes generally led them to take the political step of forming the Australian Labor Party. Over time we have seen that voluntary unionism has not protected the average worker from the employer, from those who seek to impose how much salary or what wages should be paid to those employed by them.

The struggle between labour and capital has gone on for centuries. It is because of this inherent struggle and conflict of interest that there is a need for industrial relations legislation. The Government is to be commended for bringing before the Parliament this important legislation which seeks to improve the balance between the power of capital and the power of labour. Given the lessons of history, one would have thought that we would have had the support of the Opposition. When we consider the debate that took place in the House of Representatives it is clear that even though the conservatives generally do not oppose trade unionism they still fall back on the principle of not having a proper industrial relations policy and system of conciliation and arbitration courts. Rather, they rely upon voluntary unionism and agreement at the work place, the coal face, the office, between the employer and the employee. Over time we have seen how unequal that situation has been. Workers have found it absolutely necessary to combine their efforts to get improvements in their working conditions and in their living wage.

I find it hypocritical, therefore, that members of the Opposition rely upon such a specious argument to oppose this legislation. They support the attacks made upon the arbitration system by talking about it being the `industrial club', as though the system were some sort of mechanism invented by this Government or by the Labor Party. In fact, it was the arbitration system that brought about the downfall of Prime Minister Bruce in 1929. The workers clearly showed then that they wanted to rely upon a judicial process that would protect the lower paid workers from the exploitation that existed at the time and that still exists to this day. Let us make no mistake about that. I instance what is taking place with the rationalisation and reconstruction of industry, what is taking place in the coal mining and pastoral areas of our country. We witness the rapacious and greedy attitude of some employers to employees who rely upon not only their own resource but also upon the collective strength of their union to protect their economic interests. We see this in even the Parliament. We have an interparliamentary union. We see the need for coming together to protect a common interest.

This is all the more important in the period of great change that is taking place in our various industries, competing with those of other countries. If we consider the great development of industrial production which will take place in the Asian region in the next 20 or 30 years, the increased competition that will bring and the need for Australian industry to be reconstructed, we realise how important it will be for us to have an industrial relations system operating in this country which will protect our workers. That new source of productive capacity will have considerable effect upon industrial relations in the work force and the living standards of our workers.

Yet the Opposition simplistically suggests that all we have to do is to get rid of the industrial relations club and get things back to the work place, where the employer has the cards stacked completely on his side. The employer is able to dictate, as he has done over the centuries, to his employees their conditions, salaries and wages. As everything else becomes bigger, unions also will need to become bigger. So I support unequivocally the proposals in this Bill to amalgamate our unions so that they can meet the new challenges facing them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to contribute to this debate tonight on the Government's Industrial Relations Bill 1988 and the associated legislation. I intend to argue that the Industrial Relations Bill does not represent substantial reform, as is claimed by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) and by the Government through the Minister's speech, and that there is nothing imaginative, dynamic or exciting in it. Furthermore, if the legislation is an attempt to finetune the existing system, I argue that it fails in a number of important ways. We on this side of the chamber will be looking to change by means of amendment to try to put the Bill into better order.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill has been slow in coming. I can remember in 1984 spending a couple of days in Melbourne at the chambers of the Hancock Committee of Review of the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems reading the submissions to that body. That was some four years ago. The Hancock Committee's report is claimed to be the basis of this legislation. As I said, at best the Bill lacks imagination. It could best be described as orthodox. However, if one accepts that the current industrial relations system of this country is satisfactory, and if one accepts that the philosophy of the centralised wage fixing system remains sound, then I guess one examines this Bill in terms of an updating of that system.

If one looks at the report of the Hancock Committee and at the Government's rationale, rather than at its rhetoric, that is exactly what they are talking about. The Hancock report saw no reason for radical change. I will refer to page 2 of that report, which summarises the position. It says:

We accept that the system is in need of revision and that efforts should be made to improve its operation. Our recommendations are directed to that end, and are aimed at improving the practical working of the system, reducing uncertainties and promoting a closer relationship and better co-operation between the existing institutions used to administer the system.

In other words there is an acceptance of the system, the rationale behind it and its operation. Hancock simply puts a case for updating the legislation. That rationale has been accepted by this Government. In turn, that is not surprising because we all know that this Government has a very special relationship with one of the key players in the industrial relations environment-the trade union movement. The trade union system supports an industrial relations system which gives it a major position in that game. Similarly, employer organisations accept their role. It is the role of a small number of groups that are given a very powerful responsibility over the lives and interests of a very large number of employees in this country. It is not surprising, therefore, that this Government has a vested interest in the maintenance of the existing system, and it is not surprising that it was not prepared even to countenance radical reform of the system.

When we look around the world we see many and varied industrial relations systems. Ours has developed in our cultural environment and there is no doubt, as with other industrial relations systems around the world, that it has its strengths and weaknesses. In this chamber on many occasions I have heard honourable senators talking about the American, Japanese or German systems, and looking at the strengths and virtues of such industrial relations apparatus. But one will always find, on any objective analysis, strengths and weaknesses in each. Because each is set in a different cultural and historical background, it is extremely difficult to assess which is a better system. When I look at the second reading speech of the Minister I accept that our system has credits. In particular I refer to the statement made on page 4 of the Minister's speech, which I will quote. He says:

Historically these arrangements have meant that all workers, whatever their industrial bargaining power, have enjoyed minimum standards of award entitlements which are protected by law. Protection of workers through the award system is one of the real achievements of the conciliation and arbitration machinery. Indeed, by the operation of this system we have, to a far greater extent than most other comparable industrialised countries, been able to prevent exploitation of the industrially weak.

That case for preventing the exploitation of the industrially weak, by the preservation of minimum standards, is the real strength of the existing Australian system. Built into the system is a safety net. However, it can be argued that in many cases the minimum standard that is referred to in the Minister's speech has ceased to be a minimum standard. The system has got away from the safety net concept and the standard awards are not necessarily at a mean level but, in some cases, at a level beyond that which some businesses can maintain and still remain in existence. That is when the system starts to break down, as it has when it has ceased to be a safety net type system.

As we know, this system, as I indicated, is divorced from business realities. For individuals in many ways it is a system which is remote and a system in which people pass responsibilities that are very important to their lives, to others-to professionals. There is the use of a language which they do not understand and an atmosphere far removed from their places of work. Such is the case in Melbourne where these bodies meet at a national level. The result of all this is that the award conditions that are passed down in many ways are remote from the individuals and their working environments. There is a separation, therefore, from the award making procedure-the industrial relations procedure-and the coalface. We, on this side of the chamber, believe that therein lies a major shortcoming of the system.

The history of the system, as has been stated tonight by Senator Gietzelt, is very much the history of the labour struggle. The rhetoric of Senator Gietzelt tonight was that the struggle between labour and capital is legendary. He said it has been going on for centuries. A little earlier, before the dinner suspension, he talked of the conflict of strength between employers and employees. He said that the workers should unite in order to combat the employer. It is that rhetoric of class warfare, the continual battle of labour against capital. What we are suggesting, however bold it may be, is that perhaps we should be moving away from that type of rhetoric. Some of my colleagues interjected on Senator Gietzelt. One honourable senator said it is a rhetoric that is perhaps 30 years past and another said it is 50 years past.

We on this side of the chamber are asking why we must always presume that there must be a conflict between labour and capital. Why must they have conflicting objectives? Why can we not look in the other direction and realise that both can have a common interest in mutual prosperity; that labour and capital, with the right industrial relations atmosphere and the right leadership, can work together as a team towards such things as improved productivity, greater rewards, greater work satisfaction, the prospect of higher living standards, improved job opportunities through greater prosperity in business, and so forth. We on this side of the chamber have that optimism that with a different attitude these goals can be achieved. It is true that this requires a greater faith in individuals than have those honourable senators on the other side of the chamber. They have greater faith in organisations and structures that make decisions for individuals-the corporate state mentality.

We believe that, if individuals are given the opportunity, they can make very sound decisions for their own benefit and welfare. We would say, furthermore, that with that type of attitude-decisions that are made at the coalface-what is introduced into the system that is not there at the moment is a new flexibility. So what we have put in our new industrial relations policy is the case for radical change to the existing industrial relations system, not simply the cosmetic changes that occur in the Bill. We would go further than Hancock or the Government. We would allow employers and employees, when they wish to take an alternative path to the existing centralised system, to reach voluntary agreements in their labour relations, voluntary agreements that reflect the uniqueness of each and every work environment.

As I indicated, that involves a passing of responsibility back to individuals. It allows choice and rejects the uniform standards and approaches that derive from a centralised system. It facilitates the removal of archaic work practices through the greater flexibility that can follow. It allows greater scope, as I said, for flexibility in hours of work, including permanent part time work. We could say there should be flexible rewards for skill and ability. It would introduce a new enthusiasm and hope into industrial relations that will not be introduced without a radical change. We, therefore, are disappointed that the Government has not been prepared to seize this opportunity for a new direction. It has not been prepared to live up to its rhetoric of claiming to make substantial change.

Although we advocate that more radical position, we nevertheless accept that the existing safeguard of a centralised system will remain the basis of the system for a very long time. We hope, as I said, that some individuals, by agreement, will take courses separate from that. Nevertheless, we accept that the basic centralised system will exist for some considerable time. Therefore, it is necessary in this debate to examine that system in the light of this Government's proposed amendments. As I indicated at the outset, even when we attempt to do that we are disappointed that this Bill fails in what seems to us to be a number of fundamental ways.

The first way, which was mentioned by my Leader, Senator Chaney, is as to compliance. I suggest that compliance has been the major failing of Australia's conciliation and arbitration system. The system was designed to avoid direct industrial action and, with it, all that that represents in terms of costs to individuals and to the nation. Of course, there is within the system an opportunity for an appointed independent arbiter to make a fair decision upon the parties that is binding. In other words, when conciliation fails or whenever the parties are unable to agree, the provision is for independent arbitration which is binding and, therefore, according to the theory of the system, there should be no need for direct action. I am not a union knocker; I am a former unionist myself, I am pleased to say, on a voluntary basis. But I regret to say that on one side organised labour has been able to disregard the decisions that it has found unsatisfactory, and with no effective remedial action. That has caused the system to break down. Unless both sides to a bargain are going to be bound to that bargain, it will not be enforceable, it will not stand, and the other side, and eventually the community, will lose faith in the system.

That is not just what the Opposition says. In fact, it is said by Labor's Minister when he speaks of the failing of our current system in relation to compliance. It is reasonable, I suppose, that we should therefore presume that there would be significant change in that regard in this Bill. I remind you, Madam Acting Deputy President, of what Minister Willis said in relation to the first version of this Bill on 14 May last year:

An essential element of any industrial relations system which provides benefits and protections to registered organisations and their members is that there should be effective means of ensuring compliance with the decisions of its institutions . . .
He therefore agrees that an essential requirement is that there be effective means of ensuring compliance. He continued:
The principal initiative-
that is, of the previous Bill-
is that the present bans clause provisions, which have long since fallen into disrepute and are now substantially moribund, will be replaced by a new direction and injunction process.

We know that that new direction and injunction process is not included in this Bill. But it does not mean that his statement that the compliance provisions of the existing law have become moribund and fallen into disrepute has changed. So he acknowledges the major failing of the existing system. Regrettably, when we look at this Bill, we see that he has made no change to that failed system. I would have thought that even this Government would have to concede that it cannot talk about this piece of legislation as a substantial reform without there having been introduced within it effective new compliance provisions. They are simply not there.

We know that the failing of the compliance provisions has forced employers to resort to the common law to protect themselves from abuse. It is now history that there was a public uproar when this Government sort to abolish those common law powers of injunction and to downgrade the capacity to use the secondary boycott provisions of the Trade Practices Act to protect innocent third parties. The Australian community was simply not prepared to allow those safeguards to be lost. When the Government directed its attention to its changed Bill, what did it do? We presumed that there would be new compliance provisions but, of course, the Government received its instructions from the trade union movement, and its instructions were, simply, that it was not to introduce effective compliance provisions. I remind the Senate of the words of the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Simon Crean, as reported in the Australian Financial Review of 17 August, when he gave his directions to the Government. He said:
They can still introduce a Bill but it will have to be one which does not do anything on compliance.

That is what we find to be the Bill that is before us. It is a major shortcoming of this Bill and one that, by itself, means that it fails any reasonable test as a substantial reforming piece of legislation.

The second shortcoming I wish to address is that, whether or not we have a centralised system in this country, it is the view of those on this side of the chamber that there should be freedom of the individual not to join a union, and that that freedom should be protected. We do not say that in an attempt to weaken the unions of Australia. We have a view, which of course the Government would not accept, that a new element of voluntarism within unions would strengthen the union movement. There is no doubt that de facto compulsory unionism exists in this country through preference clauses and closed shops, and that it is enforced by industrial pressure. We say that it is not essential to an effective centralised system. We realise that it is a valuable tool to enhance union power. Thus, in the same way as in other cases that I have mentioned tonight, it is supported by the Australian Labor Party as the political wing of the trade union movement. We on this side of the chamber say that it will be a wonderful day for individual freedom when Australian people have the opportunity to contribute to genuine voluntary unionism. As I said, the effect of that might well be strengthening of the union movement, not a weakening of it. Of course, that is not in any way achieved by this legislation, which simply reinforces this de facto compulsory unionism.

The third criticism that I raise is that this system does not provide the accountability or the representative capacity that we would like to see in industrial bodies. I am dealing with the provisions of the Bill that provide for amalgamation of unions by, in effect, a compulsory process. It is our concern that these larger amalgamated bodies will not have the accountability or the representative capacity that we believe is necessary for effective industrial relations in this country in the future. We are not talking about the past; we are talking about the future and, hopefully, an environment in which more individuals will seek to play a role. If our dream ever came true it would be on a voluntary basis. We would therefore support, rather than the direction that is being taken in this Bill, measures aimed at a movement towards enterprise unions. We believe it would achieve single bargaining units and also units with a better understanding of enterprise, rather than particular trades or skills, and with a closer relationship with the work force and, therefore, better accountability.

It fits well with our theme of looking for greater cooperation in industrial relations in this country rather than confrontation; in other words, an entirely different attitude to the entrenched rhetoric of class conflict upon which the Labor Party's position has been founded. We believe that this would improve the industrial relations position in this country. Before people say, `But the industrial relations position has been vastly improved', I simply ask them to look at the coal industry and the shipping industry in this country, and to look at what happens on our waterfront-and another major report will be brought down on that aspect in the next few days. They should look particularly at the position in the eastern States in relation to grain storage, handling and transport. If we look at those areas, we very quickly realise that industrial relations in this country are still costing individuals and the nation a great deal.

I wish to touch upon the coal industry and remind honourable senators that in 1987 8,902 working days were lost per 1,000 employees in the coal industry-40 times the national average. So here we have an industry which, until very recently, was the major export earning industry of Australia-it has now just been passed by wool, but it is critically important to our future-and we find that it suffers from major industrial problems that are making it less competitive on the world scene, and that is costing the nation and, as I have said, individuals greatly.

Let me touch again upon shipping and the waterfront in this country. I remind honourable senators that the Industries Assistance Commission, an independent body, recently released its draft report on coastal shipping, which concluded that excessive coastal shipping freight rates wipe between $300m and $700m from Australia's gross domestic product annually, and a considerable part of that is put down to industrial practices. Productivity levels in Australia in these industries are about half the level of European container terminals, that is, of developed Western nations, and 40 per cent of many Asian ports. And we wonder why our current account balance is so appalling. Unless we can compete in these very basic areas we will not run a trade balance that goes into the black.

In relation to the grain storage, handling and transport area, I remind honourable senators also of the recent royal commission into those industries that identified total cost savings under a more competitive environment in these sectors of around $10 per tonne of grain. Of this, 15 per cent conservatively would arise from an improvement in the industrial relations environment and, more specifically, better working practices. So much remains to be done in critical areas. We say that, if we provided this country with an environment in which individuals could play a greater part and employers and employees could join together to find a relationship that could be of mutual advantage, there would be benefits in that for the community as a whole. So we do not see in this Bill the structural reforms that would be necessary to help overcome problems critical to Australia's economic well-being.

In the few minutes that remain I just want to touch upon a few of the specific changes that are included in this piece of legislation, because even if it is not all that important from a substance point of view it is nearly a couple of hundred pages in length. Firstly, we are told that the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is to change its name. It is recommended by Hancock, it is true, but that does not seem to us to indicate any major change in substance. Secondly, we read that the parties will be encouraged to formulate and use their own dispute settlement procedures. I remind honourable senators that that falls short of the Hancock recommendation, which was that legislation require all awards to contain a procedure for the resolution of grievances. That is not included within this Bill. The third of these separate areas, that of the new idea of certified agreements, could almost be described as a small, timid step towards the industry-type bargaining of which we have been speaking. Certainly the Minister, in his speech, picks up our language by claiming that it adds a new flexibility. But when one looks at the legislation one finds that these agreements are likely to be rare, that they cannot come into being without the Commission's certification and that, nevertheless, the Minister retains power to intervene-all of which we would suggest is a very patronising way of encouraging employers and employees to reach their own agreement. I note that it was not in the Hancock report, which suggests to me that it is being introduced in this Bill largely as a political response.

The labour court idea has been dropped, and that I applaud. There are new provisions in relation to demarcation-weird provisions, I would suggest, even though they had the blessing of Hancock-to give peak bodies within the system, those who have this special relationship, an extra responsibility to try to resolve demarcation disputes. We on this side of the Senate believe in certainty in the law and certainty in operations of this type, and we say that the Commission should accept its responsibility to settle demarcation disputes and have adequate powers to enforce the orders that it makes.

There are improved coordination and cooperation provisions in the Bill between Federal and State tribunals but I note that they fall far short of Hancock's recommended integrated system. The Bill provides that secret ballots will apply to registered associations, but of course it does not provide that there should be secret ballots prior to industrial action, as we would have advocated. We believe that that one step is a step back. There are now circumstances in which strike pay can be ordered. It can be ordered in relation to health and safety issues. I suppose that in a world of goodness and light that would seem to be reasonable but we are all aware of abuses, particularly within the building industry, where issues that are not health and safety issues nevertheless are promoted under that description.

In summary, therefore, the Bill does not offer the structural change that we on this side of the chamber believe is necessary. The Bill is nowhere near as significant as the Government indicates. Even if we accept the existing system it can be substantially improved and that we will seek to do in a constructive and positive way in the committee stage of this debate. Finally, I simply say that a better system is outlined in the coalition policy statement on industrial relations and I commend that to all those interested in this subject.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in this debate with some anger tempered with sadness, having listened to people on the other side of the chamber uttering terms such as `anti-union', `anti-worker' and `anti-community'. These people have read in books and newspapers about what happens in the industrial relations field, but I speak from the position of having been involved in that history making process and knowing the people involved in it on both sides of the fence. So I can speak with some authority and some force.

SPEECH.PARA: The Industrial Relations Bill provides for necessary and constructive changes in Australia's industrial relations system, more far-reaching than any other changes over a period of more than 80 years. This Bill is debated by a Labor Government which has a clear understanding of the importance of, and the need to improve, opportunities for consultation rather than growing confrontation, which would be the case if the coalition were in power. It was designed and compiled in a spirit of cooperation and consultation amongst enlightened representatives of the Government and the trade union movement with an input by employer organisations to the Hancock Committee of Review of Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems.

We need to look in a positive manner not only at the words in the Bill but also at its potential for change. A new direction is being taken by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and its collective constituent unions which is leading to a more interventionist and more participative role by trade unionists at all levels of industry and workplace activity. It takes into account the rights and responsibilities of participating in the future shaping of our society and our nation which will create a new image on the world scene. Compare the negative, nagging and unconvincing arguments of the New Right and its representatives in this chamber with the forthright, constructive statements of trade union spokespersons and senators on the Government side of the chamber.

We, the labour movement, negotiated the prices and incomes accord and then gave life to that document which established the base upon which we have built a better economic structure. This document was more than a proposal for prices and wages. It was a far-reaching economic document providing for wage and salary stability, redistribution of income to profits-that is, less wages to encourage expanded investment-industrial democracy, restructuring of industry, training for skills and, last but not least, health and safety. It sought to protect real wages, but it recognised that the 10 per cent lost during the Howard years would take time to regain. It gave clear recognition to the need to create jobs for the unemployed. This Government has met those goals, those challenges, and has created more than one million jobs in less than five years.

This Government, very early in its first term, called an economic summit at which a broad cross-section of our community was represented. At this successful operation of consensus, representatives of the Australian Council of Trade Unions showed themselves to be the most competent in the gathering when identifying our problems and putting forward solutions. The clear and unequivocal commitment by the ACTU and its collective constituents to changes in our society involved more enlightened social attitudes and more constructive economic approaches, including the production of wealth and the fair distribution of that wealth. It is not just a notional view of acceptance that with rights go responsibility but a clear and ringing assertion of it. It is against this background that this Bill will pass through the Senate.

Senator Chaney picked out what he calls unfortunate incidents. He talked about the problem with the Dollar Sweets Co. Pty Ltd and the fact that a truck driver had had problems with people on strike. I assure Senator Chaney and other Opposition senators that when people are involved in industrial disputes and lose their total income they bear all sorts of pressures. As the history of industrial relations has shown, people who break picket lines or scab certainly pay the penalty in mental torture if they have any decency.

The Mudginberri dispute was also mentioned. A group of people without any concern for the long term effects on other unions in the industry or people in the community decided to make an agreement which was worse than award provisions. Is it any wonder there was a dispute about that? It is impotence that is felt by the unions in seeking to protect hard-won gains; it is not so much aggression. (Quorum formed)

Honourable senators opposite talk about the force of the trade unions. What force do the trade unions have? They have this wonderful weapon to seek the support of their fellow workers, to convince by argument that certain actions should be supported. What about the force on the other side? The employer calls the police and has people thrown off sites if there are any problems, such as there were in the South East Queensland Electricity Board dispute. Employers even had workers arrested and charged with an offence when no offence was committed. The Supreme Court found that to be so.

The subcontractors on the Commonwealth Bank Building in Brisbane went broke recently. Workers decided to peacefully stay on the job so they could be seen to be asking for the wages to which they were entitled. They felt, as happened in the past, that the prime contractor had a responsibility to pay them the wages their wives and families needed. What was the response of the employer? He sent for the State police to have them removed. They would not be moved and it is to the credit of the police that they did not proceed any further. I mention that to demonstrate that the force of the trade unions is not very great, but that the forces of darkness, those in opposition to the trade unions, represented by people on the other side, are very great indeed.

Senator Parer and Senator Chaney talked about the safety and health problems in the construction industry as though a person's life or health was not important. My advice to workers has always been that if they get the sack they can find another job somewhere but that if they lose a leg or an arm or their life that cannot be replaced. So safety and health are very important. Of all the agreements that have been made in Queensland in relation to construction work and other work place agreements, there is one thing that employers have always agreed upon and that is not to demand a `no strike' on health and safety issues. On many occasions when there have been those sorts of problems the trade unions have said, `That area is dangerous. We will work on any other part of the construction site'. They have sought only to protect the lives of their members. What happens when the employer says, `You are not going to make any management decisions. You'll work when I tell you'. Whose fault is it when work stops? Very clearly it is that of the employer.

At least I have one ally: Senator Crichton-Browne said last night that he supported the ban on the use of the lower dining room because one of the staff had fallen on a faulty staircase and injured herself. At least someone on the other side of the chamber is not totally in darkness. I have never argued for the settlement of disputes; I have always argued for the prevention of disputes. I think that is a much more positive approach.

When we look at the amount of lost time because of disputes, we see that from January 1976 to February 1983 the monthly average of working days lost was 249,000. People may wonder why we choose that period: it was that of the Fraser Government. From March 1983 to December 1987, when the Hawke Government was in power, the figure was 115,590. When that comparison is made we can see who has done the best job of gaining continuity or work in this country and eliminating or reducing disputes.

If we look at the Menzies years and the way in which the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and the court operated, we see that the Commission used to make decisions about awards and then took unto itself the right to penalise people if those decisions were not carried through or respected by the unions. When one went into a dispute in those days about an issue no-one ever asked, `Does it endanger people's lives? Is the dispute merited? Is there a case?'. One question was asked: `Are you in dispute?'.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts and Territories, upon notice, on 24 November 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it true that the appointments of all the members of the Council of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority have been terminated by the Minister.

(2) Is it further true that the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority Ordinance 1976 as amended provides that appointments of members of the Council of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority can only be terminated by the Governor-General; if so, on the basis of the advice given to him has the Minister, in dismissing the members of the Council, exceeded his authority under the Ordinance.
(3) With respect to the statement in the Minister's media release of 15 September 1987 regarding the transition of the powers of the Council to the Chief Education Officer:
(a) what steps does the Minister plan to take to ensure that the Consultative Committee is in fact consulted by the Chief Education Officer; and
(b) does the Minister regard this Committee as an adequate check on what are, in effect, dictatorial powers which he has vested in the Chief Education Officer.

(4) Since the Australian Capital Territory public school system under a representative statutory council was widely regarded as the most successful in Australia, is it the intention of the Minister to restore a participatory form of governance to this system; if so, when.

(5) As a matter of law and in practical terms, has the Minister not left the Australian Capital Territory public education system without effective management at the system wide level, when regard is had to the fact that the body charged with responsibility for the management of public education under the aforementioned Ordinance has purportedly been dismissed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts and Territories has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 15 September 1987, the Hon. Minister revoked the appointments of three acting members of the Schools Authority. He also terminated the appointment of one of these acting members as acting Chairman. The appointments of other members ceased upon the commencement of the Schools Authority (Amendment) Ordinance 1987 which implemented the proposal to restructure the Schools Authority announced in the Budget context on 15 September.

(2) The Australian Capital Territory Schools Ordinance 1976, before the amendments which commenced on 31 December 1987, provided for the dismissal of permanent members by the Governor-General. However, the Minister had power under the Ordinance at that time to appoint acting members. The Minister also had power to revoke acting appointments made by him.

(a) In view of the representations received, the Minister for Arts and Territories agreed to make changes in the advisory arrangements for the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority. The Ordinance will be amended to introduce a statutory Advisory Committee in place of the Committee provided for in the Schools Authority (Amendment) Ordinance 1987. The legislation will provide for a Committee of 7 members: a Chairperson appointed by the Minister, 2 School Board representatives, 1 Ministerial representative and 1 representative each from the Parents and Citizens Association, the Pre-Schools Association and from an organisation representing the teaching staff.

The functions of the Committee will be specified in the Ordinance. The Advisory Committee's role will be to provide advice to the Chief Education Officer, who will be required to take account of that advice in the performance of the Authority's functions. The Committee will meet at least eight times a year and will report to the Minister when it considers it appropriate to do so.

(b) The Consultative Committee is not intended to act as a check on the activities of the Chief Education Officer, but rather to provide him or her with advice on the views of the community on issues relating to public schools in the Australian Capital Territory. The powers conferred upon the Schools Authority are not exceptional. The Authority is subject to Ministerial direction in the performance of its functions.

(4) In addition to the Advisory Committee mechanism referred to above there is a significant degree of community participation in the governance of the Australian Capital Territory public schools: as well as various formal and informal consultative mechanisms, each school has a Board comprised of parents, teachers and, in the case of secondary schools, students, which is responsible for determining the educational program and policies of that school. In addition, an Australian Capital Territory Education and Training Council has been established to achieve better planning and co-ordination of all sectors of Australian Capital Territory education. The Council comprises the Chief Executives of all Australian Capital Territory education bodies together with employer, union and community representatives and is chaired by Emeritus Professor Fred Gruen.

(5) Under the Schools Authority Ordinance the Chief Education Officer is solely responsible for conducting the affairs of the Authority. Management of public education is more effective because authority and responsibility are clearly focused. There is no question as to the legitimacy or effectiveness of the Authority's management.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 22 March 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Minister agree that there is complete incompatibility between Mr Beazley's views as expressed in the Peace and Disarmament Bulletin of December 1987 in which he states that `the Australian Government would take full charge of the management of any nuclear accident in Australian territory' and his statement in the Cairns Post of 20 October 1987 that `Contingency plans for accidents involving nuclear warships were a state responsibility'; if not, why not.

(2) How does the Minister reconcile these statements with the reports in the Cairns Post of 9 July 1987 which refer to the detailed plans which the United States has to deal with a nuclear weapons accident in Australian ports.
(3) Have there been 3 changes of Australian Government policy on this matter within the last 6 months; if not, how does the Minister explain these conflicting statements.

(4) If there have been changes in Government policy, what is the current Federal Government policy and who has responsibility in the event of: (a) an accident involving nuclear-powered warships in Australian territory; and (b) a nuclear weapons accident involving warships in Australian territory.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) No. As the honourable senator would be aware, the State Governments control various emergency services organisations (notably the Police, Fire Brigade and Ambulance) whose resources might be required in the event of an accident involving nuclear weapons or the reactors on visiting warships. As it would be inappropriate for the Commonwealth to draw up detailed contingency plans for the use of State Government resources, the development of such contingency plans is primarily a State Government responsibility. The Commonwealth of course also accepts responsibilities in the contingency planning area, such as in establishing the basic conditions under which foreign warships may visit Australia and assisting the State Government in the emergency planning process through the provision of scientific and technical support and facilitating and coordinating assistance in the event of an accident from the foreign government involved.

The statement in the Peace and Disarmament Bulletin of December 1987 was provided in response to a query whether Australia or the US would be responsible for dealing with a nuclear weapons accident in Australia and was intended to make plain that Australian government authorities would be in charge-not US Government authorities, as had erroneously been inferred from a CINCPAC Instruction that had been released by the US Government under its Freedom of Information legislation. Contrary to the reports in the Cairns Post of 9 July 1987, the contents of this Instruction do not represent `detailed plans for dealing with a nuclear weapons emergency in Australian ports'. The Instruction instead provides broad policy and administrative guidelines on nuclear safety.
(3) No. See answer to parts (1) and (2) above.

(4) (a) and (b) In the event of an accident involving the nuclear reactors or any nuclear weapons which might be carried on foreign warships visiting Australia, the provision of any assistance that might be required from authorities under the control of State Governments would be a State Government responsibility. Similarly, the Commonwealth would be responsible for providing such assistance as might be required from the relevant Commonwealth authorities. The foreign government whose reactors or weapons were involved would itself be responsible inter alia for notifying the appropriate Australian authorities that an accident had occurred and for cooperating with them so that prompt action might be taken in order to minimize the consequences of the accident. The overall direction and control of emergency action within Australian territory would be the responsibility of Australia; in the case of naval ports, provision of emergency services is the responsibility of the RAN and in civil ports it is a matter for State authorities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 1 June 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Approximately how much, taking into account CPI increases since then, in 1988 dollars, was spent on the control and treatment of poliomyelitis in the five years before and the five years after the introduction of the general vaccination against the disease.
(2) What is the projected cost, in the same terms as in (1) above, of the control and treatment of AIDS-related illnesses between 1989 and 1994.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Poliomyelitis vaccination, using Salk vaccine was introduced in Australia in July 1956. The five years before and after the introduction of the vaccine is the period from 1951 to 1961.

A great proportion of the relevant information needed to answer this part of the honourable senator's question is only available from each State Government and from individual public hospitals. Given the length of time which has elapsed since Salk vaccine was introduced, and the number of organisations from which details would need to be sought, I am not prepared to authorise the resources needed to collect and collate the necessary data.

(2) Problems in projecting the incidence of AIDS and uncertainties about the impact of new treatment regimes on the progression of AIDS and on mortality rates, mean that related costs for the period in question cannot be projected with a high degree of confidence. There is currently no vaccine for AIDS available.

Earlier this year, the Department of Community Services and Health commissioned a two stage study into costing the AIDS epidemic in Australia. Results of phase 1 of this study are to be included in a policy discussion paper on the National AIDS strategy, which is to be tabled in Commonwealth, State and Northern Territory Parliaments later this year. The second part of the study, anticipated to commence later this year, will determine a framework for identifying and projecting total costs of AIDS-related illnesses.
